ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 10.--Gambling has been going on here for some days, and five houses, including Chinn Morgan's old place, have been running with locked doors.

When Comrade Joseph Rhein, of the James H. Perry Post, awoke yesterday morning at reveille and found himself taking an involuntary shower bath he declared that he had not expected that the camp life of 1861 would be so perfectly reproduced, and said it made him feel a boy again.

READING, Penn., Sept. 10.--Pius W. Zimmerman, a brakeman on the Reading Railroad, was run over and killed by a pusher engine last night. He had sat down between the trucks and was overcome with sleep, having been working for 30 hours at a stretch. He was 23 years old and was but recently married.

A telephone message received at Long Island City about midnight last right from Sea Cliff said there was a large fire near Glen Cove, and it was supposed that either Charles A. Dana's residence or that of Mr. Perkins at Glen Cove Landing was on fire. No definite particulars were to be obtained. The fire could be seen at many points several miles distant.

PIEDRAS NEGRAS, Mexico, Sept. 10, via Galveston.--Parties arriving from Garagoza report that the two political factions in the State of Cohohuila have established recruiting camps and are enlisting men as rapidly as possible. If this information is true it presages an uprising in Cohohuila at an early day. Efforts are being made to ascertain the truth of the report.

When the application of the civil service rules to the municipal service in this city was under discussion a good deal of consideration was given to the question whether they could be applied advantageously to the laborers and lower grades of skilled workmen employed by the city.

A correspondent of the Toronto (Ontario) Mail relates the following: "In the year 1868 I was away from home at work on Bridge-street, in Belleville, on the west side of the river. At about 3 o'clock in the afternoon a friend of mine entered the shop with whom I had last parted on not very good terms,...

Dr. Swartwout, of the Chambers-Street Hospital, went wednesday night with an ambulance to the Merchants's Hotel, in Cortlandtstreet, to remove Henry Wilson, of No. 441 East Lombard-street, Baltimore, who had been attended there by Dr. A.S. Diossy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--Postmaster-General Vilas arrived in Chicago yesterday, and will remain here a day or two. He fought shy of visitors to-day and went out to call on those people whom he wanted to see instead of waiting for them to call on him.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 10.--D.L. Lake, of Haverstraw, died of an apoplectic fit on a West Shore train near Little Falls this morning, death following seven minutes after he was attacked. Friends took charge of the body and telegraphed to relatives at his home.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 10.--The Local Option bill has been passed by the House as it came from the Senate, and is now a law. The bill provides that upon the application for prohibition signed by one-tenth of the voters in any county, the Ordinary shall hold an election to determine whether or not spirituous liquors shall be sold in that county.
The inquest in the case of Gretchen Holz, who, with her sister Elia, lost their lives through a mistake of Druggist Charles Am Ende, was concluded by Coroner Haughey, of Hoboken, last night.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 10.--PostmasterGeneral Carling has issued orders to-day requesting the Post Office authorities at Montreal to have all mails going from that city to the...

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 10.--The Cincinnati Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, of which Dr. A.B. Leonard, the Prohibition candidate for Governor, is a member, took several votes yesterday bearing indirectly upon the candidacy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--The following is a synopsis of sundry decisions rendered by the Treasury Department in customs cases during the past week:
A Democratic officeholder went off on a Summer vacation, and one of his friends visiting the city inquired for him.

There will be an elaborate parade and races by wheelmen in Brooklyn on next Saturday. Starting at 9 A.M., the line of march will be along Bedford-avenue to Eastorn Parkway, to Prospect Park, to Coney Island.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Sept. 10.--The schooner Isaac Carleton, Capt. Drisco, which ar rived here yesterday from Sagua, had on board the Captain and crew of the brig C.C. Robinson, of New-York, which sprung a leak during a hurricane on Aug. 3 in latitude 34 11', longitude 75 52. They saved nothing, and with probably be taken to Boston by the Carleton.

MARIETTA, Ga., Sept. 10.--Several weeks ago Mrs. E.R. Tennant, of this place, was tendered and accepted the office of Superintendent of Women's Work at the New-Orleans Exposition, the place formerly held by Julia Ward Howe. To-day she publishes a card resigning the position and assigning as a reason: "My husband is opposed to it, and I give it up in deference to his wishes."

SUNBURY, Penn., Sept. 10.--The Rev. J. K. Millett, of McEwensville, was drowned in the river at Watsontown yesterday. He was out in a boat with a young girl named Culp, and by some means the boat was upset. Miss Culp succeeded in saving her life by clinging to the boat, but Mr. Millett, although a good swimmer, went under. He was about 46 years old.

Speaking of the Syracuse Oil Works fire an experienced oil manufacturer from Pittsburg, who was an eye witness of the fire, said that the oil company's works there were very poorly protected against fire.

The Civil Service Reform Association is sending out for distribution throughout the city and State many thousands of circulars calling attention to a circular recently issued asking old soldiers to demand the passage of the Earl bill at the next session of the Legislature.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 10.--The American Social Science Association met this morning. The report of General Secretary F.B. Sanborn, of Concord, Mass., included a special report on "Social Science Lectures in American Universities." Mr. Sanborn eulogized Gen. Grant, who, he said, was at one time a member of the association, and who, when President, recognized the principles of civil service. Papers were read by Prof. E.J. James, of Philadelphia, and E.W. Bemis, of Springfield, Mass.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10.--The statue of Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry, the naval hero of the last war between Great Britain and the United States, who won the battle of Lake Erie with a force inferior to that of the enemy, 72 years ago to-day, was unveiled to-day in the presence of more distinguished men than have been gathered together here on any public or private occasion for many years.
Capt. Barrie and the crew of the wrecked French bark Duc de Malakoff, who arrived on the steamship Albano late on Wednesday, will sail for their homes to-day on the French steamship Normandie.

The Young America Cricket Club will play a match to-morrow against the Staten Island Club at Staten Island. A delay of a day caused this match to be played instead of All New-York against the Gentlemen of Philadelphia, D.S. ...

Rumors concerning the next quarterly dividend of the New-York Central were current in Wall-street yesterday. An intimation that the dividend would be passed was emphatically denied by two of the Directors of the company.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10.--A little boy named McCloskey, who is only 11 years old, was taken to the Eighth District Police Station last night, where he told a story which has resulted in the capture of a gang of juvenile burglars.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 10.--A suit was decided to-day in the Superior Court involving points of interest to the general public. In January, 1883, James G. Holmes, late of Charleston, and now of Baltimore, was ejected from ...
BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 10.--The fact has just been made public that Willard F. McIntyre, aged 26 years, who had been employed as business manager for George G. Goodrich Co., ...

The Democrats of the Third Assembly District of Westchester County, at their convention to-day, at Pine's Bridge, for the purpose of electing delegates to the State, Senatorial, and Judiciary Conventions, stood 23 to 20 in favor of the renomination of Henry C. Nelson for State...

There were more inquiries yesterday as to weather predictions than are often heard in the business centres of this busy city. Everybody was asking what kind of weather the Signal Service Bureau predicted for to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10.--Among those who found time to entertain at their homes today were Dr. Henry E. Turner, Henry W. Cozzens, Mrs. Seth B. Stitt, Mrs. J.T. Gilbert, John N.A. Griswold, Mrs. Ogden H. Burrows, Miss Leary, Mrs. B.S. Clarke, and Robert Goelet.
WALTON, N.Y., Sept. 10.--A lively chase for a child occurred between this village and Oneonta to-day. Julius Marvin, of Brooklyn, some time ago placed his child in charge of his father's family here.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10.--Five thousand persons witnessed the bicycle contests in Hampden Park to-day. Howell easily won the one-mile safety bicycle race in 2:55, Woodside second, Higham third. Woodside made the first three-quarters in 0:46 3-5, 1:28, and 2:13 3-5.

Yesterday, in the Lord Mayor's Court before the Common Sergeant and a jury, the case of Nicholson against Kift was decided It was an action brought by Police Constable John Nicholson, No. 251 city police, against Mr. Arthur Kift, landlord of the Hope Tavern, Ivylane, Paternoster-row, E.C.,...

It will be good news to the admirers of honest racing to know that the American Jockey Club has seriously discussed the question of eliminating steeplechases from its programmes after the present racing season. A good steeplechase is worth seeing now and then, ...
BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 10.--Crop reports from trustworthy correspondents, principally farmers, in every town in Genesee County are printed in the Batavia News to-day.
COLUMBUS, O., Sept. 10.--The Republican Central Committee last right placed on the State ticket Thaddeus A. Minsball, of Chillicothe, for Supreme Judge, vice McIlvaine declined.

There was a meeting of the Trustees of the Actors' Fund yesterday at the office in Union-square, at which were present Messrs. Palmer, Poole, Colville, Henderson, Aronson, and Knowles, constituting a quorum. Mr. Poole, as Chairman of the Executive Committee,...

The lot of a Tammany politician is not at present a happy one. Tammany is an organization managed on the simple principle of enabling its leaders to eat the largest possible share of the city, State, and national taxes, by reason of their control over the masses of the faction.

Battery H. of the Fifth United States Artillery, which has been on duty at Riverside Park guarding the tomb of Gen. Grant during the past 30 days, was relieved at noon yesterday by Battery K, of the same regiment, ...

Moses Froehlich was a manufacturer of glass signs, and had a shop in the sky parlor of the building at No. 173 Canal-street. Three years ago his wife left him, and since then he has often talked of suicide. To add to his troubles business has been bad lately.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10.--The weather to-day was fine and warm, the track very much improved, and the attendance very good. The following races were run:

LONDON, Sept. 10.--The health of Lord Randolph Churchill, Secretary of State for India, has given way under the severe strain of his official duties and the part he has taken in the Parliamentary campaign. All of his lordship's political engagements have been canceled ...

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 10.--A boy who went swimming in the outlet this afternoon was chilled and as he was sinking called to a companion, who hastened to the water to help him, and both were drowned. The boys were named George Mix and George Mahon. They lived in Landon, Penn., and were attending school here.

Sons of great men seem to remind us in these days chiefly that they cannot climb to fame upon their fathers' greatness. It is a somewhat curious fact that outside of a few families, such as that of Adams, there is a sort of hereditary bar to public succession.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--The September cotton report of the Department of Agriculture shows the prevalence of hot and day weather during August, except in Louisiana, Mississippi, and Florida. Shedding of bolls and decrease of vitality have resulted quite generally.

Dr. James B. Taylor, chief of the Second Sanitary Division, was perusing a newspaper bulletin board in Boston on Wednesday, when he was startled by the announcement, "Epidemic of Typhoid Fever in New-York !" Dr. Taylor's ...
CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 10.--The easterly gale which swept the lake Tuesday and yesterday was more severe and greater in area than any other gale of the season.

EL PASO, Texas, Sept. 10.--Lieut. Davis, of the United States Army, in command of a large band of Indian scouts who have been in active pursuit of Geronimo and his band, says that he believes Geronimo is endeavoring to reach the Mescaleros Reservation in New-Mexico,...
The Jacob Brothers manufacture pianos on the upper floors of No. 1,329 Broadway. Their salesroom and office are on the second floor.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 10.--St. Louis, 8; Baltimore, 3. Base hits--St. Louis, 3; Baltimore, 5. Errors--St. Louis, 3; Baltimore, 5. Pitchers-- Foutz and Henry.

Mme. Janish, dressed in black, the coscume sparkling with beads, and a black hat, ornamented with yellow ribbons, on her head, was the central figure in the court room of Superior Court, Chambers, yesterday.

The light, drizzling rain which began falling at noon yesterday caused much discomfort to the occupants of the grand stand at the Sheepshead Bay track and doubtless prevented many people from making the journey to the course, as the crowd was much smaller than usual.
NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 10.--The annual report of the National Cotton Exchange shows the cotton movement of the United States for the year ending Aug. 31 to be as follows:
A singular lawsuit has just been brought to a conclusion is Lippe-Detmold after nearly 30 years of litigation.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 10.--Three persons died from smallpox at St. Jean Baptiste village yesterday and one at St. Henri. There are 65 patients in the hospital, of whom 55 are progressing favorably. There are 13 cases of smallpox in one house in this city.

The ceremonies at the unveiling yesterday of the statue Of OLIVER HAZARD PERRY, erected at Newport, may perhaps be accepted as a token that the fame of one of the greatest of our earlier sailors has not been eclipsed by the exploits of his renowned successors.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 10.--A young man named Thomas Sweeney, living in a suburb of Scranton, known as Carr's Patch, was arraigned before Mayor Beamish to-day for highway robbery, Edgar Webster, of this city, was the prosecutor.

HAVANA, Sept. 10.--The Spanish Government expresses its thanks to the Casino Espanol, of this city, for the offer of $500,000 toward purchasing new men-of-war, and begs that the money be expended on works of defense at Havana.

BREDA, Iowa, Sept. 10.--Cholera has broken out among the hogs here, and serious damage has already resulted. It is reported that some farmers have lost from 25 to 160 head. Nearly 2,000 dead hogs have been reported.
The Commissioners of Accounts yesterday sent to Mayor Grace a report of the result of their investigation of Corporation Attorney Boyd's office.

A quiet funeral left Undertaker Slevin's establishment, at No. 25 Spring-street, yesterday and wended its way to Evergreens Cemetery. The funeral consisted of one carriage and a hearse, and its expenses were paid by the Actors' Fund.

PARIS, Aug. 25.--This coming Fall season threatens to be more than ever foreboding in its stagnation and dull business prospects. There is absolutely nothing doing. The depression is not by any means confined to those of luxurious trades.

ALBANY, Sept. 10.--The Albany Journal corrects Clerk Vrooman's table of delegates to the Republican Convention. He allows Ontario County only six delegates, although stating that it cast 6,382 Blaine votes, which entitles it to seven, as Herkimer County casting 6,138 votes.

There can be no doubt as to the great progress and popularity of the camera. The other day we mentioned that Lulu, the famous gymnast, had returned from the Kalahari with dry plates by the hundreds, which he is now developing.

A new explosive, known as hellhoffite, which has been invented by Hellhoff and Gruson, has been subjected to comparative trials at St. Petersburg, together with nitro-glycerine and ordinary gunpowder. It is a solution of a nitrated organic combination (naphthaline, phenol, benzine, ,) in fuming nitric acid.
A little front room on the first floor of an apartment, house at No. 13 Eldridge-street has been used as an office for nearly two years by Dr. Frederick W. Rothenhausler.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--The open rate on gain and provisions to New-York to-day was 10 cents, to Philadelphia 8 cents, and to Baltimore 7 cents.
It is reported that a large shell heap has been discovered at Falmouth Foreside, on land owned by the Underwood Water Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10.--At the Central Station this morning Jacob K. Walker, Joseph Calhoun, Frank Gill, George Howgate, Gustav Wild, Alfred Hayden, and Mary Ross, charged with interfering with the operatives of the Pennsylvania woolen mills where a strike is in progress, were given a hearing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--There is an impression about the State Department that the Spanish mission will be taken up and passed upon by the President early in the coming week. Minister Foster is expected to return about Oct. 1. When last heard from he was in Switzerland. It is expected that Secretary Bayard will recommend ex-Gov. Reynolds, of Missouri, as Mr. Foster's successor.

The convention of the Irish Catholic Benevolent Union met again yesterday morning at No. 373 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, and the report condemning Austria's action in refusing to accept Minister Keiley came up for discussion. Father Barry, who the day before had wished to have Italy incorporated in the condemnatory ...

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 10.--The lint glass workers of the seven idle factories opposite this city met in convention in Bellaire yesterday and accepted the terms of comproraise previously drawn up by a committee of manufacturers and workingmen, with the exception of one slight amendment, in which the manufacturers will concur.

READING, Penn., Sept. 10.--The Boston dispatch telegraphed throughout the country, stating that the proposed fight between Sullivan and Ryan on the 26th inst, would not take place on account of a 20 weeks' engagement which Sullivan had with a minstrel troupe,...

A man named Rupp was carried beyond his depth by the undertow while bathing in the surf at Far Rockaway last Wednesday. M.J. Mulqueen, a lawyer of this city, and Richard Moriarty rescued the drowning man. A nice lifeboat which was lying on the shore was unavailable because there was no crew at hand to man it.

TROY, Sept. 10.--The Democrats of the Second District in conveution to-day elected the following delegates to the State Convention: J. Russell Parsons. John E. Gaitley, and Calvert Dunham. They were instructed to support David B. Hill for Governor. Resolutions commending his administration were unanimously adopted.
It is asserted by creditors of Kossuth Marx Co. that the assignment of that firm was made for the purpose of defrauding their creditors and not benefiting them.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 10.--The Society of the Army of the Tennessee held an adjourned meeting this forenoon, Gen. Sherman presiding. The committee appointed recommended that the next meeting be held at Rock Island, Ill., from Sept. 15 to 18, 1886, which was concurred in, ...

BUFFALO, Sept. 10.--The Third Assembly District Republican Convention to-day elected the following delegates to the Saratoga Republican Convention: Seventh Ward--Alfred Lyth and Leonard Hauenstein; Ninth Ward--William...

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 10.--The first trouble under the Bonded Extension bill passed by the last Congress for the relief of distillers has arisen in the seizure of the thousand barrels of whisky belonging to John B. Thompson, of Harrodsburg.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Sept. 10.--Milton Pearson, of New-West Alexander, was thrown frown the horse he was riding this morning and instantly killed.

First Controller DURHAM, of the Treasury Department, decided about two weeks ago that twenty-four persons had been employed by the Court of Commissioners of Alabama Claims without warrant of law, and that no payments could legally be made from the Treasury on their account in the future.

Tax Receiver Charles S. De Mett, of the Town of Hempstead, died in that village Sunday last. He was 45 years of ago, and was just completing the sixth year of service in the office to which he had been twice elected.

After losing three out of four games, the Giants recovered their equilibrium yesterday and administered a severe thrashing to the champion from Providence. Shaw the left-handed "wonder," undertook to keep down the base hit column of the local players, but he was unsuccessful in his efforts.
MADRID, Sept. 10.--The cholera epidemic is sensibly decreasing in Aragon and Navarre.
The latest novelty in advertising comes from our good friends the Italians. Like many another happy thought, it is so simple that the only wonder is why it was never thought of before.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--The election in Ohio, which takes place next month, occasions much discussion in the departments as to the advisability of the clerks belonging to that State going home to vote.
TUCSON, Arizona, Sept. 10.--Advices from Oposura, Sonora, state that on the 30th ult., while Mexican regulars were following up the trail of the Apaches,...
SANTIAGO DE CHILI, via Galveston, Sept. 10.--A committee of Liberals from the upper and lower Houses met on Tuesday night and named Senor Marcial Gonzales for President.
ROCHESTER, Sept. 10.--The wells in Warsaw Valley and at Piffard, in the Genesee Valley, have already attained a reputation throughout the country for the fine quality of their salt products, ...

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 10.--The developments that are being continually made regarding the fraudulent issue of township orders by various Trustees throughout the State show that the swindle has been very generally operated and enormous quantities of the bogus obligations disposed of. There are over 1,500 townships in Indiana,....

President Cleveland does not believe in using railroad passes. When he was first elected Governor of New-York Mr. D.H. Fonda, of the Mount McGregor Railroad, made out the first pass ever given upon that road in the name of Grover Cleveland.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--The establishment of the Sterling Furniture Company, which is owned by Thomas W. Sterling, in West Madisonstreet, was to-day closed by the Sheriff to satisfy five confessions of judgment aggregating $3,432.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--The works of the North western Horse Nail Company at Brighton Park, which shut down some months ago owing to the depressed condition of the market, will start up again in a few days.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--Rensselaer Stone, whom the President to-day appointed Collector of Internal Revenue for the Chicago District, was born in Oneida County, N.Y., and is 55 years old.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 10.--The Republican Executive Committee of Mississippi met in this city to-day, the Hon. John R. Lynch, Chairman. Eighteen of the 27 members were present.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 10.--The river coal miners' strike is spreading, and in a few days the miners expect every mine on the river to be closed. The strikers succeeded in closing all but three mines in the fourth pool to-day.

CANTON, Miss., Sept. 10--A horrible murder was committed last night at a colored church 10 miles cast of this city. Leon Cockreil, a negro school teacher, shot Aaron Warz, a colored deacon, while the latter was kneeling with the congregation at prayer.
OTTAWA, Sept. 10.--Although the date fixed for Riel's execution is only eight days off, there are few who believe that he will die on the gallows.

BERLIN, Sept. 10.--It is semi-officially announced that Spain has not yet replied to Germany's suggestion to refer the Carolines question tion to a friendly nowor for arbitration. Nor has Spain replied to Germany's demand for reparation for the insult to the German Embassy at Madrid on Saturday last.
A delegation of Irving Hall Democrats called on Collector Hedden yesterday and told him in a plain, straightforward way just what they would like to have in the matter of patronage.
CHAMBERSBURG, Penn., Sept. 10.--Mr. Thomas P. Roberts, who was Chief Engineer of the construction of the Baltimore and Cumberland Valley Railroad, ...
Modesty, it is well known, is not the note of M. Coquelin's character, and his ambition has subjected him to a good deal of badinage among his countrymen.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Sept. 10.--Gen. N. A. Miles has returned from an extended trip through Indian Territory. He states that the cattle of the Arapahoe and Cheyenne Cattle Company and others will be out of the Territory within a month from this date.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10, 1885. An informal meeting of the Cabinet was held at the White House at 11 o'clock to-day. Those present were Secretaries Bayard, Lamar, and Manning.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 10.--An unmistakable case of smallpox was discovered here to-day, and there is much excitement in consequence.

ROCK SPRINGS, Wyoming, Sept. 10.--Seven hundred Chinamen have returned here under the escort of four companies of troops. The miners, it is alleged, threaten to destroy the company's buildings, ad of which are under strong guard. Serious trouble is feared as soon as the miners think they have an opportunity to carry out their threat.
COLUMBUS, Sept. 10.--Gov. Hoadly has issued a proclamation in regard to the cyclone, at Washington Court House.

A strong odor of escaping was pervaded the corridor on the fifth floor of the Pierrepont House, Brooklyn, soon after 10 o'clock yesterday morning, and was found to come from a room which for two days had been occupied by Joseph C. Fisher, of New-Brunswick,....
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 10.--The sale of tickets for the annual music festival of the Worcester County Musical Association began to-day.

NEWARK, Sept. 10.--Pauline Spohler, aged 23 years, lies at St. Barnabas's Hospital suffering from injuries inflicted by a saloon keeper named Joseph Schmidle, of No. 221 River-street, who attempted to assault her this afternoon.

The hilarity of the patrons of Mrs. Schwertferger's saloon in Woodhaven, Long Island, was checked very suddenly at a late hour on Wednesday evening by the oppearance in the doorway of her husband, Frederick, who had not been seen in Woodhaven for six months.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--Railroad men here interested in the lines in the Northwestern Traffic Association are greatly exasperated at the action of the Manitoba Company in cutting loose from its connecting roads in the association and forming an alliance with the Canadian Pacific.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 10.--John B. Owen, a conductor on the Northwestern Railroad, walking homeward last night after leaving his train, stepped aside to allow a man to pass. Instantly a cup of vitriol was dashed into Owen's face, destroying the sight of his right eye and otherwise burning him horribly.

ALBANY, Sept. 10.--The Hon. James W. Wadsworth, who is President of the State Agricultural Society, is here in connection with the State Fair, which opened to-day. If the weather is favorable the exhibition will undoubtedly be highly successful, as there is a fine display in all the departments.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 10.--Assemblyman E.J. Seeber, from the Second District of this county, has not until very lately made it known that he was a candidate for renomination.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 10.--The last Legislature passed a law providing for the taxation of dogs in the State on their par value. The returns to the Board of Equalization show a dog population of 59,996 in the State, whose total value is placed at $197,375.

The fifth annual regatta of the Staten Island Athletic Club was held yesterday on the Kill von Kull, opposite the boathouse, at NewBrighton. There were many ladies present, and after the races the annual reception of the club took place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--The annual Potomac River regatta took place this afternoon. The weather was cloudy, and a slight breeze from the west slightly ruffled the water at the opening, increasing in force toward the close so as to make the river a little lumpy. All the races were a mile and a half straightaway.
The story that the Queen has concerned herself in this matter is utterly untrue, for no communications have passed between her Majesty and the Duke of Cumberland for more than five years.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 10.--The Prohibitory State Convention held in Worcester today was well attended, and the interest shown indicates a respectable vote on election day.

KANSAS, CITY, Mo., Sept. 10.--As the Chicago passenger train of the Hannibal and St. Joseph Road was about to start from the yards this evening, to pull up to the Union Station, an attachment was levied upon it on account of taxes due to the State and county by the company to the amount of $30,000.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 10.--The oil trade was kept in a feverish state of excitement to-day by reports from two very important wells, both threatening to open up new territory of an indefinite extent.

The following dedication has been written by Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes for a goodsized volume of selections from his poetical works, which is soon to be issued by the Howe Memorial Press of the Perkins institution and Massachusetts School for the Blind, in Boston:

A meeting of the Brooklyn Citizens' League was held last night in the assembly room in the Brooklyn Academp of Music, and these officers were elected: President--Alexander E. Orr; Vice-Presidents--H.E. Deming, George H. Fisher, Thomas H. Rodman, and John McGuire;

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 10.--Charles S. Leete, President of the New-Haven Mechanics' Bank, was to-night elected President of the Security Insurance Company, of this city, vice Charles Peterson, deceased. Mr. Leete is one of the largest wholesale druggists in the State, and for some years has been Vice-President of the Security Insurance Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--The President has issued the following proclamation:

LIMA, Ohio, Sept. 10.--On Tuesday night an attempt was made to blow up with dynamite the hotel, saloon, and residence of Neal Bidwell, in the village of Westminster, not far from this place. The saloon had recently been opened, and its presence was hotly opposed by some of the inhabitants.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 10.--Twelve firms of distillers of this city sent out a circular to-day announcing that they will hereafter make a basing price instead of selling their goods upon a highwine basis.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 10.--For more than a week the United States man-of-war Swatara has been lying tied up to the bank of the river at the head of Mandeville-street receiving on board a cargo of surplus silver dollars to be transferred to the Treasury vaults at Washington.
HAVERHILL, Mass., Sept. 10.--The reunion of the classmates of the poet Whittier in the old Haverhill Academy held here to-day was one of the pleasantest occasions.
About the 28th of July, 1885, the seizing officers of the Custom House seized the stock of one J. Emrich, at No. 66 Nassau-street, and took the same away.

A statement made by the Rev. Dr. Richard Newton at the funeral of the Rev. Dr. Tyng, in New-York on Tuesday, has given rise to considerable displeasure among Catholics in this city on account of its incorrectness. Dr. Newton is reported to have said:

BUFFALO, Sept. 10.--The Bar of Erie County held a largely attended meeting to-day to take appropriate action on the death of one of its members, the Hon. George W. Clinton. Such an assemblage of leading lawyers of this part of the State has seldom been seen.

The two vacancies upon the Forestry Commission should be filled without delay. Mr. THEODORE BASSELIN, who has appeared at Albany as an opponent of legislation for the preservation of the Adirondack forests, is now the only one of the three Commissioners appointed by Gov. HILL who has accepted the office.

The new Bishop of Salisbury will be quite the youngest Bishop on the bench. He is in every sense of the word a Harrow boy, having been born at "the town on the hill" when his father, the late Bishop of Lincoln, was head master at the famous school there.

CORNING, N.Y., Sept. 10.--About 10 o'clock this morning many people near the Erie Railway station at Cameron, a small hamlet about 25 miles west of this place, were startled by a rumbling sound, as if an earthquake was about to take place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--Inquiry at the office of the Commissioner of Railroads shows that no reports regarding the floating debt of the Union Pacific Railroad Company have been received since December last.

MONTREAL, Sept. 11.--The little difficulty between the English and French papers, which at one time threatened serious consequences, bids fair to be settled at last. The Mayor publishes an apology for the article which appeared in La Patrie, and the editor of the Herald has sent an apology to the French press. Bishop Fabre, whose paper was the most bloodthirsty of the lot, has not deemed it necessary to retract anything.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11.--John L. Sullivan arrived here this afternoon direct from Boston. He was accompanied by Tom Delay, his trainer, and Tom Costello, a local sport and gambler. MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 11.--One of the leading lumbermen in the city said this afteernoon that the growing scarcity of long timber is manifest everywhere. There is none in stock and no logs to make it out of, except at the railway mills, where hauliug can be done.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 11--The feature of the last day's races of the New-Haven Driving Association was Phil Thompson's effort to beat 2:23 for a special purse. Smith, editor of the Syracuse Journal, was a candidate for Secretary of State on the Republican ticket, and it is understood here that he has been assured by some of the party leaders that he could be nominated, To-night Mr. Smith said that he had absolutely no political aspirations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11.--Inspector-General Nelson 13. Davis will be placed on the retired list Sept. 20. His successor, it is understood, will be either Gen. Roger Jones or Gen. A. Baird. Another attempt by the yachts Puritan and Genesta to sail the first of the races for the America's cup came to naught yesterday. ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 11.--M.C. Rockwell, he ex-banker, of Union, N.Y., and his clerk, D.J. Palmer, were arrested at 10 o'clock this morning, charged with larceny in the first degree in misappropriating $50,000. The complaint is made by Mrs. Livingston, a depositor.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 11.--Bishop Henry C. Lay, of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Easton, is at the Church Home on Broadway, this city, dangerously ill, and but little hope is entertained for his living more than a few days, and he may possibly not live that long. BUFFALO, Sept. 12.--The Wallula arrived from Duluth this morning with 19,140 barrels of flour on board. This is the largest consignment that has been received here in many years. It is being loaded for New-York and will fill 160 cars. The flour is from Minneapolis mills, and is destined for England.

Only a few, less than a baker's dozen of the cottagers, have closed their houses. As usual most of the cottagers will remain until the latter part of October.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12.--.Emory A. Storrs, the well known lawyer, orator, and Republican politician, of this city, was found dead in his bed at the Clifton House in Ottawa, Ill., this morning. He had been ailing for several days, but no serious result was anticipated, and his death created a marked impression throughout Chicago.

A three-story building is now approaching completion on the grounds of the Central Tennessee College that will add a new department to that popular institution. NEVADA, Mo., Sept. 13.--A locomotive and caboose on the Lexington and Southern branch of the Missouri Pacific Railroad went through a bridge into the Little Osage River, near Pleasant Hill, to-day, and Engineer Frederick Karl and Fireman P. McHaney were drowned.

The Supply of peaches from the Delaware Peninsula last week was much less than arrived from there during the previous week. This falling off was caused by the abundance of New-Jersey peaches, which so depressed the prices that the Peninsula growers sent their peaches to other markets or sold to buyers from other markets, who are now on the Peninsula and have been there all the season.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13.--A crowd of boys who loiter around Eighteenth and Naudain streets received a serious check in their pranks this afternoon. John Ward, 15 years old, living at No. 1,721 Carver-street, was shot in the face at 3:30 o'clock by John Anderson, who lives in Donnelly's Court, in the rear of No. 1,813 Southstreet.

SACRAMENTO, Cal. Sept. 13.--In the 4year-old trot here yesterday Joseph Cairn Simpson's Antevolo trotted a mile in 2:19 . This beats the four-year-old stallion record by two and a half seconds. The horse has never worn anything but tips, having never been shod.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13.--Five young toughs returning from a dance early this morning stopped at Michael Rossa's fruit stand at Nineteenth and Halsted streets, and walked off with two bananas each, Rossa yelled for help to recover his stolen fruit, and the young fellows returned for more.

MILES CITY, Montana, Sept. 13.--A stage robbery is reported from near Forty Mile Ranch on Friday night. Three masked men stopped the stage and secured the Wells-Fargo treasure box containing $600, en route from Fort Custer to Fort Mckinney. Twelve thousand dollars of Goverment money for the troops had been sent through only a day or two before.

LEWISTON, Idaho, Sept. 13.--D.M. Frazer, for 12 years Auditor of Shoshone County, has been found murdered in his lodgings in the rear of his store at Pierce City. His body had been hacked to pieces.

BLAKELY, Ga., Sept. 13.--Samuel Strong shot Albert Bacon yesterday. The ball took a curious course. It entered the right side of the neck under the jawbone, cut off a small piece of the tongue, ranged over to the left jaw, knocked out a tooth, and loosened several others, and finally came out of his mouth. The wound is fatal.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Sept. 13.--Boating on the Delaware and Fludson Canal as very slack at present owing to the depression in the anthracite coal trade. Cooney is a strict Catholic, and for 30 years has been President of the St. Vincent de Paul Society.
GUAYMAS, Sept. 13, via Galveston.--Seventeen deaths from yellow fever have so far occurred here--12 soldiers, 3 natives, and 2 Americans. The names of the latter are unknown.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 13.--A public meeting of Western Union operators was held here to-day to take action on the subject of extra work demanded without extra pay. A committee of live was appointed to wait on the Superintendent immediately and ask for the restoration of extra compensation. The Superintendent will be given until Sept. 15 to answer. In the event of a refusal, it is believed that serious trouble will ensue.

RIMOUSKI, Quebec, Sept.13.--The steamer Sardinian has passed inward. Among her passengers is Archdeacon Farrar, the eminent English divine.

William Spelman, whose further right to the pulpit he has occupied for over 30 years is awaiting, judicial decision. INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 13.--The train records show that last week there were 492 fewer loaded cars handled at this point than during the previous week.

ALBANY, Sept. 13.--The Assistant Secretary and Dr. F. Curtis, of the State Board of Health, visited Troy to-day to investigate the facts concerning the alleged cases of varioloid at that place. There is every reason to believe that the eruptions are those of chicken pock, and no evidence whatever that the cases passed through Albany. Dr. Curtis will personally examine the patients to-morrow and set the disputed diagnosis at rest.

A druggist of East Washington has inaugurated a system of advertising that is proving as popular among the small boys as it is novel. Some two weeks ago a small boy entered the store with about a yard of peach kernels strung on a thread and offered them for sale.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13.--The cornerstone of St. Gregory's Roman Catholic Church, in the northwestern section of the city, was laid this afternoon in the presence of fully 10,000 persons. LONDON, Sept. 14.--The Standard publishes the Anglo-Russian protocol concerning the Afghan frontier. Every detail in connection with the frontier line has been settled. The only possible point of difference is the Oxus, which the English have been unable to survey minutely. Zelenoi, the head of the original Russian Frontier Commission, has been deposed.

Mr. JOHN L. SULLIVAN, of Boston, the most eminent slugger of the age, has announced his intention to retire from the prize ring and become a gentleman. So notable a decision upon the part of a man so much before the public cannot fail to be of general interest, but the announcement is calculated to awaken very different feelings among various elements of society.

PIERRE, Dakota, Sept. 15.--All is quiet on Winnebago and Crow Creek Reservations. The recent order sent to Agent Gasman to eject settlers refusing to leave will not be enforced. The settlers are quietly submitting to the order, and leaving of their own accord. Few, if any, remain, but it is the determination of all having taken claims there to return as soon as the final opening takes place.

WINNIPEG, Sept. 15.--Lord Lansdowne Governor-General of Canada, will arrive here to-morrow morning. He is making a tour on the Northwest. He will go through the Rocky Mountains to British Columbia, thence to Portland, Oregon, or San Francisco, and home through the States. He will receive a big reception here.

HONESDALE, Penn., Sept. 15.--Never in the history of this part of Pennsylvania has fruit of all kinds been so abundant as it is this year. Loudon Snowden, late Superintendent of the Mint in this city, who was visited at his country seat, Fairlawn, near Haverford, by a Philadelphia Times reporter, said: "I have just returned from a visit to my sick mother in the Cumberland Valley, and have only glanced through the article printed in Sunday's Times. MONTREAL, Sept. 1.--There were 35 deaths in the city yesterday, but it is impossible to furnish any figures about the authenticated cases of smailpox, as the Health Depertment now refuse to furnish any statistics. There are over 1,000 cases in the city.

WAVERLY, N.J., Sept. 17.--This was Governor's Day at the State Fair in progress at this place. Between 40,000 and 45,000 people are estimated to have passed the gates of the fair grounds to-day.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 17.--In the District Court to-day John A. Phillips had a preliminary hearing on the charge of incest with his daughter, 10 years old. He was ordered to give $3,000 bail for appearance in Superior court. He was released last February from prison, where he had served a sentence for incest with another daughter.

NEWBURG, Sept. 17.--Miss Florence R. Vernol, whose mysterious disagnearance from her home at Wallkill, Ulster County, was reported recently, was found at Port Jervis on Tuesday evening at the residence of Mrs. Stevens, a widow living in Germantown, where she has been boarding since her arrival in town.

PARIS, Sept.17.--Twenty cases of cholera have been reported in Paris during the past three days. The sanitary officials claim that the disease is sporadic and not Asiatic cholera, and that the hot weather prevailing has made the cases more severe than is general at this time of the year.
BERLIN, Sept. 17.--It is reported that Prince Bismarck has informed the Bundesrath that he has no fears that the differences with Spain will result in hostilities.

Akeley, taxidermists, arrived this morning and removed Jumbo's hide in three pieces. The hide will be cured here and then shipped to Rochester to be mounted. A funeral pyre was built with four cords of wood, and the flesh taken from Jumbo's bones slowly burned up.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 17.--The pleuropneumonia fund to kill all exposed cattle has failed, and the cattlemen, who met here today, will only try to quarantine the exposed cattle in Harrison. Pendleton County has the disease, but the only lot of cattle yet affected is kept in one inclosure. Several instances are roported of transactions in exposed cattle at various points. Remedial measures are looked forward to from the Legislature, which meets in December.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 17.--The conviction of Bank President Adam Brabender for cheating and defrauding the depositors of the County Bank was secured to-night, and he was remanded for sentence to-morrow morning. He will probably be sentenced to five years, and another Sunday school Superintendent will have to be elected.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 17.--This was the second and last day of the reunion of the Army of the Cumberland. Upward of 40 posts of the Grand Army of the Republic, a dozen camps of Sons of Veterans, several companies of militia, and visitors from every State in the Union are present.

Donovan, Superintendent of Carriers in the Chicago Post Office, as President of the organization, but the constitution and other minor matters provoked a good deal of squabbling and confusion.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 17.--From private telegrams received here, it is learned that Brainerd, the Vermont bank defaulter, is at Hamilton, resting at the Queen's Flotel, and will come on here and join his wife at once. To a friend he told the story of his travels.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 18.--Ninety days after the adjournment of the State Legislature the laws enacted become binding. To-day is the ninetieth day, and among the laws now in force are the 10-hour labor law and an enactment making central standard time legal in this State. In accordance with this Michigan clocks have been turned back, and everything is done earlier in the day--by the clock.

King Monmouth came in second, and R. Craig's (formerly J.R. Keene's) 5-year-old ch.h. Blue Grass third. There were only four starters.

McLaughlin, a young man belonging on the Fishkill side of the river, and another young man named McElrath, who had been in this city last evening, started to return to the Fishkill side of the Hudson in a small boat. SANTA FE, New-Mexico, Sept. 18.--During the last 10 days the Apaches have murdered six citizens of Grant County--Ranchero Brady, of Pollock, near Elmacho: Evaristo Abeytia, a Mexican, near San Lorenzo; two sons of John McKerin, on a ranch near Gallino Creek; George Howe, a woodchopper, near Georgetown, and a Mexican sheep herder, near Lake Valley. They also destroyed Mcknight and Keith's ranch house near Lake Valley.

ALBANY, Sept. 18.--"Hill and Carr are to be the candidates," was the opinion expressed here to-day by several politicians of both parties, who had been asked for their beliefs as to what the Republican and Democratic Conven-- tions would do next week.
BURLINGTON, Iowa, Sept. 18.--The balloon which descended at Monmouth, Ill., yesterday and created such a sensation was one in which Prof. Williams was to make an ascent from the Fair Grounds.
Patrick Cavanagh, foreman of bricklayers on the new Puck Building, at Mulberry and Houston streets, was discharged a few days ago for drunkenness.

JERSEYVILLE, Ill., Sept. 18.--George Egelhoff, proprietor of the carriage manufactory here, made an assignment yesterday. His assets are scheduled at $25,885 and the liabilities at $16,346. Henry Nevins, of this city, is the assignee.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18.--Charles Hall, of Cheshire, want to Hitchcock's pond, in the town of Wolcott, to fish to-day. He stood on the shore and used a number of lines. One of them was taken by a fish and dragged off. Hall sprang into the water to catch it, missed his foothold, and was drowned. He was 54 years of age.
The Fall term of the university opened this week. There have been changes by which the Faculty has been strengthened.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 18.--William Agnew, of Hampton, who was struck by a train on the West Shore Road here yesterday, died today from the effects of his injures.
It is reported from Rock Springs, Wyoming, that "an amicable adjustment between the company" (the Union Pacific Railroad Company) "and the Knights of Labor is expected immediately."

MARSEILLES, Sept. 18.--Seven deaths from cholera occurred here to-day. Considerable excitement has been caused by the arrival of a transport bringing French troops from Tonquin. Fourteen of the soldiers had died from cholera on the voyage and two more have died since the arrival of the vessel here. Many others are down with the disease.
The Summer Home of the Children's Aid Society at Bath, Long Island, for well children, and the Health Home for sick children on Coney Island are now closed for the season.

The British brig Georgia, of Nassau, which arrived yesterday from Aspinwall, by way of Old Providence, was detained at Lower Quarantine. Four of the crew were suffering from either yellow or Chagres fever, and were at once removed to the hospital.

HUNTINGDON, Sept. 18.--Sheriff McAlvy sold at Sheriff's sale to-day the large car and car wheel works recently owned and conducted by the Blaine Brothers, who made an assignment in favor of the Union Bank, of this place, in September, 1883. William Dorris, in behalf of the bondholders of the works, bid in the property at the low figure of $7,000. The works are worth from $75,000 to $100,000.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 18.--The case of the Rev. Charles B. Smyth against the Presbytery of New-York was decided by the Presbyterian Synod in session here yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. B.M. Mallon opened last Spring a liquor store at No. 261 West Twenty-seventh-street. The place consisted of a roomy saloon over which was a dwelling of two stories with an extension in the rear, where the stock was kept. Over the extension was the carpentering loft of Isaac Terrell.

ALBANY, Sept. 18.--Gov. Hill to-day issued a proclamation designating the Hon. William Rumsey a Justice of the Supreme Court, to hold Circuit Court and Oyer and Terminer, for the Sixth Judicial District, in the village of Norwich, on Sept. 21.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 18.--Connecticut's farmers are troubled just now by having too much of a good thing on their hands. This is a condition of affairs that doesn't often happen with the tillers of the soil in the Nutmeg State. Usually the trouble is that there is too little.
ERIE, Penn., Sept. 18.--President Adam Brabender, of the Erie County Savings Bank, convicted yesterday of fraud and conspiracy, was sentenced this morning to two years in the penitentiary.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 18.--Orange County's big agricultural fair closed at this city this afternoon with a very large attendance for the closing day. Nearly 60,000 persons visited the fair during the four days on which it was held, which number is at least 20,000 more than ever before attended a fair in this county.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 18.--In June and July last the Fire Department was called out almost every night by an incendiary fire. This culminated on Sunday, July 26, in the arrest of Charles H. Weiderhold, who very early that morning had been detected firing a barn.

Sickness or nausea. is most commonly relieved by vomiting. A horse is unable to vomit, because its diaphragm is not a complete partition in the abdomen, perforated only by the gullet, and against which the stomach can be compressed by the abdominal muscles, as is the case in man. Hence its nausea is not at once removable, and is more notable and enduring.--Notes and Queries.

DICKINSON, Dakota, Sept. 20.--Prairie fires have been raging all day. Miles of country have been burned over, and losses of grain and hay, in stacks, and several buildings are reported. It is impossible to estimate the damage, but it will amount to several thousand dollars. The fire is supposed to have been started south of here by Indians.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 20.--The record of the Minneapolis milling year, which closed on Sept. 1, has just been compiled, and will be made public to-morrow. The totals show a large increase over the preceding year's business.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 21.--The friends of Mrs. Catharine Smith, of Boston, have come to the conclusion that she drowned herself from the Fall River boat which left New-York bound East on Thursday night. CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Sept. 21.--Work was resumed at the Rock Springs coal mines this forenoon. All the Chinamen went to work, and also all the white mechanics, engineers, black smiths, firemen, and carpenters employed in the mine. The white coal miners who declined to work were paid off. Everything is quiet and no more trouble is anticipated, as the military force is ready to protect the workmen.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 21.--The Rev. C. W. Camp, for the past 10 years Rector of St. John's Church here, has tendered his resignation, to take effect Oct. 2, having accepted a call to Grace Episcopal Church, in Lockport, this State. Mr. Camp was for several years Grand Chaplain of the State Grand Lodge of Masons.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Sept, 21.--Ellis Cole, of Philadelphia, who was honorably discharged a week ago from the United States Army at Fort Yeatch, Dakota, was killed this afternoon on the Pennsylvania Railroad, near Spruce Creek, seven miles from here.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 21.--To-day Edgar Stark, Cashier of the Cincinnati National Bank, came to this city bearing with him the three warrants, aggregating $3,500, which are held as collateral for a loan to the Vernon Bank, purporting...

LONDON, Sept. 21.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its review of the British grain trade during the past week says: "Broken weather with occasional rains during the week have tended to delay the harvest. The sales of English wheat during the week were 70,441...

Paul Bauer was convicted of pool selling at Coney Island last March and was sentenced in the Kings County Court of Sessions to three months' imprisonment in the penitentiary and to pay a fine of $750.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21.--The rumors which were in circulation some weeks ago to the effect that serious blunders or frauds had been discovered in the measurements of several of the contracts on the section north of Lake Superior, on the Canadian Pacific Railway, are to-day confirmed.

ALBANY, Sept. 21.--Gov. Hill to-day pardoned Nelson Bryan, of Kings, sentenced to nine months' imprisonment in the Kings County penitentiary May 13, 1885, for receiving stolen goods, and Timothy Driscoll, of Albany, who had served nearly one year of his three years' sentence for grand larceny in the second degree. Six petitions were denied.

But two prestidigitators of note have stood before the public within the memory of the present generation. One was the elder Herrmann, whose command of legerdemain, in the exact sense of the word, was simply matchless, and the other was Mr. Robert Heller, whose ingenious performances derived special value from the running accompaniment of wit and music that went along with them.

Members of the Grant Monument Association are very sanguine of the success of the proposed fair in aid of the national monument fund. "Madison-Square Garden," said one of them yesterday, "is just the place for an affair of the kind. It is big, centrally situated, and easy of approach, and although it is not a sightly oile, it is particularly handy in a big city like New-York."

LONDON, Sept. 21.--An enormous Socialist meeting was held yesterday at Limehouse. The crowd prevented numerous attempts of the police to arrest the speakers, but the officers finally succeeded in arresting Mr. Mahon, Secretary of the Socialist League; the steward of a German club, and six spectators.

SARATOGA, Sept. 21.--Following upon a Sunday of delightful quiet in Saratoga to-day has been one of increasing bustle and noise, of multiplying crowds, and of a somewhat less contented frame of mind among the delegates to the Republican. Convention that is to meet here to-morrow.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 21.--Albert Waller, aged 22 years, who has been a resident of this city for the past nine months, having been employed in the livery stable of a relative, was several days ago arrested by local detectives and committed to jail.

Twenty-three Italian associations celebrated the anniversary of the entry of the Italian troops into Rome yesterday. They first had a parade down South Fifth-avenue to the City Hall, where they were relieved by Mayor Grace, and then they went to Union Park, Harlem, at One Hundred and Thirty-third-street and East River. The scene there grew very animated; soldiers in red and green uniforms...

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21.--The Rev. Father James McCaffrey, of St. Patrick's Church, has created something of a sensation among his parishioners and the people of other parishes by announcing from his pulpit that the Catholic children of his church who are sent to the public schools will not be prepared for their first communion by any of the priests of the parish, nor would they be received and given instructions for the...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 21.--The attempt to start the Cleveland Rolling Mill Works this morning was a failure. Only 40 men returned to work, although it was said that 1,000 had signed a petition stating that they were willing to resume.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 21.--A serious break was expected in the whisky market today, but it did not occur. The "Big Eleven," as the combination of distillers are called, who are endeavoring to control the market, held their ground against the Mill Creek and other local companies and a shipment of 789 packages which arrived from Peoria. The prevailing price was $1.03, and the combination has agreed to hold to the same price to-morrow.

WACO, Texas, Sept. 21.--The Rev. Dr. Carroll, of this city, whose reply to Senator Richard Coke on the liquor question furnished the Prohibitionists of the State with their ablest argument, yesterday from his pulpit discussed the negro problem.
HARRISONBURG, Va., Sept. 21.--The Shenandoah Iron Company, at Milnes, in this county, has defaulted on the payment of some of its indebtedness, and a bill was filed in the Circuit...

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 21.--For some time past Francis B. O'Donnell, aged 32 years, and his brothers Edward and George, have been the proprietors of the Roxbury Gazette. Francis had been suffering from aberration of the mind.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 21.--For some time a gang of workmen has been engaged in stone ballasting the tracks of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, just below this city.

Yesterday was the fifth day of the National Rifle Association's Fall meeting at Creedmoor, and in point of interest and attendance was no exception to the preceding days. When it was announced that the "regulars" had captured the Hilton trophy by outshooting the New-York...

FERDINAND WARD, a swindler and thief who ought now to be suffering punishment for his crimes in State prison, is living comfortably in Ludlow-Street Jail, where he is held in the custody of the Sheriff under orders of arrest in civil proceedings begun by the late J. NELSON TAPPAN and by WILLIAM H. BINGHAM.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 21.--It was a walkaway for New-York to win from Buffalo to-day, the latter only getting men beyond second base twice. Keefe pitched in splendid form, striking out the side twice.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21.--The leave of absence granted First Lieut. Otto L. Hein, First Cavalry, has been extended five days. Leave of absence for four month, to take effect about Oct. 1, had been granted Capt. William C. Shannon, Assistant Surgeon.
Richard J. Morrisson, Mayor Grace's private secretary, has been designated by Corporation Counsel Lacombe to succeed Algernon S. Sullivan as Public Administrator.

Collector Hedden did not appear at his office in the Custom House until nearly 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. When asked if there was anything new in the Bacon case, he very briefly and curtly replied that there was nothing to be said.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21.--The Eureka Coal Company, with mines in Will and Grundy Counties, in this State, to-day confessed judgment of $27,709 in favor of Erie L. Hedstrom, a Buffalo coal merchant, and Charles P. Wheeler...

The steady northward growth of business and population on Manhattan Island gives importance to the report which Lieut.-Col. W. McFARLAND has made to Gen. NEWTON on the present condition and prospects of the project for connecting the Harlem with the Hudson River. Various surveys of different routes for this waterway have resulted in the selection of a cut...

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 21.--It is reported in political circles here to-day that Col. Morton, the defeated candidate for the Augusta Postmastership, will probably be appointed Division Superintendent of the New-England Railway Mail Service at an early day.

The Fall meeting of the American Jockey Club will begin Saturday at Jerome Park. The two great handicaps of the meeting are the Manhattan and the Grand National, and the weights for both were announced yesterday.

The Hon. ADONIRAM J. WARNER, of Ohio, is said to be disappointed with the reception given to his silver compromise by the Administration. Mr. WARNER is too easily cast down. He ought not so soon to expect that his compromise will be accepted, even in principle, by the Administration.

Overcoats and wraps were very desirable articles for the spectators of the races at Sheepshead Bay yesterday. It was the last day of the season, and there was a fair attendence to witness the six events. The first was a dash of seven furlongs, which Decoy Duck won from Pontiac after a brilliant finish. The 2-year-old race was won handily by Inspector B., and then another magnificent finish gladdened...
NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 21.--James Davis, alias L. Wesley Shaw, of Port Jervis, although young in years, has started out on a career of crime that already has brought him into serious trouble.

MONTREAL, Sept. 21.--The health authorities flatly refuse to give any statistics for last week as regards the deaths from smallpox, but from other sources it is learned that there were 29 on Saturday and 41 yesterday, and the total for the week cannot be less than 225, as against 128 the previous week. The Rev. Father Leclerc, P.P., of St. Joseph's Parish, reported today that there were hundreds of unreported...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21, 1885. The office of Chief of the Post Office In spectors has been tendered by the Postmaster-General to William A. West, of Mississippi. Mr. West is a prosperous farmer, living near Oxford, Miss., and has engaged successfully in mercantile pursuits in St. Louis and New-Orleans and has been President of a bank in Oxford. Mr. West was at the department today and has the tender under consideration.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 21.--Senator Sherman and Congressman McKinley addressed a large meeting in the Music Hall to-night. Tha Lincoln, Blaine, and Foraker Clubs, in their respective uniforms and about 1,500 strong, escorted the speakers to the hall. About 5,000 voters listened to the speakers throughout and frequently interrupted them by applause. The speeches were substantially the same as have been delivered...

The cool breeze which swept across New-York Bay yesterday caused a smaller attendance on the Staten Island Cricket Ground to witness the match between the visiting English team and the "All New-York" eleven than when the Englishmen played their first match on the same ground earlier in the month.
COHOES, N.Y., Sept. 21.--John Welch, a baker on Willow-street, is to-night dying from a gunshot wound inflicted by a companion named Keefe.

Mr. Florence set before the audience at Daly's Theatre last night--a numerous and appreciative audience, by the way--the old theatrical version of "Dombey Son" which John Brougham made in the year of grace 1848, and which gave fame to the theatre on Chambers-street and fortune to William E. Burton.

John J. Ford, of No. 30 City Hall-place, while in a state of inebriation yesterday afternoon, conceived a grievance against the office cat of the Sun, owing to an article that appeared in that paper on Sunday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 21.--The Trustees of Cornell University have created another Fellowship, to be named after the Hon. Erastus Brooks. This makes eight Fellowships in all that are open yearly and valued at $400 each.

Before Ferdinand Ward will consent to be cross-examined in the civil suit now pending to get back some of the enormous profits made by William S. Warner out of the swindling operations of Grant Ward, he wants to be assured that the District Attorney will not press the criminal proceedings against him next month.

The Secretary of the Treasury has called for the resignation of Martin L. Noerr as chief of the division of captured and abandoned property and lands. Mr. Noerr was appointed from the District of Columbia, and is one of the oldest employes in the service. There are no charges against him.

The lawyers who are standing between William S. Warner's money and the clutches of Grant Ward's defrauded creditors argued before Referee Cole yesterday that the real question at issue was not whether Warner had obtained money by fraud or whether he was cognizant of Ward's swindling operations and closed his eyes to them while pocketing exorbitant rates of interest on money loaned, but whether or not Warner had been exacting usury.

DETROIT, Sept. 22.--Clingstone and Harry Wilkes, the trotters who are booked for a race in this city next Saturday, arrived here last evening. Clingstone was given three mile heats this morning. John Splan, who has him in charge, sent him in the second for a nice working gait.

LYONS, N.Y., Sept. 22.--There is a great stir in this place at the reported elopement of Stephen M. Welsh, a well known railroad man, and to-day the matter has been the general topic of conversation in this vicinity.

READING, Penn., Sept. 22.--Patrick McCaffrey, a brakeman on the Pennsylvania Railroad, while standing on the caboose of the wreck train as it passed over the bridge near Spring City to-day, endeavored to catch his hat which had been blown off by a gust of wind.

SEATTLE, Washington Territory, Sept. 22. --A body of men, masked and armed, paid a visit last night to the quarters of the Chinese workmen at Black Diamond mine and burned their houses. The Chinamen fled on their approach.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 22.--The Times-Union to-morrow will publish an abstract of the State census, prepared for its trade edition to be issued in October, showing that the population of the State has increased 64,653 since 1880. The number of acres of land assessed is 17,103,182. The value of live stock is $5,537,403.

HONESDALE, Penn., Sept. 22.--There is much excitement in the western part of this (Wayne) county over the discovery of a deposit of copper ore, which promises to be one of great value according to assays that have been made of it and the calculations of mining experts who have visited the locality in which the discovery has been made.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 22.--It became known to-day that some irregularity existed in the accounts of Thomas P. Barry, General Passenger and Ticket Agent of the Cincinnati, Washington and Baltimore Railroad.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 22.--A special to the News from Eagle Pass says: "Confirmed reports have reached here of the confiscation of Las Cruces silver mines in the Carmen Mountain, Mexico, by Mexican troops upon a trumpedup claim of a Mexican Sergeant antedating the claims of Owens, Stapps, Davis, and other Americans.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 22.--An encounter occurred near Verdon, in Hanover Country, late Saturday evening, between two farmers, Riley Austin and Alonzo Hendricks.
The state of affairs in New-Hampshire over fire insurance matters is truly extraordinary.

The Great Eastern is again in pressing "difficulties," and, as we announce in another column, she is menaced by an order of the court, Mr. Justice Chitty having issued a decree that the monster ship shall be offered for sale by auction at Lloyd's next month.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 22.--The fourth annual meeting of the American Forestry Congress was opened at Horticultural Hall this morning. Mayor O'Brien spoke a few words of welcome. President Higley responded and drew attention to the importance of the movement for the restoration of the forests as touching...

The Paris correspondent of the London Times gives an account of the way in which news is manufactured in Paris. He says: "When the news is foreign and of international importance the sensational journals publish long columns, dated from all the capitals of the world and bearing the latest possible dates.

If Mr. Ruskin does not see his Notes and Queries he will be interested to know that an etymological discussion is being carried on in that learned little print as to the derivation of "the name Ruskin."

RACINE, Wis., Sept. 22.--This afternoon Capt. William Jones, of the Lifeboat Service at this place, was drowned while practicing with his crew under the direction of Superintendent Rogers. Six of the crew escaped. The disaster was caused by the upsetting of the boat by heavy breakers raised by the prevailing north-east gale.

The Popolo Romano publishes the interesting announcement that a line of steamers is about to run between Rome and Genoa, and that the two pioneer boats destined to open the Tiber once more as a highway of commerce have been built by a Newcastle firm.

The meeting of the trunk line Presidents at Commissioner Fink's office yesterday was attended with important results. All the roads were represented except the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western, but the other. Presidents did not attach any importance to Mr. Sloan's absence, as he has not, so far as known, attended any of the conferences.

The Metropolitans were "Chicagoed" by the St. Louis Browns on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Browns were in a batting mood, and they hit the ball safely nine times in six innings. Besides being hit hard Lynch was very wild, advancing a number of base runners by his poor command of the ball.
Senator James H. Berry, who had been attending court at Berryville, met with quite a serious accident last week.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22.--Miss Emily Sacbener, whose home was in New-York, and who was a member of the company now filling an engagement at the Thalia Theatre, died suddenly to-day at her lodging house of paralysis of the heart.

SARATOGA, Sept. 22.--The Democratic phalanx has received a slight reinforcement today, but the main body of delegates, with their camp followers, are not expected till to-morrow morning. Every additional arrival adds volume to the Hill boom and confirms the confidence of his friends that he will be the successful candidate for Governor.

Our esteemed contemporary the Com- mercial Advertiser has fallen into two errors, and it gives us pleasure to correct them. It assumes that the independent Republicans have been trying to create a new party. Nothing could be further from the truth.

Deacon Azel Tennant and wife, of this city, celebrated the sixtieth anniversary of their marriage last evening. The bride has just passed her eightieth birthday, while her husband is 4 years older, and the worthy couple have apparently some years of useful enjoyment before them.

There are but four stake races for 2 and 3 year olds to be run at the coming meeting of the American Jockey Club, and they are the Nursery and Jerome Stakes to be run on Saturday next and the Champagne and Hunter Stakes for fillies to be run on the following Tuesday.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Sept. 22.--In the Laporte homicide case this morning the defense continued their effort to establish the prisoner's insanity. Old Mrs. Laporte testified that her son Jack was troubled with insomnia and restlessness from his infancy, and that she was aware that something was wrong with his mind for a long while back.

Mrs. Margaret Hendricks, who was accused of having brutally ill-used little Amy Belmont, was convicted in the Middlesex County Court at New-Brunswick yesterday. She had taken the child from the Southern Home in Philadelphia for adoption.

Malingering is a subject which may well occupy the attention of all medical men holding public appointments. Though a very old form of imposition, and in some varieties become so trite as to be nearly impracticable, it still maintains itself like a hundred other practices of dishonesty, acquiring new ruses as the old become familiar.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22--During the National Democratic Convention last year Carter Harrison made the statement that the Irish never bolted the Democratic ticket. "They do" cried a man in the Dody of the building. Harrison repeated his statement, which was fiercely disputed by the man on the floor.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22.--The steamship Prussian, at this port from Glasgow, had a stormy passage. A high sea washed over the starboard side of the vessel and unshipped two companion ways, almost filling the first hold with water.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 22.--A considerable flutter has been caused by the publication of an editorial in Sunday's Evansville Courier, in which the Democratic triumvirate is told it must stand aside for other and younger leadership. The Courier editorial is by a former Secretary of State, and the article is presumed to be in the interests of Gov. Gray for United States Senator.

Dr. William L. Morse, who lives at No. 104 North Green-street, Baltimore, went to the International Hotel on Park-row Monday night. He was given room No. 14 and immediately retired. Servants rapping on the door yesterday morning gained no admission. In the afternoon the room was broken into and the doctor found unconscious.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 22.--Thomas W. Carpenter, late bookkeeper of J.L. Schoolcraft, a broker, who about two months ago absconded with $28,000 worth of bonds belonging to Mr. Mark Downey, and after an absence of two weeks returned conscience stricken and made...

Frederick W. Schroeder, a gray-haired veteran of the Union Army, was on trial in the Court of General Sessions yesterday for forgery. He was employed as a canvasser of saloons and restaurants by the Electric Time Telegraph Company, and received a commission on every written order he secured.

Agnes Kammler, a nice-looking young immigrant woman, landed at Castle Garden yesterday and asked if Mr. Helman had called for her. She explained that she had agreed by letter to marry Mr. Helman, whose advertisement...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 22.--Word has just been received here that in a fight in Letcher County, between the Jones and Wright factions, Dolph Draughn, Deputy Sheriff; Sam Cook, and William Francis were killed.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 22.--The Genesta rounded Brenton's Reef Lightship at 9:33 P.M. The wind was fresh from the north-northeast and a short chopping sea was running. She carried a mainsail, topsail, and three jibs, and reported the Dauntless as 15 miles astern.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Sept. 22.--At the colored convention which assembled at Louisville, Ky., last Summer the proposition was made to select some day to be celebrated by their race commemorative of the signing of the emancipation proclamation by President Lincoln. The committee to whom this proposition was made decided upon Sept. 22 as the day for the celebration by their people.

The delegates were slow in reassembling after the recess. As they straggled down to the convention hall they found the doors surrounded by Swinburne men wearing the portrait of the Albany doctor on their coats and imploring to be let in. They got in and filled up a section of the hall near the door, prepared to make a noise at the proper time.
One of the new cars recently put on the Broadway line, No. 231, met with a mishap at the corner of Broadway and Spring-street yesterday afternoon while on a down trip.

The rice dealers and importers declared yesterday that the decision of the Treasury Department that broken or granulated rice should be allowed to be entered on payment of a duty of 20 per cent. ad valorem would really decide little or nothing, as it was not fair nor equitable and had been largely brought about by certificates sent from Rangoon and not from a careful examination of the rice itself.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 22.--A special to the News and Courier from Johnston's says that O.T. Culbreath was lynched to-day at Edgefield. He was charged with killing William Hammond, a young man who was guarding the...

"I never speak at fairs now," said Senator Cullom last evening. "A man with a speech has no show against a horse race or a fat cow. The last time I tried to make a speech at a fair was at Lincoln--right down near me, you know. There were two rings near the stand.

DETROIT, Sept. 22.--A novel case has just been decided in the Superior Court of this city. John E. Jenks manufactures certain pills. Last September he sold a large quantity of them to James E. Davis Co., a drug firm of this city, on condition that they should not dispose of them under a certain price.

The Caffey Cottage, a Summer boarding house at Larchmont, was set on fire between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday morning by some unknown person who had saturated the outside thoroughly with kerosene and then lighted it. There were several boarders in the house.

Tommy, the famous little running dog belonging to Jack McMaster, the trainer of the Williamsburg Athletic Club, died suddenly in his kennel, on the club's grounds. Classonavenue, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.
The Democracy of Kentucky are not going to nominate any old politician nor any war veteran for Governor next time.

C. Fred La Mont writes to THE TIMES that the First Assembly District Democratic Convention of Orange County did not unceremoniously set Congressman Beach aside, as stated, and that the convention was not controlled by Alderman Doyle.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22.--In the United States Circuit Court here to-day, Judge Brewer presiding, leave was granted to Wager Swayne, Trustee, to foreclose the Indianapolis Division mortgage of the Wabash system for default in interest.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 22.--The great strike that has prevailed at the Cleveland rolling mills for the past three months is practically over. This morning the crucial test came. The company had made the announcement that they would blow the whistle for the men to go to work the same as if no strike had ever occurred.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22.--The naval board appointed in August to make an inventory of all work done on the unfinished cruisers Chicago, Boston, and Atlanta and of all material applicable thereto have submitted their report to the Secretary of the Navy.

Elizabeth Fieldham, a young woman who lives with her parents at No. 423 West Seventeenth-street, quarreled with her father on Monday night. She then went out and soon returned and told her mother that she had taken a quantity of white lead for the purpose of killing herself.

There are probably hundreds of thousands of men in the country who feel as did a correspondent of ex-President Arthur, when he wrote a few days ago: "Inclosed find a dollar.
