After buying his Sunday dinner at a grocery store in Greenwich-avenue, near Seventh-avenue, Saturday night Ernest Rost started for home. It was only a few minutes past 10 o'clock. He lived at No. 229 West Thirteenth-street, near Eighth-avenue.
Vinton has been released by the Athlet ics. Dorgan is increasing his batting average of late. Baldwin, of the Detroits, is one of the few pitchers who can bat well.
LEWISTON, Idaho, Sept. 22.--Five Chinamen, implicated in the murder of Fraser and the robbery in Pierce City, were taken from jail by citizens last night and hanged to trees near by.
The inquest into the death of Edward Carroll, who was shot and killed at Waverly, N. J., last Saturday morning by Special Officer Dwyer, of the Pennsylvania Railroad, was begun yesterday.

The Porte has now a perplexing problem presented to it--a problem that recalls the one it undertook to solve in 1877, with results to itself so disastrous. The revolution in Roumelia, though hitherto bloodless, has led to unquestionable infractions of the treaty of Berlin.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 22.--The first concert of the Worcester Music Festival this afternoon opened with a fine performance of Beethoven's dramatic Leonore overture in C. The orchestra consists of only 53 pieces, but the artists are well selected and the body of tone seems ample for the hall.

A number of owners of property in Twenty-seventh-street, between Sixth and Seventh avenues, have formed an organization, to be known as the Owners and Business Men's Association, to take measures to stop the renting of houses in that vicinity for improper purposes.

Viscount K. Fujinami, of Japan, returned from Sacramento Friday night. He is accompanied by Tooru Yamaguchi and Sosuke Niiyama. The Viscount is of royal blood, being a nephew of the Emperor of Japan.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22.--The Daily News of this evening prints the first of a series of articles designed to show that a large number of police officers are regularly levying tribute upon unfortunate women who haunt the streets of Chicago. It is charged that patrolmen, and at least in one instance a police Sergeant, on the West Side, together with John Brennan, an ex-policeman,...
The story comes from Rutland, Vt., that Silas M. Waite, ex-President of the ruined First National Bank, has been cruelly treated by one of the attendants at the House of Correction.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 22.--S.M. Hickey today concluded arrangements with Courtney's representative, Spellman, and the double scull race between Hanlan and Lee and Courtney and Conley will be rowed off Pleasure Island on Tuesday, Oct. 13, at 3:30 P.M. Both crews are practicing on the Lancaster course.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 22.--Early yesterday afternoon George Chambers, a farmer, 52 years of age, and his wife drove to this city from their home, seven miles distant, in the town of New-Windsor.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 22.--Oberlander, left fielder of the Stars, of Syracuse, had his left leg broken at Oneida to-day while playing in the game against the Oneida Baseball Club. He was endeavoring to steal second base, and came into collision with the baseman. He was one of the best men in the nine.
The young horsemen of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association made rare sport for themselves and their friends at their grounds at Cedarhurst yesterday.

The first noonday wedding of the season occurred yesterday at St. George's Church, Stuyvesant-square. The bride was Miss Marion Du Bois Floyd, the eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicoll Floyd, of this city. The groom, Dr. Charles L. Lindley, is a son of the late Rev. Dr. Lindley, who was a missionary to Africa.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22.--Commissioner of Railroads Johnston has received from C.P. Huntington, of the Central Pacific Railroad, an answer to his inquiry concerning the payment of subsidies to the Pacific Mail Steamship Company.

The Republican Convention at Saratoga yesterday listened to a trumpery speech from Senator WARNER MILLER, its temporary Chairman, completed its organization, took one ballot for a candidate for Governor, and hastily adjourned until this morning.

The County Democracy Committee on Arrangements yesterday made final preparations for the trip to Saratoga. Grand Marshal Keiso issued an order that delegates and their friends should meet at the Grand Central Station at 9:30 A.M. to-day. In the order Mr. Kelso also says:

LONDON, Sept. 22.--It is stated this afternoon that Sir Richard Assheton Cross, the Home Secretary, disavows the action of the police in interfering with the proceedings of the Socialists' meeting at Limehouse on Sunday last, and will mitigate the sentences of the eight Socialists who were convicted on Monday of obstructing the police in the performance of their duty.

DUBLIN, Sept. 22.--A meeting of the National League was held here to-day. It was announced that $3,000 had been received from the Irish-Americans of San Francisco for the support of the cause. The announcement created great enthusiasm.

CHAMBERLIAN, Dakota, Sept. 22.--Orders have been posted in the Post Office at this place signed by John G. Gassman, United States Indian Agent at the Crow Creek Agency, ordering all settlers to move their effects from the reservation before Oct. 7 ...
The Hoboken Council to-night passed an ordinance providing for a license fee of $250 for roller skating rinks and rules for the management of the rinks. Improper persons must be excluded.

The French adaptation in verse of "Macbeth," by M. Jules Lacroix, was revived at the Odeon last night. Rousseil as Lady Macbeth.
MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 22.--Returns at the Health Office show that there were 27 deaths from smallpox here yesterday, 4 in Ste. Cunegonde, 3 in St. Jean Baptiste village, and 2 in Cote St. Louis.

Before the vote was taken in the convention to-day few delegates would have been willing to believe that this would be the outcome.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22.--It is stated here to-day that the action of the State authorities to have the sale of the South Pennsylvania Railroad to the Pennsylvania Railroad Company restrained will be settled one way or the other early in October.

AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 22.--Abner Coburn Martin, nephew of the late ex-Gov. Coburn, who resides in San Francisco, has filed a petition in the State Supreme Court to break the deceased's will, on the ground that one of the witnesses to the will was a stockholder in the corporation of the Coburn Hall Association, which was a legatee under the will. A hearing will be had on the matter at the December term of the court.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 22.--The handsome bridge over Jones's Falls, at Calvert-street, is decorated on either corner by an elaborately carved lion of colossal size.
A large crowd spread over the fair grounds at Mineola, Long Island, yesterday, at the opening of the forty-fourth annual exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 22.--A verdict was rendered to-night by the Coroner's jury inquiring into the death of the engineer and fireman killed in the wreck of a passenger train on the Kentucky Railway, in which accident many others were injured.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22.--David H. Wilkie, a Chicago builder, made an assignment to-day for the benefit of his creditors to Hugh Davies.

MONTREAL, Sept. 22.--The testimony in the case of Mr. Sheppard, charged with having libeled the Sixty-firth Battalion in his paper, the Toronto News, was concluded to-day. Sergt. Neilson, of the Toronto Grenadier Guards, was the principal witness. He acknowledged having made the charges against the Sixty-fifth, but only gave them as hearsay.

The principal contest at Creedmoor yesterday were the "President's Match" for the military championship of the United States and the Wimbledon Cup match at the 1,000 yards' range.

The second day's play in the cricket match between the English amateurs and the All New-York eleven yesterday was productive of very fine play on the part of the visitors, but the home team showed up very badly. The day was anything but pleasant on the Staten Island ground, a heavy mist hanging over the waters of the Bay, causing the light to be anything but good for either batsmen or fielders.

A dispatch from Clearfield, Penn., to the Pittsburg Commercial Gazette says: "The Hon. William A. Wallace, of Clearfield, whose son died on Monday morning from the effects of a fall a few days previous, is indeed an unfortunate man.

RALEIGH, Sept. 22.--The Register, a weekly paper published in this city by Mr. P.M. Hale, who is State Printer, in the last two numbers frequently refers to civil service reform as "snivel" service reform, and as yet no Democrat and no newspaper of that party has denounced this sneering and contemptuous allusion to the principal issue upon which Mr. Cleveland was elected.

Bacon, pending an investigation of all the circumstances attending the change in the office. The action of the Secretary is based on information that the appointment is an improper one. ELGIN, Ill., Sept. 22.--The Republican Convention for the Fifth Congressional District of Illinois was held here to-day and A.J. Hopkins, of Aurora, was nominated on the first ballot, to succeed the late Reuben Ellwood.

LIMA, Sept. 22, via Galveston.--Several merchants implicated in the Cacerist movement have been banished from the country. The uncloaking of the conspiracy, through the capture of Cacerist correspondence, is likely to prove fatal to the rebellion.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22.--President Dexter, Franklin McVeigh, and the other older members of the Chicago Civil Service League, who became so excited over an unexplained official indorsement by the league of charges against Collector Spaulding, were somewhat calmer today.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 22.--At East Aurora, Erie County, to-day, the firm of Richardson, Beebe Co., made, it is claimed, the largest cheese ever pressed.

CHRISTIANIA, Sept. 22.--Christine Nilsson met with a most enthusiastic reception upon her arrival here. The streets through which she passed were crowded with people, who heartily cheered the celebrated singer.
BUFFALO, Sept. 22.--The First Assembly District Democratic Convention to-day elected as delegates to the State Convention J.H. Cannon, George Chambers, and John J. Kennedy. They are uninstructed.

A Presque Isle clergyman who thinks that women's sphere does not include the ballot box and the ward caucus tried to interview Hannibal Hamlin on this subject.
GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 22.--Reports are coming from the cotton belt districts of Texas showing that the heavy rains of the past week have worked serious damage to the standing cotton.

ROME, Sept. 22.--There were 214 new cases of cholera and 175 deaths in Palermo during the past 24 hours. Reinforcements of troops have arrived at different points in Sicily, and the populace has been quieted. No disorders are reported there to-day.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22.--The Tribune on Sept. 15 instructed a large number of its correspondents in various parts of the country to each impartially interview in his neighborhood "a prominent merchant, banker, and farmer," with a view to getting the candid opinions of these gentlemen "concerning the intended war of Wall-street on silver money."

Much interest was manifested yesterday in yachting circles in the challenge of Mr. John B. Herreshoff, owner of the Stiletto, to sail the Atalanta a race over a course of 100 miles, on the Hudson River, which was published in yesterday's TIMES.

Mr. D'Oyly Carte is reported to have told an interviewer at New-York the other day that the Japanese coiffure, which he had introduced on the Savoy stage in "The Mikado," was growing fashionable in London, and that certain great ladies had already adopted it.

A dangerous fire burst out at 2:45 o'clock yesterday morning on the top floor of the fivestory building Nos. 177 and 179 Grand-street, occupied by M. Friedman Co., makers of umbrella sticks and walking canes.

Capt. R.B. Forbes was born at Jamaica Plain, Sept. 18, 1804, and therefore is 81 years of age to-day. At his birth he weighed less than five pounds, and grave doubts were entertained "whether he should ever come to anything useful," and yet he grew to be a model man in body and mind.

Alfred A. Page, who was known as Dr. Page, and who was supposed to be a native of Virginia and to have been graduated in that State, died yesterday at the Hotel St. George under circumstances that point to suicide by morphine or an overdose of the drug.

LONDON, Sept. 22.--The Standard's correspondent at Vienna states that in an interview the Austrian Under Foreign Secretary assured him that Austria had no intention of annexing Bosnia and Herzegovina, as has recently been published. Emperor Francis Joseph's visit to Bosnia, the Secretary said, had no connection with the recent events in Roumelia.
MONTREAL, Sept. 22.--The negotiations for the transfer of the North Shore Railway from the Grand Trunk to the Canadian Pacific have been completed.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 24.--Ada Green Hicks, the young wife who donned male attire and came here from New-York a few weeks ago in search of a truant husband, was arraigned in the Hustings Court to-day and pleaded guilty to housebreaking. Her punishment was fixed at five years in the State prison.

Philip Fitzsimmons, a drug clerk, 46 years of age, living in Morrisania, was a prisoner at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on a charge of disorderly conduct.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 24.--The Freshman Class entering Yale to-day is the largest on record, 160 entering the academic and 90 the scientific departments. This is a great surprise, as it was thought that Harvard, by dropping Greek as a required study, would profit at the expense of Yale, which retains it.
LOUISVILLE, Sept. 24.--The first race today, 1 mile and 500 yards, was won by Athlone by a half length in 2:16, Biddy Bowling second, Volo third. Mutuals paid $14.70.

The trial of the suit of James B. Silkman, of Yonkers, against Darius G. Crosby, of New-York, was brought to a termination yesterday afternoon, in the Circuit Court at White Plains, after a four days' trial. Both the plaintiff and defendant are lawyers.

Nearly every leading manufactory of wire was represented at a meeting Tuesday afternoon at the United States Hotel, at which it was decided to order an advance in prices ranging from 10 to 15 per cent., basing the advance upon the general improvement in the wire trade all over the country.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 24--The contents of the two barrels of a shot gun, fired by James Wilson, will end the life of James Armstrong, a neighbor, with whom he had quarreled. The shooting occurred yesterday in a remote part of Jessamine County, near Kentucky River.
PARIS, Sept. 24.--The clerical newspapers here declare that fully 24,000 Christians were murdered in the recent outbreaks in Anam.

BELLAIRE, Ohio, Sept. 24.--At a meeting of the flint glass workers and manufacturers to-day, a compromise was effected by which the 10 months' strike is positively ended. The fires will be lighted to-morrow.

In "The Four Georges" great amazement is expressed by Thackeray because George II, seized his father's will, and never would permit it to be proved, nor was anything ever heard of it afterward, and its suppression produced a violent quarrel with the royal family of Prussia.

The Autumn race meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association was brought to a successful close yesterday afternoon at Cedarhurst. There was as large an attendance as upon the first day of the meeting.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24.--The Bankers' Convention finished its business before 1 o'clock today, and in the afternoon many of the old delegates took a trip to Pullman, where they were shown the beauties of the model town. The business of the convention was not particularly interesting.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24.--Five days ago this usually quiet village was startled by the discovery that a great crime had been committed within its limits, and that the perpetrator, Henry Guy Carleton, of New-York, was still at large.

TRENTON, Sept. 24.--Vice-Chancellor Bird to-day filed an opinion overruling the demurrer of Daniel Dodd and the other managers of the defunct Newark Savings Institution to the bill of complaint entered by George a Wilkinson, Receiver of the bank.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 24.--The registration of voters under the new law was begun to-day. The law applies to Cincinnati and Cleveland.

The thirteenth annual Fall prize meeting of the National Rifle Association came to an end at Creedmoor yesterday. One hundred and seventy-eight cash prizes were awarded to successful marksmen, amounting in the aggregate to about $2,500, besides the usual contribution of badges, clocks, and rifles.

The attention of the Essex County Court of Common Pleas of Newark was absorbed yesterday in the hearing of an old suit for the property of a deceased Catholic priest. Twenty years ago the Rev. Philip McMahon, a Catholic priest, disappeared from Brooklyn.

Three thousand people went out to the North Hudson Driving Park above Weehawken yesterday to witness the second day's racing of the Fall meeting. Several hundred ladies were in the grand stand. The first event was the final heat in the 3:00 race, which was postponed from Wednesday.

The schooner yacht Dauntless, which sailed with the cutter Genesta in the race from Sandy Hook Lightship to Brenton's Reef Lightship and back again, passed the starting point on the return at 11:20 o'clock Wednesday night, just 6 hours and 20 seconds behind the Genesta.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 24.--Gov. Hill delivered the annual address at the Onondaga County fair to-day. He rode to the grounds with Judge Ruger, accompanied by Judges Comstock and Andrews.

OTTAWA, Sept. 24.--Official returns show that there has been a large falling off in the export of fish from Canada to the United States since July 1, last when a new agreement was entered into between Canada and the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24.--The opposition among independent Republicans to Col. Quay for State Treasurer is beginning to take shape. A thorough organization is on foot, and within five or six days a mass meeting of the Republicans will be called, and the bolt will be formally started.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 24.--The steam boiler in Bush Stockwell's flouring mill, at Wilson, Niagara County, exploded this morning, one-half of the boiler going through the side of the mill to a distance of 10 rods. The mill and machinery were badly wrecked. Fortunately no person was injured. The damage to the mill is estimated at $10,000.

BATH, N.Y., Sept. 24.--News of the nomination of Mr. Davenport by the Republican State Convention was received at his home here with the greatest enthusiasm by our citizens without regard to party.

James Renwick, the architect of St. Patrick's Cathedral, filed plans yesterday in the Bureau of Buildings for two spires to be erected on the Fifth-avenue front of the Cathedral. The spires, when completed, will cost, Mr. Renwick estimates, $190,000, and work is to be begun on them within a month.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 24.--A loud report of a pistol in the Vanderbilt House barroom this morning caused much excitement among the guests.

The second day of the open tournament of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club at Montrose, N.J., was very well attended. Numbers of carriages containing many well known people from "the Oranges" and New-York were on the ground.

In Trinity Chapel, at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Miss Nannie Robertson Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Thompson, was married to Mr. A. Emilius Outerbridge, of this city. The Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix officiated.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 24.--The State census gives Des Moines a population of 32,469, a gain of 10,061 over the Federal census of 1880. This does not include any of the eight suburban corporations, which have about 5,000 more. Des Moines has the largest gain since 1880, Sloux City second, Cedar Rapids third.
WORCESTER, Sept. 24.--This afternoon's concert was far below the festival standard. MacFarren's "May Day" cantata was the principal feature.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24.--The leave of absence granted Capt. Frank D. Baldwin, Fifth Infantry, has been extended 10 days. Lieut.-Col. Thomas F. Barr, Deputy Judge-Advocate-General, has been relieved from duty in the War Department, to take effect Oct. 10, and assigned to duty as Judge-Advocate of the Department of Dakota.

Nicolas Pierola, the ex-President of the Republic of Peru, arrived in this city by the Pacific Mail steamer City of Para yesterday afternoon, Signor Pierola was banished from Peru in the latter part of last month by President Iglesias, and he has come to this country for a short rest.

LONDON, Sept. 24.--An immense popular meeting was held here to-night, at which orations were delivered by Messrs. Bradlaugh, Morley, Chamberlain, and others. The hall in which the meeting proper was held was packed by an audience of 7,000 persons, and outside the building fully 20,000 more were assembled.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 24.--At the Republican State Convention held here to-day Francis Miller, of Montgomery, was nominated for Controller and William M. Marine, of Harford, for Clerk of the Court of Appeals.

BOSTON, Sept. 24.--Major Edward P. Brown, the well known Boston lawyer and opponent of Gov. Butler in the notorious Tewksbury Almshouse investigation, has disappeared for the present and left no trace behind.

EASTPORT, Me., Sept. 24.--Eleven men were drowned in the wrecked steamer Humacoa at Grand Manan yesterday, not 20, as before reported. Only one of the crew--Jeremiah Daley, a young man, 18 years of age--was saved.
MONTREAL, Sept. 24.--La Minerve, commenting on the result, of the Sheppard case, says the verdict is in conformity with justice and equity.

There was just frost enough in NewJersey during the cold weather of Wednesday to touch the tops of the tall chestnut trees, loosening the nuts, which were shaken to the ground by the high winds, while the frost was not sufficient on a level with the gardens to affect the most sensitive plants. The annals of New-Jersey do not record the falling of the chestnuts so early in the Fall before.

The death list in Montreal grows longer from day to day. The number of victims on Sunday was 41; on Tuesday it was 48, and on Wednesday 51. There are in the city 100,000 persons who have never been vaccinated.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24.--The Chicagos met with fair defeat at the hands of the Providence Club to-day, to the chagrin of a large audience. Shaw was at his best, and puzzled the home batsmen. He was given splendid support in the field also.

SARATOGA, Sept. 24.--David B. Hill has been nominated for Governor. His name was presented by a liquor dealer of Chemung. Democracy's freebooters are in the saddle. Its baser politicians have wedged themselves to the front. They have named for their standard-bearer one of their own stripe--a man who is repugnant to the best members of the Democratic Party.

POTTSDAM, N.Y., Sept. 24.--Charles L. Knapp, of Lowville, was nominated for Senator by the Republicans of the Twentieth District, in session here to-day.

William Fraisse, a distinguished Swiss civil engineer and politician, died a few days ago at Lausanne of which town he was a native, in his eighty-fourth year. In his early youth he showed a special aptitude for the exact sciences.
"What a blessing it would be," writes a correspondent, "if the Swiss only had the same public spirit as the Americans.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24.--It is no uncommon sight in Chicago to see a policeman leave his supposed post and go into a neighboring saloon for a drink. More common yet is it to see officers in uniform whiling away their hours when off duty in a saloon.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 24.--Prof. Johnson, of the United States Bureau of Geology, has for some time been making an examination of the hill parishes of Louisiana for coal and iron.

DES MOINES, Sept. 24.--James Michelwait, the Prohibition nominee for Governor, is a Prohibition Democrat, and was an Assemblyman in the Legislature of 1873. The other nominees are Republicans. The ticket will probably receive more votes than the straight Greenback ticket, to be nominated Oct. 1.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 24.--The Rev. Edward McColgan, Vicar-General of the Archdiocese of Baltimore and Pastor of St. Peter's Church, was to-day invested with the purple rochet and mantilla of a Monsignor in the Catholic Church.

NASSAU, New-Providence, Sept. 21.-- Statements which lately appeared in print, to the effect that the schooner Helen M. Rowley, of Port Jefferson, N.Y., had been seized and sold by the authorities here, are incorrect. The vessel has nearly completed repairs and will soon proceed to sea in ballast, another vessel being already chartered to take forward her chargo.

ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 25.--The feeling in St. Petersburg regarding the Roumelian question is hourly becoming more warlike. The sympathy of the masses is strongly with the Bulgarians. Mr. Frank Siddall, of Philadelphia, who purchased the pacers, Westmont and Lorene, of Mr. J.M. Hill a week ago, is very proud of his new property. Mr. Hill feels rather regretful at losing his team.

HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 25.--The body of a man, supposed to be that of Herman Podewels, of West Point, Neb., was found on the railroad track near Catskill this morning horribly mutilated. He was a passenger on the Atlantic train on the Hudson River Railroad, and, it is believed, was going to Burnside, Orange County. It is thought that he fell from the train.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25.--The Executive Committee of the Lehigh and Schuylkill Coal Exchanges met to-day and agreed to advance the line and city and harbor prices 10 cents per ton on all sizes for October.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--The Socialistic leaders of this city are out with a new scheme. There are about 250,000 wageworkers, laborers and artisans, in Chicago, and the number of trades and occupations of all kinds represented here is, in round figures, 500.
VIENNA, Sept. 25.--It is rumored here tonight that the King of Servia has been murdered. The report is, however, not confirmed.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 25.--The leading feature of this afternoon's concert at the Musia Festival was the performance of selections from Rubinstein's "Tower of Babel," including the orchestral imitation of the storm, the recitatives for bass and tenor, done respectively by Messrs. M.W. Whitney and George J. Parker, and the choruses of the three dispersing tribes.

To-day the Fall meeting at Jerome Park will begin. The programme is an interesting one, and three stake races are to be decided. The fields are not overlarge, but the quality is good. DAVID BENNETT HILL, the nominee of the Democratic State Convention for Governor, was born in Havana, Schuyler (then Chemung) County, N.Y., on Aug. 29, 1844. His ancestors came from New-England.

BOSTON, Sept. 25.--Lilian Norton-Gower, known professionally as Lilian Nordica, the prima donna, has gone to Paris to claim the estate of her husband, Frederick A. Gower, who is supposed to have been lost from a balloon, as nothing has been heard of him or of the balloon since the ascension was made from Cherbourg in July.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25.--It was stated by the Times at the time of the death of Emery A. Storrs that he left no property. This was, it now appears, a weak way of stating it. Mr. Storrs left his wife absolutely penniless.

Frank Smith, a youth whose face was one of childish innocence and simplicity, on Thursday pleaded guilty, in the Court of General Sessions, to picking the pocket of Frederick Scheyer, a Newark brewer, of a gold watch and two rings.

MONTREAL, Sept. 25.--The proprietor of the Toronto News is determined that in future his paper will be outside of the jurisdiction of the courts of this Province, and has in consequence canceled the circulation of the paper in Quebec.

TORONTO, Sept. 25.--An anti-French meeting was held here to-night for the purpose of forming an organization against the French Canadians, who, it is alleged, are getting too strong a hold on politics in this country.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 25.--President Adams this afternoon gave his first annual talk to the student body of Cornell University in Sage Chapel. His remarks were very practical and were mostly of counsel.

A large number of people who have country places near New-York were in attendance, and returned to their homes the same evening.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26.--Charles H. McCauley, formerly an examiner in the Pension Office, was arrested here to-night in the act of setting fire to a large office building known as the Le Droit Building. His purpose was discovered in time to prevent any material damage. He is said to have made five similarly unsuccessful attempts to destroy this building before this. It is thought his mind is unsettled by business troubles.

A debt of $60 until recently existed between Salvano Briallo and Miguel Marange, two Italians, who live at No. 1 Howard-court, Brooklyn, but on Monday Marange paid $58 on account. Salvano has since been trying to collect the remaining $2, but without avail.

Very large crowds went to Riverside Park yesterday to visit Gen. Grant's tomb. Capt. Brewerton and Lieut. McClellan had all the work that they could attend to in escorting very aged and enthusiastic ladies and gentlemen into the tomb.

Pretenders to longevity usually turn out upon strict inquiry to be hoary impostors. They are not half so aged in reality as they make themselves out to be. Mountains, themselves, for all their show of antiquity, form no exception to this almost universal rule of evidence.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 26.--One of the prettiest single scull races ever rowed on the Schuylkill took place this afternoon. The contestants were Harry Sankey and P.A. Holt, both local oarsmen, well known to lovers of aquatic sport.
The first of the gold shipments from Europe reached the city yesterday by the Bremen steamship Werra, the amount being $1,215,000, the largest single shipment for a very long time.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 26.--The Willowdale Company, manufacturers of blankets, at No. 178 Devonshire-street, Boston, and Meriden, Conn., has liabilities of about $400,000, of which some $300,000 are secured by hypothecations.

A great number of spectators attended the third meeting of the lacrosse teams of the St. Regis Indians and the Williamsburg Athletic Club yesterday in Brooklyn. The grand stand was well filled, and the free stand was black with the coats of the supporters of the home club.
BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 26.--William Tierney, aged 14 years, has been arrested for setting fire to the seven-story Roberts Block of buildings on Chardon-street, last night.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 26.--The Republican Convention for the Second District of Onondaga County to-day nominated Alfred Stacy, of Elbridge, for member of Assembly.

The members of the three Democratic factions in this city were resting yesterday. The labors at the State Convention had apparently made them all tired, but each organization had pickets out, and it was easy to see that the preliminaries for the local contest were being quietly arranged.

The inner hot nucleus of the globe (which is not liquid, as the old-fashioned geologists did vainly hold, but solid and rigid) contracts faster than the cooler outside. The cold upper shell therefore falls in upon it more or less continually, and thus, occupying less horizontal space, must necessarily cause great lateral pressure.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 26.--Mrs. Jane Brower, soon after rising yesterday said that she was near death. She returned to bed and died a few moments afterward. She was aged 105 years and 8 months. She had never worn spectacles. The day before her death she split some kindlings for the kitchen fire.

In the back room of a Third-avenue lodging house there lives a talented young man who ekes out a slender livelihood by writing advertisements for business houses whose proprietors lack the ability to attract attention by their own printed announcements.

Thompson had kept himself so secluded that it was impossible for any friend of Gov. Hill to see him and tell him what he was expected to do in the way of helping to elect the State ticket.
The Madison-Avenue Congregational Church, the pulpit of which was vacated by Dr. Newman last Spring, was reopened yesterday to a small congregation numbering less than 100 persons.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 27.--Mrs. David Rice of Shelby, was walking on the railroad yesterday, when a spark from a passing locomotive set fire to her clothing and she was burned to death.

Just after the Long Island City ferryboat Long Beach left her slip at East Thirtyfourth-street at 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning the attention of the few passengers was attracted by the strange conduct of a young and neatly dressed woman, who carefully searched her pockets and threw overboard every loose thing she found, including several pieces of paper.
READING, Sept. 27.--A wreck occurred on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, near Tuckerton, at a late hour last night, caused, it is said, by an open switch.

LOWELL, Mass., Sept. 27.--Ex-Gov. Tablot is slightly more comfortable to-day. His pulse is improved, and his temperature is nearly normal. His physicians feel encouraged.

The October number of the North American is one of the best ever issued under its present management. The articles have for the most part the merit of timeliness. They are written by skilled writers and by men of eminence, and they relate to subjects in which the public interest is vital and considerable.

Cola E. Stone, one of the best amateur bicycle riders of this country, and champion of the West, died an his home in St. Louis on Saturday. Hendee and broke his arms, from the effects of which accident he died.

ST. JOSEPH, Sept. 27.--The Sam Jones camp meeting opened here to-day. An immense tent, with a seating capacity of 8,000 people, has been erected in the heart of the city, and four meetings will be held daily. Many people were turned away during each service to-day. Sam Jones is assisted by S.W. Small, "The Old Si" of the Atlanta Constitution.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 27.--What came as near to a riot as anything New-Haven has seen for years occurred late this afternoon. Patrolman William Tighe found Edward McDermott half drunk and disorderly on Oak-street, one of the worst parts of the city.

The first of the indoor concerts given this season at the Casino was held last evening. The band was somewhat stronger numerically than it has been of late, and two soloists-Mme. Teresa Carrefio, pianist, and Mr. Jules Levy, cornetist--took part in the entertainment. Several compositions that were new to Casino audiences, if not to the regular frequenter of the concert room, were rendered.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27.--The 16 Chicago playhouses have furnished theatregoers during the past week with everything from grave to gay and from good to bad. Comedy has preponderated. Melodrama of a wishy-washy kind has come next, and there has been at least one interesting and excellent representation of tragedy. Of comedy Lotta in "Nitouche" has led every other attraction, filling McVicker's at every performance.

I hear that the Empress Eugenie has been very unwell in Germany. She did not benefit by her course of the Carlsbad waters, and has now been ordered to go to Meran, in the Tyrol, for a three weeks' grape cure. The Empress intends to remove next month the coffins of her husband and son from Chislehurst to the new mausoleum which she has erected at Farnborough.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27.--Col. John C. Kelton, Assistant Adjutant-General, who has been on duty on this coast for the past 15 years, has been relieved from duty at the Headquarters of the Division of the Pacific, and has been ordered to report for duty to the Adjutant-General at Washington. Lieut.-Col. Chauncey McKeever will be his successor. Col. Kelton will leave here about Oct. 1.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton occupied his pulpit yesterday for the first time since the Summer vacation. There were traces in his voice of the severe cold that prevented his resuming the pulpit a week ago yesterday, but otherwise he seemed, as he said he felt, in better health than for a long time.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 27.--The strike at the Cleveland rolling mills is at last ended. The men struck on July 1 against an indefinite reduction in wages which the managers had decided to make.

--A new photograph of Nathaniel Hawthorne has been brought to light by an industrious American collector. It was taken in London 25 years ago, and will be engraved for an early number of Harper's Magazine. Mr. Lathrop says it is "one of the most lifelike and telling portraits of Hawthorne that has ever appeared."

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27.--Thomas C. Hance, Captain of an oyster boat, shot and instantly killed his wife, Annie C. Hance, this evening, in a house of ill fame on Spring-street. The couple had been living apart for some-time. Hance married the woman about two years ago, knowing her to have been a prostitute.

Carl and Benediti Wagarn, two Italians, resided at No. 61 James-street until a few months ago, when the janitor, Michael Durando, put them out for disorderly conduct. Two weeks ago the Wagarn brothers returned while intoxicated...

The flickering embers of Coney Island gave a last vigorous flicker yesterday, and Coney Island went out. The warm weather attracted a considerable number of people to the popular resort and surprised the numerous vendors at the island, many of whom had folded up their tents like silent Coney Islanders and stolen quietly away.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 27.--The yacht Puritan arrived here early this morning from New-York, and has attracted great attention.

HARRISONBURG, Va., Sept. 27.--Major James Ralston, a well known farmer and extensive cattle dealer of this county, was run ever by a train and killed at Cowan's Station, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, to-night.

ATLANTA, Sept. 27.--A man giving the name of Howe died about three weeks ago at a benevolent home in this city, and was buried in the Potter's Field. It has since been learned that his real name was Marsden Waddell and that his home was in Lanark County, Canada.
Wallace Ross says that he and Teemer will row the victors in the double scull rowing event at the Pleasure Island course at Albany, Oct. 13, between Hanlan and Lee and Courtney...

BINGHAMTON Sept. 27.--At a meeting of the leading Democrats of this city, held here last evening, a resolution was passed urging the Democratic State Committee to nominate Gen. Edward F. Jones, of this city, as candidate for Lieutenant-Governor Gen. Jones was Colonel at a Massachusetts regiment that went through Baltimore in 1861.

A fire which occurred last evening in the New-York Institute for the Blind, at Ninthavenue and Thirty-fourth-street, was so handled by William B. Wait, the Superintendent, that a serious conflagration was averted.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27.--Jerry McCarthy, widower, a gain trimmer, 54 years old, has lived for some time with his two unmarried sons, Charles, 22 years of age, and Dennis, 20, in a little house in Milton-avenue.

READING, Penn., Sept. 27.--Mr. Harry Block was run over by a car at Pottstown yesterday and killed. He was an old man, and had a leg fractured in the service of the Reading Railroad Company several years ago.

MONTREAL, Sept. 27.--At a mass meeting of French Canadians held on the Champ de Mars this afternoon resolutions were passed calling for subscriptions for an appeal to England in the case of Riel. Mr. Fitzpatrick, one of Riel's counsel, said that the case would be appealed whether the money was raised or not.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 28.--On the night of the 17th of last December Perty Harrington, a farmer living near Geneva, Ohio, was shot and killed by a man who broke into his house to Commit a robbery.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--Letters of administration were granted to-day upon the estate of the late Emery A. Storrs to the widow, Mrs. Caroline Storrs, who lives at the Leland Hotel.

Col. Mapleson's resident agent in this city received orders from the impresaric yesterday directing him to announce a season of Italian opera at the Academy of Music, beginning on Nov. 2. There will be 28 subscription nights and the price of parquet and balcony seats for the course is fixed at $50, and of boxes at $400.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 28.--The race for the Blue Grass Stakes, three-quarters of a mile, which opened to-day's meeting, was won by Sis Himyar by half a head in 1:16 , Mary Payne second, Katrine third. Mutuals paid $7.70.

The late Frederick Marquand, of Brooklyn, manifested a lively interest in the success of the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association, and more than once made an offer of a large sum of money as a building fund, on condition that the association should raise a given sum in addition. This condition the association was not able to fulfill.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28.--It is stated today by a competent authority that all the Pittsburg interests have agreed to the terms offered by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for the purchase of the South.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 28.--The Trustees of the Art Museum to-day accepted the proposition of David Linton to give them $75,000 for the erection of a new building for the art school in lieu of his former gift for the removal of the old Post Office building for a similar purpose. There is now no prospect that the old Post Office building will be removed.

The Democratic organs which are now whistling in double leads in order to keep up the courage of the rank and file have a discouraging task. The attentive listener detects an elegiac tone even in the shrillest of the whistles.

On the first day the Grant Monument Association's rooms were thrown open to the public contributions were received amounting to $7,667 50. This amount was received on July 29. Since that date 51 working days have elapsed. The amount of the fund to-day is $82,502 08, therefore the averace daily contributions have been $1,617 68.
HONESDALE, Penn., Sept. 28.--Five years ago the Hon. E.B. Hawley, State Senator from the Wayne and Susquehanna District of Pennsylvania, and editor of the Montrose Democrat, became suddenly insane.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 28.--Richard Howell, the world's champion bicyclist made a half mile in this city this afternoon in 1:13 3-5, beating the world's record for that distance by 1 2-5 seconds. He will attempt to-morrow to lower the one-mile record, and is expected to make 2:32. Fred Mood will also make a trial, promising to make 2:30 if Howell makes 2:35 or less.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--Adjt.-Gen. Drum left Washington this morning upon an inspection tour. He will be absent about a week. Gen. Sheridan has returned to Washington and is at his office at the War Department to-day.

The second game between the Lacrosse Club of New-York and the St. Regis Indians on the Staten Island grounds was the best contested game that has been played in or around NewYork this season. Upward of 2,000 people witnessed the contest, and when the New-Yorks were declared the winners by two goals to one the crowd surged on to the ground and fairly mobbed the players.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill, Sept. 28.--Dr. George W. Barton, who has practiced medicine at Sabrook, a little town 20 miles east of this city for 15 years, was shot and almost instantly killed in the street this morning by Dr. Harvey L. Harris, of the same town.

LONDON, Sept. 28.--Lord Salisbury and Lord Randolph Churchill will address a Conservative meeting at Newport next week in the presence of each other and from the same platform. The meeting is designed to show that these two leaders are pursuing a united policy.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 28.--The following certificates of incorporation were filed to-day: The Arnold Ore Company, of New-York; capital, $20,000; Ixion Bicycle Club, of New-York; Uptown Fifth-Avenue Railroad Company, of NewYork; capital, $2,000,000.
HAVANA, Sept. 28.--Limbano Sanchez and Mongo Gonzalez, the rebel leaders, were killed yesterday by Spanish troops. Their bodies were captured, together with their arms and documents.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Sept. 28.--For two weeks it has been constantly raining here. The East Tennessee and the Brunswick and Western Railroad tracks have been so heavily washed that no trains on either road are moving to-day.

The attendance at the Brighton Beach races to-day was below the average, although the weather was delightful, the track is first class condition,, and the programme a very good one. It was, however, a very bad day for favorites, as in only one instance--the fourth race, when Little Minch won--did they fulfill the expectations of their backers.

Joseph Bryning, aged 68, of Mount Vernon, committed suicide yesterday afternoon with a pistol loaded with leaden chips. He threatened his wife and son-in-law, and upon their flight shot himself. Coroner Tice held an inquest, and a verdict of suicide while temporarily insane was rendered.

LONDON, Sept. 28.--Prince Bismarck be-- ing opposed to-a formal conference of the powers on the Roumelian question, Lord Salisbury has agreed that the scope of the proposed meeting of Ambassadors at Constantinople be limited to an exchange of views on the question at issue without any formal voting and without the drawing up of any protocols.
PALERMO, Sept. 28.--There have been reported in this city to-day 162 new cases of cholera and 94 deaths from the disease.

The carpenters and scene setters at Wallack's Theatre paused in their mechanico-histrionic labors yesterday and chuckled in their grimy skins. Mme. Judic was rehearsing and the carpenters, though accustomed to performances all to themselves, could not resist the French comedienne as she gesticulated and tittered according to the requirements of her various roles.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 28.--United States Agent Peacock arrived in this city to-day from the Tonawanda reservation, where he has been paying the Indians their annual allowance. The official count of the tribe makes their number 573, showing that the Tonawandas are slowly but surely passing away. A few years ago they numbered 1,000, but every year there is a failing off.

Yesterday morning a collision occurred near Hinsdale, on the Long Island Railroad, causing a loss in rolling stock to the amount of $10,000. An engineer and fireman and two news boys had a narrow escape from death.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 28.--George Whitely, a well known young man here, went possum hunting last night with a pistol in his pocket. While cutting a log the pistol fell out of his pocket, struck a tree, and was discharged, sending the cartridge into his body. He died this morning.
Games at the Polo Grounds are now called at 3:45. The Metropolitan and St. Louis Clubs play again to-day.

The religious-exercises of the South Baptist Church in Tottenville, Staten Island, last Sunday evening were varied by such episodes as one Deacon boring augur holes in the baptistry to let the water out and prevent a baptism, while other church officers rushed out, drew off their coats, and squared their fists in each other's faces.

OTTAWA, Sept. 28.--The Dominion Government has become alarmed at the great falling off in emigration to Canada, upon which entirely depends the settlement of the Northwest and the success of the Canadian Pacific Railway.
NYACK, Sept. 28.--The Prohibitionists of Rockland County are beginning to arrange for the Fall campaign, and they say they mean to make it an aggressive one.
The annual conference of the Board of Indian Commissioners will be held in October, beginning on the 7th, at the Mohawk Lake Mountain House, Ulster County, N.Y.

A recent number of the New-York Enterprise, a weekly newspaper published and edited by a colored gentleman, is devoted to the instruction of his brethren concerning the conventionalities of society and the requirements of etiquette.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 28.--A very serious epidemic of glanders has developed among the mules used on several of the street car lines and to-day 42 mutes belonging to the St. CharlesStreet Railroad Company incurably infected were taken out and shot, involving a loss of $10,500 to the company.

TRAVERSE, Dakota, Sept. 28.--The most destructive prairie fire ever witnessed in this community occurred yesterday. A man living in Lake Township set fire to some straw.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 28.--To-morrow will be the fifieth day of Mrs. Veronica Bulla's fast. She began abstaining from food Aug. 10, and since then it is claimed nothing but water has passed her lips. She has lost 20 pounds in weight, and is now too weak to leave her-bed, though until a few days-ago she could walk about the house. She began her fast on account of some gastric troubles.
TORONTO, Sept. 28.--The Irish athletic team left here to-day for New-York. A large number of friends were at the station to see them off.
DUBLIN, Sept. 28.--Mr. C.H. James, one of the official Assignees of the Dublin Bankruptcy Court, has been committed for trial on a charge of fraud.

MONTREAL, Sept. 28.--The by-law passed by the Provincial Board of Health making vaccination compulsory having appeared in the Official Gazette increased the excitement among the French Canadians to such an extent that a riot broke out in the east end this morning, and before the crowd dispersed they smashed many of the windows of the East End Health Office.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 28.--Mrs. Frederick Vanderbilt was thrown from her carriage here this evening, her horses running away and colliding with another team. Her injuries are not believed to be serious, but nothing definite could be learned to-night. The driver of her vehicle was badly cut on the forehead.

The raising of it was simply a testimony of the "independent Republicans of the Twenty-second District" to their respect for the character of the nominees of the Republican Party.
MADRAS, Sept. 28.--The municipal authorities have extended the right of suffrage to women.

The Government's suit against ALEXANDER GRAHAM BELL and the American Bell Telephone Company is now attracting attention wherever telephones are used in this country. The subject will be fully considered from all points of view.

Mr. Henry Chanfrau as Kit, the Arkansas Traveler, is a small edition of his lamented father. Henry has a slighter form than the late Frank Chanfrau, his features are less mobile, his eye lacks the sparkle and flash of his father's, his voice the sonorous richness that charmed the playgoers of two generations.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28.--The member of the Eastern Pig Iron Association have appointed a committee to prepare an answer to the circular recently sent out by Secretary Manning asking information from manufacturers and other associations. The association will ask most emphatically for a continuance of specific duties on iron and iron ores.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 28.--The Church of St. John the Evangelist, at Goshen, was dedicated yesterday according to the rites of the Roman Catholic Church.

RED, WING, Minn., Sept. 28.--George Albeilson, of Wabasha County, has lost over 60 hogs with hog cholera during the last two weeks. Near River Falls, Wis., several hundred hogs have died from the same disease. Curiously enough only black and spotted hogs have been attacked by the malady.

The race for the Cape May Challenge Cup between the Genesta and the schooner Dauntless, which was finished yesterday morning by the return of the Genesta, was in reality little more than a walkover for the Genesta, as she held the lead from start to finish, and came in many hours ahead.

BOSTON, Sept. 28.--The cricket match between, the Gentlemen of England and the all New-England fifteen was begun this morning on the grounds of the Longwood Cricket Club. The wickets were pitched soon after 11 o'clock.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 29.--The people living near Moncure, Chatham County, were shocked on the morning of Sunday, Dec. 24, 1883, on learning that during the previous night Mrs. Olive Gunter, aged 89, and Miss Jane Gunter, aged 64, had been murdered, and that a granddaughter of Mrs. Olive Gunter, aged 8 years, had been badly wounded.

The question "Where is Gen. Slocum?" so often propounded in the Gubernatorial campaign three years ago, was revived yesterday with redoubled frequency and emphasis. From early morning until 8 o'clock in the evening the movements and intentions--even the existence--of Gen. Slocum were involved in mystery.

COHOES, N.Y., Sept. 29.--Archie Chibert, aged 5 years, whose parents reside in Sargeantstreet is dying to-night from poisoning caused by eating horse chestnuts. His body has swollen to an enormous size and is greatly discolored.

In clearing up what was supposed to be a fag end of the investigation into the doings of the Armory Board the Senate Committee struck a vein of testimony full of surprises to the men who are privileged to ask questions and of discomfort to the witnesses who must answer them.

TRENTON, Sept. 29.--Rufus Keisler, a letter carrier, attached to the Newark Post Office, was indicted by the United States Grand Jury for having unlawfully opened a letter addressed to one Ellis, and for secreting, embezzling, and destroying the letter.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept., 29.--The Soldiers' Monument was dedicated here to-day. Gov. Robinson and staff, 2,000 Grand Army veterans, and large assemblage of citizens were present. The dedicatory address was delivered by Gen. Joseph R. Hawley.

The supposed murderers of the Bohemian Gotlieb Kalat were arraigned before Recorder Smyth, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday morning. William Carroll, James Fitzpatrick, John Hughes, and Andrew Spanier were jointly indicted for killing the man on Aug. 8, and it was decided to try Spanier alone.
John O'Brien, a laborer employed upon the new Croton aqueduct, was killed at shaft No. 20 yesterday afternoon by the caving in of rocks upon him.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 29.--The war between the Southern New-England Telephone Company and its subscribers has approached a climax.
Mr. D'Oyly Carte's "Mikado" company played a cricket match yesterday with the Staten Island Cricket Club, on the grounds of the latter, at Camp Washington, Staten Island.

Collector Hedden and Surveyor Beattie were in consultation most of the day yesterday with a deputation of politicians, among them Senator Tim Campbell, Maurice B. Flynn, John E. Brodsky, and Richard S. Newcombe.

The Pope has desired the Chapter of Franciscan Monks to suppress the numerous breweries belonging to that order in Bavaria, so there will be no more of the famous "Franziskanner Brau," which is so highly esteemed by all beer drinkers in Germany. The personage who will most deeply regret (and resent) this step will be Prince Bismarck, who was a large consumer of this particular brew, of which he is exceedingly fond.

SPRINGFIELD, Sept. 29.--The Republican politicians are gathering here to-night for the Republican State Convention to-morrow. The professional workers are out in force, but business men and prominent citizens are not numerous among the delegates.
GENEVA, Sept. 29.--The two men who recently robbed the Imperial Russian Bank of 34,000 have been arrested in this city.

All the people who could find room in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, from foyer to footlights, united last night in a beautiful memorial service to Gen. U.S. Grant with the Grand Army post that bears his name. Several rows deep in the auditorium were gray-haired Grand Army soldiers in the dress uniform of the order.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 29.--President White delivered his farewell address in Sage Chapel today before the Faculty and students of Cornell University. Mr. White referred to the founding and establishing of the university, and spoke of the trials and difficulties encountered by Ezra Cornell and his colaborers.

Crowds of ladies visited Stern Brothers' establishment in Twenty-third-street yesterday to view the Fall and Winter importations which that firm had announced could be inspected at that time. ABINGDON, Va., Sept. 29.--The condition of ex-Judge George W. Ward, editor of the Examiner, who was wounded in nine places by Dr. White and his two nephews on Sunday last, is thought to be favorable to-night.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 29.--The bust of Elizabeth Fry, which was presented recently to the Friends' School of this city by Mrs. Ella J. Wheeler, of Boston, was unveiled this afternoon in Alumni Hall by Mrs. Julia Ward Howe. The bust is the work of William Theed. It is of Carrara marble and stands on a beautiful pedestal of Tennessee marble about 4 feet in height. Mrs. Ruth S. Murray presided.
LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 29.--The veterans' reunion in this village to-day was well attended.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29.--Henry O'Brien, a big, burly expressman, was in the Armory Court to-day charged with beating his wife. She appeared in court thin and wan and with eyes red and swollen from weeping.

Ex-United States District Attorney Elihu Root took up the entire day in the Surrogate's Court yesterday in opening the final argument for the defense in the Hoyt will case. NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 29.--A Parnell branchof the Irish National League of America was formed to-night in this city for the purpose of raising funds to support the Parneilite members in Parliament. The movement to raise funds for the Parnellites is spreading all through NewEngland.

PRESCOTT, Arizona, Sept. 29.--Information received from Clifton of Indian depredations is so alarming that Gov. Tritie issued a general order to-day calling out the militia for active service.

Miller. The news was received with general incredulity, and not until it was confirmed by the official announcement at the Stock Exchange was it accepted as a fact.
BUFFALO, Sept. 29.--A meeting of the freight agents of the west-bound roads was held here to-day to take action on the demoralized condition of west-bound coal rates.

READING, Penn., Sept. 29.--After a trial of five days the jury in the case of Jefferson M. Keller against the Pennsylvania Schuylkill Valley Railroad Company returned a verdict this afternoon of $17,500 for damage to the business and property of Mr. Keller, who is an ice dealer. The railroad company's roadbed ran directly through the ice dam and house of Mr. Keller, at the mouth of the Wyomissing.
Miss Maggie Dixon, though but 16 years of age, has been for some time past a school teacher in Union Hill.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 29.--Mr. Benjamin E. Smith, of this city, and formerly one of the largest railroad builders and managers in the West, was adjudged insane to-day and sent to the asylum.
Gen. EDWARD F. JONES has been lowered into the hole made in the Democratic ticket by ROSWELL P. FLOWER's withdrawal. The General was a brave soldier, and helped put down the rebellion.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Sept. 29.--A large meeting closed late last night, at Seattle, Washington Territory. It was a convention of laborers, called together to try to devise some means of ridding the country of the unwelcome Chinese.

The examinations for entrance to Columbia College in the Departments of Arts and Mines commenced yesterday. There were 140 applications for admission to the School of Mines and 117 for admission to the School of Arts. Numerous changes have been made in the curriculum of the School of Arts.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 29.--A special to the Pioneer Press from Winnipeg reports the death of Thomas Lumsden, brother of Sir Peter Lumsden, of the Afghan Frontier Commission. NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 29.--Judge Brown, of the Supreme Court, at his chambers in this city, has granted an absolute divorce to John E. Earle from Agnes A. Earle. Both parties to the suit are well known residents of Middletown, Orange County, the plaintiff being an engineer on the Erie's Middletown express between that place and Jersey City.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 29.--On a muddy track and with the rain falling the races were continued to-day. Gray Cloud won the first race, one and one-quarter miles, by five lengths, in 2:20, Biddy Bowling second, and Pattie W. third. No mutuals.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Sept. 29.--Gen. Miles, commander of the military Department of the Missouri, in his report to the AdjutantGeneral of the army says that the control of the military in New-Mexico has stopped the issuing of 20,000 more rations than the Indians needed, saved $100,000 a year to the Government and driven off the outlaws.

TRENTON, Sept. 29.--Among the indictments found by the recent United States Grand Jury is one against Capt. Yungst, of the steamer Rhein, of the North German Lloyd Line, for carrying more passengers on his vessel than the law allows.
Miss Minnie Maddern's engagement at the Lyceum, originally for four weeks, has been extended to eight weeks. It began Sept. 15. "In Spite of All" is drawing large audiences.
The Colored Republican County Convention met last evening in the lecture room of Bethel Church, in Sullivan-street, between, Bleecker and West Third streets.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 29, via Galveston. --No mail has yet come through from the United States, and there will be none until Wednesday or Thursday next by which time it is expected that the washouts will be repaired and trains be running to and from El Paso, unless more heavy rains fall.

The National Rod and Reel Association will hold its fourth annual tournament on Wednesday, Oct. 21, instead of on Oct. 14. The change in date was considered advisable as many members of the association are still recreating.

The bondholders' committee of the Texas and St. Louis Railway Company met yesterday and received reports stating that the money needed for the reorganization under the plan submitted Aug. 28 had all been subscribed.

With the close of the Summer season the Erie Railway will discontinue the Shohola Glen express. The Mountain express, leaving NewYork at 3:30 P.M., will make its closing trip west of Middletown on Saturday next, returning Monday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29.--One day in March, 1884, Donald McDonald went into a Clark-street restaurant and ordered a breakfast of milk toast. The bill or fare set forth that the price of this delicacy was 10 cents.

Eighty-one Kings County Prohibitionists met in County Convention in Everett Hall, Brooklyn, last evening. A.H. Walkers was Chairman, and E.J. Wheeler Secretary. Speeches were made abusing the Republican and Democratic parties, and a platform was adopted.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29.--The letter from Murat Halstead to Gov. Chase, which has been republished here and elsewhere during the past few days, has created a genuine sensation here. Old soldiers appear amazed and disgusted at the intense bitterness of the letter and the almost insane fury of the writer.
Miss Julie Wilson, of Brooklyn, was married at 12:30 P.M. yesterday to John Aspinwall, of Barrytown, N.Y. The ceremony took place in Grace Church, and was performed by Assistant Bishop Potter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--The removal of Capt. S.A. Johnson, chief of the mail division of the Treasury Department, to make room for Valentine Snyder, a young man from New-York, who came here as Secretary Manning's private secretary and was afterward advanced to the chief clerkship in the Treasurer's office, creates much talk here.

BISMARCK, Dakota, Sept. 29.--A terrific windstorm struck the Upper Missouri Valley, about 200 miles north of this city, yesterday and reports received show that its violence has not been equalled by any storm of the season.

The Republican State Committee will meet at noon to-day at the Gilsey House to organize the campaign in the State. MONTREAL, Sept. 29.--In consequence of the riot last night the Health Board have been compelled to close their east end branch. The mob had emptied on to the street 200 pounds of sulphur, 500 placards, six dozen bottles of carbolic acid, and a large quantity of chloride of lime, and set fire to it, evidently with the intention of disinfecting the district.

Yesterday was the first day in Brooklyn for registration of voters for the coming election, and the lists were open from 7 to 10 A.M. and from 3 to 10 P.M.
The schooner yacht Dauntless arrived off Tompkinsville, Staten Island, early yesterday morning. She passed Sandy Hook at 3 o'clock A.M., and was at her anchorage an hour or two later.

ALBANY, Sept. 29.--It is held in a recent opinion by the Attorney-General that sections 179 to 194 inclusive of subdivision chapter 8 of the revision of the banking laws passed by the Legislature of 1882 (known as chapter 409, Laws of 1882) are not applicable to banks of discount and deposit organized under the general banking law of 1838, or acts amendatory thereof.

WARSAW, N.Y., Sept. 29.--John, the 16year-old son of P.J. Shillinglaw, a dry goods merchant of Attica, while driving his bicycle between the double tracks of the Erie Railroad between the stations of Portage and Castile at noon to-day, was struck by a fast express and killed instantly.

HAVANA, Sept. 29.--Donato Vergez is the only surving member of the Limbano Sanchez party. He is wounded and is being pursued.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29.--About 200 persons attended to-day the formal opening of the Western Theological Seminary, the new Episcopal institution, in the handsome new structure recently completed in Washington Boulevard.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 29.--Work was begun to-day in this city to put all telegraph, telephone, and electric light wires under ground, Dorsett's conduit system being used. Six miles of these conduits are to be laid this Fall in the heart of the city, where the wires are the thickest.

The Tammany General Committe of the Twenty-first Assembly District met at No. 104 West Forty-seventh-street to hear the report of the delegates to the State Democratic Convention. Cornelius O'Reilly wanted, to know why Roswell P. Flower had been slaughtered in the house of his friends.

The American Jockey Club was again fortunate in having fine weather for the second day of the meeting, but the attendance was only moderate. Six races were decided, the first of which, a mile and a furlong, was won by the favorite, Strathspey.
PLYMOUTH, Sept. 29.--The Hamburg-American Line steamship Rhaetia, Capt. Vogelesang, from NewYork Sept. 19, for this port and Hamburg, has passed the Lizard.

BOSTON, Sept. 29.--The cricket match between the eleven of England and the fifteen of all New-England was concluded to-day, the Englishmen winning by 21 runs.
The strange actions of a short, stout woman, about 60 years old and poorly dressed, attracted much attention in North Seventhstreet, Brooklyn, Eastern District, last night.

BOSTON, Sept. 29.--The Directors of the New-York and New-England Railroad, at their monthly meeting to-day, voted to issue $2,000,000 of preferred stock for the purpose of paying the debts of the company.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 29.--The Cigarmakers' International Convention has selected Boston as the place for holding the next meeting, in 1887. A committee was appointed to consider the propriety of consolidation with the Progressive Union.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29.--The members of the New-York Club are in an unhappy frame of mind this evening. They arrived here last night from the Metropolis, accompanied by about 200 of their ardent admirers, with the avowed intention of winning three out of four, or perhaps, as they put it, four straight games, from the Chicago Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--Leave of absence for one month from Oct. 1 has been granted First Lieut. Edward L. Bailey, Fourth Infantry; leave of absence for six months, to take effect about Nov. 1, has been granted Capt. George W.H. Stouch, Third Infantry; leave of absence for four months has been granted Capt. Thomas H. Logan, Fifth Infantry.

The auction sale of the Home Farm herd of Jersey cattle, the property of Col. H.S. Russell, of Milton, Mass., announced to take place at the American Horse Exchange yesterday morning brought together a large number of the prominent cattle breeders of the country. A few of the animals brought high prices, and the aggregate amount of money received for the 63 lots was more than $15,000.

BERLIN, Sept. 29.--The Central Union of German manufacturers, representing the leaders of the protection party, has sent a petition to Prince Bismarck asking him to inquire into the subject of bimetalism.

CALCUTTA, Sept. 29.--Disastrous floods, covering an area of 3,500 square miles, have occurred in the Presidency of Bengal, the largest and most populous of the 12 main divisions of British India.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 29.--The new church building erected for Christ Church Society, (Episcopal.) of Westport, was dedicated this forenoon by the Right Rev. John Williams, Bishop of the Diocese of connecticut.

PALERMO, Sept. 29.--There were 159 new cases of cholera and 89 deaths from the disease reported here yesterday.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 29.--Lieut. Greely was tendered a dinner this evening by business and professional men of this town and county. Several complimentary speeches were made, to which the Lieutenant replied at some length. Lieut, Greely's health has been greatly improved by his Summer in Berkshire, and he now seems to be quite well and hearty.

Keep, editor of the Wall-Street Daily News, by the Manhattan Railway Company, was submitted to Justice Gorman yesterday, and the Justice announced that he would be ready to render his decision on the 13th prox. The brief makes a pamphlet of 33 pages. It is divided into two parts.

DANVILLE, Va., Sept. 29.--Mr. Hugh Walker, living in Caswell County, N.C., about nine miles from here, went to his barn last night, and while he was away a negro. Bud Mebane, went to Walker's house and assaulted his wife.

OTTAWA, Sept. 29.--Squire Boughner, private bankers, of Bothwell, Ontario, are in pecuniary difficulties, brought about through speculation. Their liabilities are placed at $100,000, which, it is believed, will be nearly covered by their assets.

LONDON, Sept. 29.--Earl Dufferin, Viceroy of India, telegraphs to the British Government that necessity has arisen for armed intervention in Burmah, and that he has ordered the chief Commissioner in British Burmah to send to King Thebaw a protest against the exactions of the Burmah Trading Association.

WINDSOR, Ontario, Sept. 30.--The Rev. James C. Smith, (colored,) of this place, was assaulted to-day by John Chambers, a neighbor, who cut him frightfully with a scythe. When Smith was nearly dead from loss of blood Chambers procured a gun and would have killed him at once if Smith's wife had not placed herself in front of her dying husband and called upon Chambers to shoot her instead.

JOLIET, Ill., Sept. 30.--Burglar James Young, of Carroll County, who is serving a sentence of 10 Years at the State prison here, escaped from the harness shops to-day and climbed to the top of a high derrick in the prison yard.
The eight Police Captains who are candidates for the Inspectorship made vacant by the promotion of Inspector Murray will not be examined by the Civil Service Commissioners tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--The Chicago Club won its fifth game from the New-Yorks here today, and by doing so has almost settled the League championship question that has been agitating the minds of admirers of the national game during the past few months.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--The General Freight Agents of the various roads running east from Chicago to-day decided that all foreign business contracted for previous to Monday will have the usual 10 days to be carried out, but all contracts since that day must be loaded by to-morrow night, or else the business will be charged full tariff rates.

The first day of the open lawn tennis tournament of the Ladies' Outdoor Club, at Staten Island, yesterday, was well attended. BOSTON, Sept. 30.--The annual meeting of the Board of Overseers of Harvard College was held to-day. The Hon. E.R. Hoar was reelected President of the board. The appointments were approved of Robert Sanderson as instructor in French, and John Graham Brooks, D.D., as lecturer on Socialism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--On Aug. 3 the Postmaster-General appointed a commission consisting of W.P. Edgarton, Post Office Inspector; H.W. Hall, Post Office Inspector; E.W. Alexander, Superintendent of Mails, Philadelphia, and G.J. Lund, Assistant Superintendent of the Railway Mail Service, to investigate and report upon the New-York and Brooklyn Post Offices and their methods.
Major Zenas C. Priest, Superintendent of the Middle Division of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, will on Oct. 18 complete 50 years of service with that corporation.

The annual exhibition of the American Institute was opened yesterday with an address by the Hon. Hosea B. Perkins, who gave a history of the origin of the institute, its work thus far, and its prospects, and in conclusion an exposition of its value as a stimulus to the American industries and inventions.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 30.--Leopold Rosenfeld and Meyer Kauffman, clothiers, doing business at No. 61 West Pearl-street under the firm name of Rosenfeld Kauffman, made an assignment to-day to Louis S. Levi. Their liabilities are estimated at $100,000 and their assets at $50,000.

The centennial convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of NewYork was organized in Trinity Church yesterday morning. Four hundred clergymen were present when the convention was called to order by Assistant Bishop Henry C. Potter.

Detectives Heidelberg, Lanthier, and Dolan yesterday came into the Tombs Police Court with three prisoners--George M. Horn, Lorenzo D. Cronniger, and George Harris, who also called himself Bedford--whom they charged with forgery.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 30.--The schooner Curtis Ackerly, commanded by Capt. Boulo, reached this port this morning in a waterlogged condition. She sailed hence with lumber for Trinidad Sept. 22, and ran into the cyclone of the both when 150 miles off Mobile.

The auction sale of the late Mrs. Mary J. Morgan's valuable collection of orchids and other rare plants began at 11 o'clock yesterday morning at Horticultural Hall, No. 26 West Twenty-eighth-street. As early as 9 o'clock ladies and gentlemen began to arrive, and when Auctioneer William Elliot stepped on the platform fully 300 people were moving about among the 2,000 plants which were placed on tables stationed on all sides of the large room.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 30.--The Alabama-Soldiers' Monument Association has been organized here to build a monument to the Confederate dead on the Capitol grounds where Jefferson Davis was inaugurated President of the Confederacy. The association includes most of the prominent men in Alabama. The monument is to cost $50,000, and Montgomery has already subscribed a large amount.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--Upon the recommendation of the Surgeon-General, Col. Thomas A. McPharlin, Surgeon, will transfer his duties and the public funds for which he is accountable as Assistant Medical Purveyor to Capt. Henry Johnson, Medical Storekeeper, who will, in addition to his present duties, temporarliy perform the duties of Assistant Medical Purveyor.

BUFFALO, Sept. 30.--The Erie County Republican Convention to-day nominated Daniel H. McMillan, of Buffalo, for State Senator from the Thirty-first District. Mr. McMillan was born in the town of York, Livingston County, in March, 1848.

BALTLIMORE, Sept. 30.--To-day at the meeting of the Corn and Flour Exchange the deaths of four of the members were announced --George W. McClure, Usher Ciabaugh, S.M. Lyle, and Dr. H.F. Zollickoffer. Mr. McClure was one of the oldest members of the body.
A corpse was found at 11 o'clock last night sitting bolt upright on a bench at the south border of the Central Park green. It was that of a man who had evidently shot himself in the left temple.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 30.--The Minnesota and Northwestern Railroad Company has filed a complaint with the State Board of Railroad Commissioners charging the Union Depot Company with "unjust discrimination."

Mrs. Gold, of No. 154 West Forty-sixthstreet, and a Miss Newton were run away with yesterday afternoon while riding on the Eastern Drive at Central Park. At the corner of Fifty-eighth-street and Lexingtonavenue their carriage upset and they were thrown violently to the pavement. Miss Newton struck on her head, was picked up unconscious, and taken to the Presbyterian Hospital, where doubts are expressed as to her recovery. Mrs. Gold was not seriously injured.

Chairman Comstock announced yesterday that a civil service examination will be held at the Custom House on the 14th, 16th, and 17th of the present month for clerks of the twelvehundred-dollar grade, the only clerkships open to the public, the higher paid offices being filled by promotion.

A largely attended meeting of importers, manufacturers, and others in this city interested in arriving at a basis of market value for Swiss and German machine made embroideries and laces, was held at Manhattan Hotel, in Canalstreet, yesterday afternoon. Nearly every prominent lace importing house of the city was represented.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 30.--One of the crew of the steamer Craighill is at Quarantine very sick with yellow fever, having contracted it on the voyage from Progreso, Mexico, and three others are down with the disease. Dr. Griffin has permitted the others of the crew to proceed to the city, their clothing and effects having been thoroughly disinfected.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 390.--Advices from the Indian Territory say that a portion of the Cherokees are disposed to antagonize the appointment of Robert L. Owen as Indian Agent at Union Agency.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 30.--Dr. W.W. Myers, a well known physician of this city, was arrested to-day charged with raising a promissory note from $125 to $925 and forging a note for a like amount, which was not discounted. The hearing will take place on Friday, and in the meantime the doctor has been placed under $3,000 bonds.
LOUISVILLE, Sept. 30.--The first race today, three-quarters of a mile, was won by Moonshine by three lengths, in 1:21, Phil Lee second, Red Girl third. No mutuals sold.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 30.--Canon Farrar reached this city this afternoon as the guest of Johns Hopkins University. To-morrow he will deliver the opening lecture of the Fall course at the university. He will preach in two of the Protestant Episcopal churches of Baltimore after a visit to Washington on Friday.

TUCSON, Arizona, Sept. 30.--A courier who has arrived from Major Davis's command announces that on Sept. 22 the command had a fight with Apaches, killing one and wounding several. Sixty hostiles were engaged. The troops lost one scout. The Indiana retreated into the mountains. Major Davis followed them early the next morning, and was joined by Crawford and his scouts.

LASALLE, Ill., Sept. 30.--Mr. Franklin Webster, formerly of this city, but for several years editor of the Chronicle, New-York, an insurance journal, was married to-day to Miss Jennie Andrews Mason, of Lasalle. The happy couple left to-night for their future home in Orange. N.J.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 30.--At Chester Park to-day, in a pacing race for the 2:15 class, Mike Wilkes paced the first heat in 2:17 and the fourth in 2:20. Jewett took the second heat in 2:19 and Little Mack the third in 2:19 . The conclusion of the race was deferred until to-morrow, owing to darkness.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 30.--The passage of the General Local Option bill by the present Legislature has revived the temperance crusade here in a wonderful degree. While the bill was before the Legislature the Prohibitionists gave out that they would be content with a high license in large cities.
