ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 30.--John Muir. Traffic Manager of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company, passed through here yesterday on his return from the East. He is of the opinion that the Oregon lease is off. He said the Directory of his road was no longer anxious that the lease should be consummated.

Kohlsaat's bakery, in the basement of a four-story brick building back of No. 196 Clark-street, heard a curious crackling sound about 1 o'clock this morning. No particular attention was called to it, but an hour later the engineer noticed that a cap over one of the pillars supporting the floors above was crushed, and that the floor was sinking.

All the trunk line railroads were represented at the meeting of General Passenger Agents, at Commissioner Fink's office, yesterday. The Lehigh Valley Company, for the first time in a long period, sent a representative.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. 1885. It is estimated that there has been a decrease of about $12,000,000 in the public debt during September. The payments on account of pensions during the month were about $4,000,000.

WARM SPRINGS, Montana, Sept. 30.--One of the buildings of the Insane Asylum was burned yesterday, and three inmates--A.B. Magee, Hannah Belcher, and Hector Milanperished in the flames. It is not known how the fire originated.

The members of the County Democracy County Committee met in Chickering Hall last night. E. Ellery Anderson, the Chairman, said that the committee had assembled to ratify the Democratic nominees on the State ticket, and that he was glad to see such an outpouring of Democrats in such a cause.

Mrs. Grant visited Riverside Park yesterday with Col. Fred Grant for the purpose of placing in the sepulchre a floral tribute presented by U.S. Grant Post, of the Grand Army. Later in the day Mrs. Gen. Maltby called, and was admitted to the tomb.

Forty yachts started in the annual Fall regatta of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club yesterday. It was an exasperating sort of a day as far as wind was concerned. At the start there was a very light breeze from the southeast. Then it died away altogether.

PARIS, Sept. 30--Misses Morris, Johnston, Everest, and Tifft, of America, will be Miss Nevada's bridesmaids. Mme. Nilsson has sent a telegram regretting her inability to attend the ceremony owing to the recent tragedy at Stockholm.

UTICA, Sept. 30.--The renomination of Judge George A. Hardin to the Supreme Court bench in the Fifth Judicial District on Friday last was a source of unmixed gratification, not only to the members of the Bar, but to the citi zens of the district generally. ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 1.--Seven naval cadets of the Third Class were caught on Tuesday night hazing the new members of the Fourth Class. The Third Class men were all caught in separate acts of hazing, and inquiries now proceeding will probably end in a courtmartial, and all seven will be dismissed from the navy.

BOSTON, Oct. 1.--Harvard College opened to-day with a large attendance of students, probably the largest number that has ever been in the college. The exact number cannot be ascertained for a few days, as the Freshman Fall examinations will not be concluded until tomorrow.

The Daft electric motor was attached to a train of four cars on the Ninth-avenue elevated railroad last night, and after Jay Gould and a number of gentlemen interested in the new motor and the elevated railroads had taken seats in the cars the train moved out of the Fourteenthstreet station.

LONDON, Oct. 1.--The National Liberal Federation, at a meeting to-day, adopted resolutions favoring the abolition of primogeniture and other forms of entail and security of tenure for farmers, making the compensation for improvements on lands compulsory, and urging the purchase of lands by the Government for allotments to laborers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1, 1885. The President to-day appointed the following named Postmasters: Richard J. Ashby, at Charlestown, West Va., vice A.F. Gibbons, suspended; James Delancy, St. Peter, Minn., vice Joseph K. Moore, resigned.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 1.--Fannie E. Slocum, of this city, has eloped with Fred B. Finger, Captain of the Forty-first Separate Company. Miss Slocum was married when 16 years old to Nicholas Sherman, of Fonda.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 1.--The Ambassadors met to-day to consider the Roumelian question at the residence of Count Corti, the Italian Ambassador, but adjourned without transacting any business of an important nature, several of the Ambassadors having not yet received formal instructions from their respective Governments.

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 1.--The recent lynching of Joseph Grabel, of Greene County, Penn., by a mob of "Red Men" in Wetzel County, this State, promises to lead to some exceedingly interesting developments, and may be the cause of additional lawlessness.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1.--Gastone Malinaro, an Italian laborer, told a queer story to-day in a warrant which he swore out is Justice Lyons's court for the arrest of Raphael De Bartolo, on the charge of abducting him. Malinaro is 29 years old, and speaks English very imperfectly.
MADRID, Oct. 1.--In Spain to-day there have been reported 490 new cases of cholera and 176 deaths from the disease.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 1, via Galveston.-- Mail communication between this city and the United States was resumed to-day, nine days' accumulation of mail being distributed this afternoon. The Central Railway has been repaired at the places where the track was swept away by the bursting of reservoirs.
The body of the woman found dead in the woods near Corona, Long Island, on the morning of July 10, was identified yesterday as that of Mrs. Ann Howard, of Whitestone.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1.--Collector Spaulding, Revenue Collector Harvey, and Pension Agent Sweet retired from the Governments' service to-day, and Collector Seeberger, Revenue Collector Stone, and Pension Agent Mulligan stepped into their places.

A strong delegation from the Staten Island Cricket Club and also from the Ladies' Outdoor Club thronged the White Star pier yesterday morning to bid good-bye to the team of amateur English cricketers who were leaving for home after a successful tour through the United States and Canada.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 1.--At the closing session of the meeting of the International Cigarmakers' Association the Committee on Strikes reported that during the past two years there had been 152 strikes and 27 lockouts among the cigarmakers of this country.

The Rev. Mr. KETOE has just returned from a visit to the settlement in Manitoba of the people who were assisted by benevolent Britons to emigrate thither from the slums of London. He reports that the experiment is entirely successful, and that the emitgrants are paying their way and contented with their lot.

CHESTER, Ill., Oct. 1.--In June last there came to this city from Philadelphia the Rev. Samuel Magee, a handsome, talented young minister of fine social qualities. He had formerly been a minister in the "Old Light" ...

PORT JERVIS, Oct. 1.--John La Forge, aged 14, and Charles Faurot, son of Capt. Theodore Faurot, of Highland Falls, this county, a boy of the same age, went butternutting near that village on Monday. While climbing a wall near Bettman's Pond, the La Forge boy stepped on the tail of a large blowing adder, a snake which is very venomous, but rare in this region.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1.--Services in memory of Gen. Grant were held this evening under the auspices of the local commandery of the Grand Army of the Republic, in the Metropolitan Church of this city, at which Gen. Grant was a regular attendant during his Presidential term.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 1.--Vice-President Oakes, of the Northern Pacific, was asked today regarding the condition of the Transcontinental Association and the probable effect of the Southern Pacific's refusal to honor the drafts of the Denver and Rio Grande for a settlement under the arbitrators' award of percentages.

The steamship Alvo, Capt. Williams, of the Atlas Line, reported at Quarantine on her arrival from Barranquilla and Aspinwall yesterday that two deaths from Chagres fever had occurred during the voyage.

Large as St. Augustine Chapel is it is none too large to accommodate the Centennial Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New-York. Nearly every clerical member of the convention was in his seat at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, and the laymen were little behind them.

Lieut. J.M. Hawley, United States Navy, commanding the Coast and Geodetic Survey schooner Eagre, has discovered a rock in the East River, distant 350 yards east-southeast from Black Buoy No. 1 and 575 yards northwest by north of entrance to Newtown Creek.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 1.--Charles Callaghan, aged 61 years, a resident of Buffalo, N.Y., was burned to death at the home of his son Charles, on Pleasant-street, last night by the overturning of a kerosene lamp.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1.--The fine schooner Frank Wheeler, built at Port Huron last Winter at a cost of about $60,000, went to the bottom of Lake Superior last night and is a total loss.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 1.--Dr. J.M. Matthaws, of this city, who was an applicant to succeed Dr. Hamilton as United States SurgeonGenerat, makes some statements in an interview published this afternoon, which shows that the war between Vice-President Hendricks and exSenator McDonald is now over.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1.--A very large crowd left here to-night on the 6:25 train to attend the Republican meeting at Alexandria. Among the passengers were John S. Wise, Republican candidate for Governor of Virginia, who was to address the meeting, and John Ambler Smith, a claim agent of this city and formerly member of Congress from the Richmond district.

LIMA, Oct. 1, via Galveston.--Advices from Pisco state that the montoneros occupying Ica mumber 250. Canete also fell into their hands after an hour's fighting. The celebrated montonero, Pacheco, was taken prisoner.

The people who visited Jerome Park yesterday got more than they bargained for in the way of excitement. The racing in itself was excellent, and aroused the enthusiasm of the large crowd present, added to which the longstanding antagonism between the Dwyer Brothers and Pierre Lorillard reached a period of open rupture that made the crowd to howl and the judicious to grieve.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 1.--Judge Brown, of the Supreme Court, to-day rendered his de cision in the fifty-million-dollar foreclosure suit of the United States Trust Company against the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railway Company, and has entered the decree of foreclosure and sale. The review of the case and the decree consists of 269 large printed pages.

Capt. William V. Van Rensselaer graduated in an engineer's course at the old Seneca Falls Academy. Whatever he does he does thoroughly, and at the age of 18 he was placed in positions of responsibility in engineering works on the canals. Before he reached his majority he had charge of the enlargement of the Cayuga and Seneca Canal.

BRIDGEPORT, Ill., Oct. 1.--As a result of the labors of Mormon missionaries in this vicinity, several of the most prominent residents of Lawrence County will leave their old homesteads here Oct. 12 and emigrate to Utah.

As early as 9 o'clock yesterday morning people began to fill up the few seats in the Surrogate's Court. Some of them carried their lunches in newspaper parcels and in other ways signified their intention of staying all day. Two hours later Capt. McIntyre, an officer of the court, routed some of them out to give seats to several ladies.
HAVANA, Oct. 1.--The Cubans Salcedo and Estrada, belonging to the party of Limbano Sanchez, were shot on the 29th ult., at Baracoa.

Several times during the past two weeks a woman giving the name of Miss Annie Bennett registered at the Morton House, at Broadway and Fourteenth-street, for a day at a time. Her conduct about the hotel was above reproach.
RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Oct. 1.--John E. Smith, of Morrisville, Madison County, was nominated for Senator in the Twenty-third District Convention to-day on the first ballot.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 1.--Yesterday the letter carriers of Atlanta were laden with numerous small mail packages addressed to the various children of the city. The documents were copies of the "Faithists' Calendar." The pamphlets were eagerly read by the children, and many of the documents were taken home.
UTICA, Oct. 1.--The Democratic County Convention has nominated the Hon. Abram B. Weaver, ex-State Superintendent of Public Instruction, for Senator in opposition to Henry G. Coggeshall.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 1.--Canon Farrar delivered an address on education to-day at the annual session of Johns Hopkins University. He spoke of the difference in the educational systems of England and America, and accorded to the latter a high praise for its greater approach to perfect education.

It was rumored yesterday that the People's Telephone Company, representing the Drawbaugh claim, was about to apply to Judge Wallace for a rehearing of the Drawbaugh case, had in the United States Circuit Court last October.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 1.--The Republican State Committee have delined to accept Gov. Hoadly's challenge to a joint discussion with Senator Sherman at Dayton on Saturday evening. The declination is made because Gov. Hoadly has declined to meet Judge Foraker in joint debate, and the committee say: "We will not entertain any proposition from Gov. Hoadly to dignify his candidacy for the United States Senatorship by granting a discussion with Senator Sherman."

Others do not forget a very recent past in his history, however much he may flatter himself that it is concealed from view.

Parke, of No. 186 Front-street, is the maker of the costumes and Mrs. Parke, with Miss Cottrelly, is responsible for many of the individual colors and their combination.

It was announced yesterday that the Directors of the Union Pacific and Missouri Pacific Railroads had taken action by which the Missouri Pacific Road leases the Central Branch of the Union Pacific. The lease is for 25 years. The branch runs from Atchison to Edmunds, Kan., and Mr. Gould calls it "naturally" a part of the Missouri Pacific, which has been operating it.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 1.--Last night Lieut. Dodds, late Professor of Military Tactics at Rutgers, left to rejoin his regiment at Fort Russell, Colorado. A score of students cheered him as the train left and then paraded through the principal streets of the town.

PARIS, Oct. 1.--Mlle. Emma Nevada was married to-day to Dr. Raymond Palmer, of Birmingham, England. The civil service took place at the English Embassy and the religious ceremonies at the Church of the Passionist Fathers. The bridesmaids were Misses Morris, Johnston, ...

MONTREAL, Oct. 1.--The Montreal Lacrosse Club, champions of the world, leave this city on Saturday afternoon on a visit to NewYork, Baltimore, and Boston. They will arrive in New-York on Sunday morning, will leave on the following day for Baltimore, and will play the Druids of that place on Wednesday.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 1.--Mrs. William Kountz, residing on Peyton's Creek, Smith County, yesterday cut her throat from ear to ear and died. She leaves seven children, the youngest 3 weeks old. It is thought she was temporarily insane.
President Shelbourne, of the New-York Electric Lines Company, talked to the Electrical Subway Commissioners yesterday about the system adopted by his company for laying electric wires under ground.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1.--The Pennsylvania Railroad officials are denying that they intend to enter the anthracite coal combination in 1886. One of them admitted that the subject might be given consideration at a later day.
Jacob Harloff was arrested at his home on Garden-street, Hoboken, yesterday on a charge of arson. The complainant is Mrs. Hannah Krautze, a tenant in the house.

ELKTON, Md., Oct. 1.--Charles P. Barnes was to-day found guilty of murder in the second degree for the killing on May 30 last of Thomas E. Brown, his brother-in-law, and James A. Barnes, his son. The murder was entirely unprovoked, and talk of lynching was freely indulged in at the time. Barnes elected to be tried before Judges Stump and Robinson, instead of a jury, and they sentenced him to 14 years in the penitentiary.

QUINCY, Ill., Oct. 1.--M.M. Wood, city editor of the Sunday Topic, committed suicide last night by shooting himself with a revolver. Wood was a bright and popular young man of 21 years and a son of wealthy and highly respected parents living in Ellinton, Ill. The cause of the rash deed is not stated.
A general convention of window glass manufacturers was held here Wednesday with Thomas Wightman, of Pittsburg, in the chair.

MONTREAL, Oct. 1.--Another day has passed peacefully and hope grows stronger throughout the city that the trouble over smallpox and the means of combating it may not again take alarming form. New cases are appearing and about 30 have been reported to-day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1.--The Secretary of the Treasury to-day instructed the Collector of Customs at New-York to issue clearance papers to the steamship City of Mexico, plying between that port and Honduras, which vessel has been under surveillance at New-York for several weeks, because of a suspicion that she was being fitted out for a filibustering expedition against Honduras.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 1.--Williams College yesterday was the scene of cane rushes, in doors and out, between the Sophomores and Freshmen.

The Republican County Convention, to nominate county officers to be supported at the coming election, was held at Lafayette Hall, White Plains, yesterday. Ex-Collector William H. Robertson called the convention to order. W.B. Davidson, of Dobbs Ferry, presided.
Tammany Hall held primary elections last night in all the Assembly districts of the city to choose delegates to the County and other local nominating conventions soon to be held.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 1.--Miss Alice B. Jordin, of Coldwater, Mich., a graduate of the Academic and Law Departments of the University of Michigan, entered the Yale Law School to-day. She is the first lady ever entered in any department of Yale outside of the Art School.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 1.--A wreck occurred on the eastern division of the Erie Railroad this morning at about 2:30 o'clock at the Newburg Junction, east of Turners, when train No. 43 ran into train No. 31, demolishing two passenger coaches and a combination coach. Two freight cars were slightly damaged. There were no passengers on train No. 31.

FALL RIVER, Oct. 1.--Silvina Generoux, the youngest of the smallpox patients, died at 4 o'clock this morning in the hospital. City Solicitor Jackson goes to Boston to-night to consult with the Governor as to what precautions can be taken legally to prevent people from Canada coming to this city after exposure to the disease.

The orchids on exhibition at Horticultural Hall, which are being sold for the account of the estate of the late Mrs. Mary J. Morgan, attracted a much larger crowd yesterday than on the first day of the sale.

The Executive Committee of the Grant Monument Association held a meeting at noon yesterday. Five out of 20 members were present. No business was transacted at the meeting, and the committee adjourned without adopting or suggesting any new plans by which the fund might be increased. The fund amounts to $83,028.19.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 1.--The Illinois Live Stock Commission has prepared and laid before the Governor a report setting forth that the State is absolutely and entirely free from pleuro-pueumonia in an acute or contagious form. The Governor is requested to inform the Executives of such States as have quarantined against Illinois, with a view of having the restrictions removed.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 1.--The Georgia State Fair, which will open here on the 26th, promises to be a success. There are $9,000 in cash premiums offered, and one of the features will be a line exhibition of Jersey cattle.

Prof. Cromwell will begin a series of exhibitions at the Grand Opera House next Sunday evening. His first lecture will be devoted to St. Petersburg, Moscow, and Constantinople.

BISMARCK, Dakota, Oct. 1.--Charlie Smith, son of a prominent business man of this city, was lost on the prairie 100 miles north of here several days ago, and when found was on the verge of starvation.

ALBANY, Oct. 1.--State Treasurer Maxwell to-day promoted Major R.G. Milk from the cashier's desk to the position of Deputy Treasurer. Philo H. Backus was transferred from bookkeeper to cashier, and James H. Schooley from check clerk to bookkeeper. Mr. Milk entered the State service in 1869. All these positions were in line of promotion, and not governed by civil service rules.

NEW-BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 1.--An omnibus driven by Charles Dyson, aged 19, in which his two sisters, Minnie and Lottie, aged 13 and 15, were riding was struck by a train this morning. Both the girls were killed, and the boy was so badly injured that he died soon after.

HAWLEY, Penn., Oct. 1.--The Erie and Wyoming Valley Railroad, which is an extension of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad from this place to the middle anthracite coal fields at Pittston, will be opened for regular passenger traffic on Monday next.
William Page, the artist, died on Wednesday at his home near Tottenville, Staten Island. He had been sick for some time. His age was 75 years 8 months and 19 days.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 2.--United States Marshal Freeman and a posse yesterday destroyed an illicit distillery in Henry County, and arrested the owners. Marshal Spurrier arrested Ben Cuff and Andrew Thompkins at Fountain Head for illegally removing whisky. The former gave bail and the latter was committed.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Oct. 2.--Andrew G. Boyd, editor and proprietor of the Free Press of this city, died to-day of pneumonia. He was 61 years of age, and some years ago was connected with the press of Baltimore.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2.--A Justice of the Peace at Niles, Mich., in November, 1877, united in marriage Adrian M. Avery, of South Evanston, Ill., and a young woman of the Michigan town. Six weeks later the wife left her husband and thereafter refused to live with him.

The attendance at the Centennial Convention of the Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New-York was large almost up to the hour of adjournment. It might be that a remark made by Erastus Brooks had something to do with this somewhat unusual condition of things at a convention lasting for more than two days.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 2.--Much interest has been manifested by the public in the trial of Charles A. Bridges, of Copiah County, Miss., for the murder of Charles Anderson, a Cincinnati thief, in a Basin-street bagnic last March. The killing was clearly proved, but the prisoner put in a plea of self-defense.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 2.--The Newburg brokerage firm of Charles R. Callahan Co. announced their suspension this morning, and have transacted no business since. The amount of liabilities, as stated by members of the firm, is $2,500.

Wall-street had another sensation yesterday. Following close in the wake of the suspension of Soutter Co. came the announcement early in the day of the failure of another conspicuous bear house, preceding only by an hour or so the news that one of the biggest bear operators in the market had been pushed to the wall.

ALBANY, Oct. 2.--Palestine Encampment, No. 37, I.O.O.F., of Lynn, Mass., arrived here from Rochester at 6 P.M. They were met at the station by the Albany Patriarchs, and after a brief parade escorted to the Stanwix, where supper was served. To-night they were tendered a reception at Graves's Hall. Col. Henry T. Sanford delivered an address of welcome.

TUCSON, Arizona, Oct. 2.--S.S. Colman arrived this morning and reports that Mike Noonan, a rancher, was killed yesterday by Apaches in his cabin on the east side of the Dragoon Mountains, just north of Middle Pass.

Princess Dolgorouki, the widow of the late Czar, has left Aix-les-Bains, with her family, for Biarritz, where she intends to remain till the beginning of November, when she returns to Paris for the Winter.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2.--The British steamer Coventry, Capt. Bacon, bound from this port to Galveston, sailed to-day with only one able seaman before the mast.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 2.--To-day the dead body of William Sale, suspected of murdering Deputy Sheriff George Johnson, in Crawford County, last week, was found in the creek near the residence of the murdered man's brother. His hat and shoes had been sunk in the creek, his throat cut, and one eye gouged out.
OSWEGO, Oct. 2.--The Democratic Assembly Convention of the Second District, held today, indorsed L. Alexander, the Prohibition candidate.

SOUTHBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 2.--David Vinton, aged 74 years, a farmer living on the outskirts of the town, was killed Wednesday afternoon by a cart stick in the hands of his son David, aged 35 years.

Thomas Hughes, the author of the famous "Tom Brown" stories, was introduced by the Hon. John L. Cadwalader at Association Hall last night as "the friend and honored guest of every American." Mr. Hughes then proceeded to lecture on the ante-bellum poetry of James Russell Lowell to a fairly large and thoroughly sympathetic audience.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 2.--William Edward Mills, colored, dropped dead in the main corridor of the County Jail here this noon. There was a fight in progress among some of the prisoners at the time. Mills was not engaged in it, but was a passive spectator. He suddenly sank to the floor and immediately expired. The man was of a nervous temperament, and it is supposed he was literally scared to death.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2.--A fickle-minded Grand Jury kept Jasper E. Sweet, the printer who shot Dr. Waugh, in suspense from sunrise to sunset to-day, and finally left-him to spend another night in jail. Waugh had attended Sweet's wife, and the printer said the doctor had been too intimate with Mrs. Sweet.
All reasonable men, whether they dislike or admire Mr. Chamberlain's views, must agree that he has developed into a public speaker of the first order.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 2.--Walter G. Smith was found dead in a shed on his father's farm, in Spencerport, to-day, with a revolver by his side and a bullet wound in his head. Smith had been an invalid for some months, and it is supposed that his illness turned his brain. He was a nephew of the late E. Peshine Smith, a former Minister to Japan.

The gloomy weather of yesterday prevented a large attendance in Central Park to witness the match between "The Mikado" eleven and the Musical Social Club. Only one inning was played, the result being in favor of the musicians. Ko-Ko is good at making hits on the stage, but on the cricket field as George Thorne he had no chance, as he was run out.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 2.--The Faculty of Cornell University to-night made awards of the nine scholarships, valued at $200 a year and good for four years, which were contested for last week by over 60 candidates.

BIRMINGHAM, Conn., Oct. 2.--A party which is just finishing a long drive took dinner at a hotel here to-day. It was composed of Mrs. P.V. Kellogg and daughter, of Chicago; Mrs. George Seeley and daughter, of New-York; Mrs. George Ives, of Danbury, Conn., and their attendants.

READING, Penn., Oct. 2.--Robert L. McLean, a son of the late Col. Joseph McLean, of this city, bas been missing since yesterday. He is a married man of exemplary habits, and left home yesterday in an unusually happy mood.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 2.--Edward Brain was convicted of unlawful cohabitation to-day. His latest wife, a Danish girl, testified freely as to their marital relations.

Amid much enthusiasm the Twenty-second Assembly District Republican Club raised a banner in front of its quarters on Thursday night.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2.--President Roberts and General Traffic Manager Wilson, of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, who attended the meeting of trunk line Presidents in NewYork yesterday, state to-day that the meeting was the most harmonious ever held.

MONTREAL, Oct. 2.--Another quiet day has brightened the prospect that the intelligent efforts now at work to stamp out the smallpox will be permitted to go on without further disturbance. Compulsory vaccination is not yet in force, although house-to-house visits have begun.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2.--A number of cigar importers doing business in Chicago to-day forwarded a petition through Collector Seeberger to Secretary Manning asking that the customs stamps may be placed upon their goods in Chicago, with date of arrival here instead of that of New-York.

The scenery at Lake George is now at its loveliest. The foliage--possibly on account of a wet Summer--is more brilliant in color than for years. The clear waters are as placid as glass, reflecting the gorgeousness of the mountains as they only do in October. Most of the hotels are closed, but the Lake House, at Caldwell, will remain open during this month and may be longer.

Many will hear with pleasure that an effort is now being made to restore the ancient church of Foston, near York. The chancel has just been substantially rebuilt at the cost of the Rector, but it is also necessary to restore the nave, for which a minimum sum of 1,000 is required.

An interesting paper was lately read at a meeting of the Saxon Economical Society in Dresden giving an account of the introduction of the potato into Germany and the gradual spread of its cultivation.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 2.--Mrs. Lillie J. Morton, of Kalamazoo, Mich., who was on her way home from Boston, died on a train near here this morning, of consumption. She was the only daughter of J. Winslow Ryers, of Kalamazoo, and was on her way home from Boston, where she had been for treatment.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 2.--Dr. Emma Lee Hudson, who swindled various firms and private individuals in this city, and who was to-day released from Blackwell's Island prison after serving a three months' sentence for similar offenses in New-York, arrived here this evening in charge of Inspector Leggett.

HINGHAM, Mass., Oct. 2.--The Cohasset friends of Capt. Crocker, of the sloop Puritan, visited his residence in that village to-night and congratulated him on his victory over the English cutter Genesta.
ROME, Oct. 2.--The Pope has approved a decree of the Congregation establishing an episcopal see in Nebraska, and the Rev. Dr. O'Connor, the present Vicar Apostolic, has been created Bishop of Omaha.

BALLSTON, N.Y., Oct. 2.--The citizens of Schaghticoke, Rensselaer County, are much excited and surprised at a scandal which has just been made public, involving one of their hitherto most respected citizens.
RALEIGH, Oct. 2.--Robert Perry, a wellto-do citizen of Perquimans County, died a little more than two months ago.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 2.--James Donnelly, of New-York, and Edward Berry, of New-Haven, Conn., fought a desperate four-round prize fight this morning at Beck's Run, about five miles from this city.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 2.--Si King, a negro, who had been pursued for a week by a mob near New-London, Mo., was corraled in a cornfield a few miles from that town last night. He was shot twice, but not seriously injured.

Louis H. Everitt, an actor, better known as "Harry" Everitt, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital, where he had been for some days. Mr. Everitt was born in Philadelphia 51 years ago, and went on the stage at an early age, appearing at the Arch-Street Theatre in that city in 1853.

CHESTER, Penn., Oct. 2.--The Government cruiser Chicago, the heaviest vessel ever built at Roach's ship yard, has settled on the ways to such an extent that workmen have had to shore her up to prevent accident.
JAMESTOWN, Oct. 2.--C.P. Vedder, of Ellicottville, Cattaraugus County, was renominated by the Republicans in the Thirty-second District to-day for State Senator on the eighth ballot.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 2.--A case of smallpox exists in the house of Joseph Melisse, on Charles-street. A quarantine has been established. The several district physicians have commenced to vaccinate persons in their sections, as is customary every three years.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 2.--The failure of Heath Co. and Hudson in New-York considerably affected the oil market to-day. Prices declined and closed rather weak at 100 3/8. A gauge was taken of Thorn Creek to-day.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 2.--Shortly after 3 o'clock this morning a battery of boilers at the Solar Iron Works of Clarke Co., on Thirtysixth-street, exploded with disastrous effect. The night turn had just been relieved by the day force when the explosion occurred, and that portion of the works in the vicinity of the boilers was filled with a cloud of steam.

Post, the young Rector of St. Paul's Church, who has had so much trouble with his congregation during the few months that he has been connected with the church, to-day reconsidered his decision not to resign under any circumstances and placed his resignation in the hands of Biship Scarborough.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2.--The will of the late Mrs. Jane Moriarty, owner of the chop house which had been patronized for so many years by Yale students, has been probated. The estate is valued at $30,000, and is bequeathed to a son and his wife. In case they have no children the property is to go to the New-Haven Orphan Asylum. The immediate heirs are childless.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., Oct. 3.--Douw A. Fonda, the oldest merchant in Fonda, has assigned. His liabilities are about $50,000 and his assets about one-third of that amount. Many farmers from whom he bought hay will lose largely.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 4.--The trial of Mrs. Druse for the murder of her husband closed at Herkimer at 12:30 this morning. The jury brought in a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree. It was the most brutal murder ever known in this part of the State. It is probable that the first person ever hanged in the county will be a woman.

This will be the last week of the present peach season, and although there will be a good supply of small peaches there will be few very nice ones. A Goliath of kites was hung in peaceful repose beneath Harry Hill's grave arbor at Flushing, Long Island, yesterday. For two weeks it had defied all efforts to raise it in the Autumnal breeze, but in all the proud consciousness of an eighteen-foot stature it was attacked by a numerous crowd yesterday. The kite was conspicuous by a patriotic nationalism.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 4.--The delegation to the congress of the Socialistic-Labor Party was welcomed at the Belleville house by the Cincinnati section, Charles Fritz delivering the address and Alexander Johns, of New-York, replying in the name of the delegates. PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 4.--The wage differences between the window glass manufacturers and workmen, which threatened to result in a strike, have been satisfactorily settled and a general resumption of the factories will take place as soon as the furnaces can be put in condition for work. It is understood that the workmen compromised on a 10 per cent. reduction.

Veissel Pasha telegraphs that he has completely defeated the Albanians and captured and promptly hanged the most notable of their leaders. SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 4.--A tornado swept over Northampton this afternoon about 4 o'clock, uprooting a number of magnificent elms in the heart of the city, including the one on King-street, 26 feet in circumference, which Jonathan Edwards planted. MASSOWAH, Oct. 5.--Ras Alula announces a great defeat of the followers of El Mahdi near Amideb. It is now believed that it will not be necessary to relieve Kassala.

MONTREAL, Oct. 5.--The new wing of the old smallpox hospital was finished this afternoon, when a few patients were removed to it. There was no trouble in making the removals, and this evening finds the city as far from disorder as it was yesterday. Few apprehended resistance to what was to be done to-day, the alarmists basing their theories on the chance of disturbance at the opening of the Exposition Buildings for hospital purposes.

BOSTON, Oct. 5.--The Ipswich Woolen Mills, at Ipswich, Mass., were sold at auction today to Charles G. White for $28,500. It is believed that Pierce, Hardy Co., of Boston, are the real purchasers. It is understood that the mills, which employ 150 hands on woolen hosiery, will be reorganized and started at once.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 5.--Mrs. Amelia, a poor widow, who lived and kept a small store at James-street and Concord-alley, committed suicide this morning by hanging herself in the cellar of her house, where her body was found by her son. She leaves six children. A note left by her for her children gave instructions as to the disposal of her property, but gave no reason for her action.
BALLSTON, N.Y., Oct. 6.--The body of an unknown man was found floating to-day in the creek at Hoosick Corners. Foul play is suspected.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5.--The Chicago City Railway Company has sold to H.G. Foreman Brothers and Charles Henrotin $1,000,000 4 per cent. bonds, which are issued by the company against additions and improvements to their property. The bonds run for 20 years, maturing Oct. 1, 1905. The interest is payable April 1 and Oct. 1 each year.

The old New-York volunteer firemen ran with the machine again-yesterday. The historical force engines that have rusted in barns and rotted away in cellars were pulled out to the light, burnished up again, surrounded by fire laddies in red shirts and shovel hats, and led in a lurid and triumphant procession down Broadway.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 5.--The Ambassadors yesterday held a conference on the Roumelian question lasting four hours. The discussion took a wider range than was anticipated and provoked some difference of opinion, which has not yet been settled. This may delay the delivery of the identical note to be addressed to the respective powers and afterward submitted to the Porte.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 5.--Indianapolis, the great trotting stallion of W.H. Wilson, was shipped from Peoria, Ill., and by mistake was brought to Lexington instead of to Cynthiana, arriving here on Saturday. He was led to Cynthiana, a distance of 26 miles. The exposure brought on inflammation, and he died this afternoon.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 5.--The first snow Buffalo has had this Fall fell this morning, and this morning the first frost was seen. The snow came as pioneer to a dreary rainstorm, which set in about 10 o'clock. It fell straight down in little hard lumps, almost like hail.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Oct. 5.--John Durham, a farmer, whose property amounted to $20,000, committed suicide in his barn at Pembroke this morning by hanging himself to a rafter, where his body was found by his wife. He was 70 years old.

READING, Penn., Oct. 5.--The Keystone Iron Works in this city resumed operations today after a continued stoppage of nearly two years. The resumption is due, it is said, to the improvement in the iron trade. The works when running full give employment to 100 hands.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 6.--Returns from 91 Connecticut towns show that there was an unusual number of scratched ballots cast yesterday. Sixteen towns can be fairly called divided, 45 went Republican, and 30 Democratic. The vote was generally light, and in some cases candidates appeared on both tickets. License was one of the main questions, but the number of towns voting against it is not much changed from last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6.--Mr. Joseph E. Hayden, a fourteen-hundred-dollar clerk in the Pension Office, was dismissed to-day " for using gross language toward the Executive of the United States." The offense is alleged to have been committed while he was riding in a carriage on Pennsylvania-avenue, when it is said he even went so far as to wish for the death of the President. Hayden was appointed by President Arthur, but claims to be a Democrat.

KINGSTON, N. Y ., Oct. 6.--A quarrel occurred this morning between William Palmater and A. Yaple, who was at work on Palmater's farm in New-Kingston, Delaware County. READING, Penn., Oct. 6.--The puddlers employed at the Reading Iron Works have quit work on account of the managers refusing to increase their wages 25 cents per ton. The last strike resulted in closing the mill several years.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 13.--Deputy Marshal Hurst, of Fentress County, was shot and killed seven miles northwest of Jamestown, last Sunday morning, by moonshiners hid in ambush. Hurst was in company of Deputy Marshal Pile, and the shot was probably intended for the latter. They had a prisoner in charge whom they had arrested the night before. Pile is constantly in hot water and carries a doublebarreled shot gun and brace of revolvers under all circumstances.

LEETONIA, Ohio, Oct. 13.--Early this morning, while a number of employes were standing within a few feet of the newly built furnace of the Cherry Valley Company, several tons of hot metal, coke, and limestone suddenly burst upon them. Anthony Burse was burned beyond recognition, and Thomas Gibbons, keeper; Joseph Moffett, a helper, and William Woodworth, engineer, were badly injured. The men were all married, and each had a large family.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 13.--Special Policeman Charles Dodson shot and killed a negro named James Ferrell at Columbia this afternoon. Ferrell's brother had been arrested by Dodson, and while on his way to the jail Ferrell came to the rescue. He first struck Dodson with a rock and then cut him with a knife. Then Dodson shot him through the neck, cutting the jugular vein.
