LIMA, Oct. 14. via Galveston.--It is reported that heavy fighting has taken place at Cajamarca between Montoneros and Government troops. Gen. Caceres has endeavored to impose a tax of $12,000 on the Province of Canta, but failed to obtain it.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 14.--The New-Yorks played a game here to-day and met defeat at the hands of the Cincinnati men. The weather was raw and chilly and anything but congenial for outdoor sports. The visitors played a remarkably strong game in the field, but they were beaten by the superior batting of the home team.

Commissioners LOEW, MOSS, and HESS have listened very patiently during the last three months to scores of inventors, including a number of self-betrayed cranks, who think that they can place the electric wires of this city under ground more cheaply and in a more acceptable manner than anybody else,

The politicians who are influential in controlling nominations for the Legislature do not always seem to appreciate the value of good candidates in promoting the general success of the party which they are chosen to represent. They are generally better known and more accurately...
Some of the Democrats in Washington are "surprised," so they say, at the result in Ohio.
ROME, Oct. 14.--A meeting of the personages charged with reviewing the Carolines question and elaborating a Papal decision respecting the matter has been held.
AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 14.--The following dispatch was sent last night:
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 14.--The prospects of a whisky pool were ruined to-day by the course of the Mill Creek Distilling Company of this city.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 14.--The members composing the syndicate which lays claim to property worth $100,000,000, consisting of a portion of the Harlem flats, in New-York City, met at the Home Hotel, in this city,

The weather having cleared up yesterday, the Grant Monument fund began to go ahead once more is a steady manner. The subscriptions were not large, but they came from various places, some of which have not been heard from to any extent heretofore.

LOUISVILLE, K. Oct. 14.--Gen. William Howard Irwin, who was an officer in the Mexican war and was on Gen. W.S. Hancock's staff during the civil war, has become hopelessly insane, and this morning he was ordered to be...

Capt. Ambrose Snow, A.B. Miller, F.B. Thurber, H.K. Miller, Waldo Smith, and James H. Seymour were prominent among those who took part yesterday in the meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation.
MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 14.--The Mobile Jockey Club was organized to-day, with D.E. Huger as President.
Mayor Haynes, of Newark, had a clear majority over both the Republican candidate and the Prohibition candidate for Mayor at the Newark charter election on Tuesday last.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14.--A dispatch was received here to-day from Maurice Vignaux, the billiard player, who is now in New-York, saying that his wife was ill in that city, and, as he could not leave her, he would have to do part of his practicing there.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14.--A report of the operations of the Special Delivery Department of the Chicago Post Office for the last 10 days shows that the 98 messengers delivered 2,369 letters which had arrived through the mails and 378 local letters deposited for delivery.
The Bostons played against 10 men yesterday in Brooklyn, and were of course, defeated.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 14.--The official figures of yesterday's elections are as follows: Mayor--Denny, (Rep.,) 9,093; Cottrell, (Dem.,) 9,0 93. Clerk-Brewning, (Rep.,) 9,089; Shields, (Dem.,) 9,202. The Prohibition vote was 147, and the Greenback vote 37. The Republicans have one majority in the Council. The Board of Aldermen is evenly divided.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 14.--A singular and surprising coincidence was noticeable on Lake Erie yesterday.
CORK, Oct. 14.--The Loyalists have forwarded a number of thrashing machines to boycotted farmers, and arranged to purchase boycotted cattle for shipment to England.
Marriage and death are rarely so closely associated as in the sad case set forth in the following announcements published in yesterday's papers:
Congratulatory dispatches over the resuit of the Ohio election fell thick and fast in the Republican headquarters at the Gilsey House yesterday.
DETROIT, Mich, Oct. 14.--There was an affecting scene in the Probate Court yesterday. Two of the venerable members of the bar, Judges Hand and Goodwin, entered arm-inarm.

TOLEDO, Oct. 14.--Complete returns from all precincts in Lucas County, in which Toledo is situated, show some changes from the first estimates. Practically official results show that Foraker has carried the county by 82 plurality,
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 14.--The most fashionable of the Autumn weddings occurred at the First Presbyterian Church this afternoon, when Miss Fannie Fuller Cook,....

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 14.--Mr. Eugene Burlingame called on Gov. Hill this morning on behalf of the committee appointed by the County Board of Supervisors and asked for the removal of Superintendent of the Poor Philip Niver for misconduct and malversation in office.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 14.--There are a great many surprised men in Ohio to-day, Republicans as well as Democrats.

CALCUTTA, Oct. 14.--King Theebaw of Burmah has answered the communication sent by the Chief Commissioner for British Burmah in accordance with instructions from the Indian Government with reference to the dispute between...

A handsome Russia leather album, artistically engrossed with a set of resolutions of esteem, was presented to ex-Fire Commissioner Cornelius Van Cott by a number of his friends in the New-York Hotel last evening.

The above cuts give a fac simile of the certificate of stock, and the indorsements on its back, that was originally issued by the Elmira Gazette Company to Edward L. Patrick, and for which he paid with the proceeds of a cheek for $10,000, signed by William M. Tweed.

John Veith and John H. Miller are both veterans of the One Hundred and Third Regiment of New-York Volunteers. The first John is a prosperous saloon keeper at No. 295 East Third-street and holds office in eight different German societies.
Mr. Harrigan has a new piece nearly ready, but "Old Lavender" is still drawing crowds at the Park Theatre.
NYACK, Oct. 15.--The prospects for electing a Republican State Senator from this (Twelfth) Senatorial district in the place of Henry C. Nelson are very flattering.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15.--Just as day was breaking this morning old Peter Daran, the watchman at Commodore Kittson's Erdenheim stock farm, near Chestnut Hill, saw a tongue of flame leap from the roof of a stable used for brood mares, about 500 yards south of the main stables.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 15.--The marriage of Miss Mary Chaffee Wells, daughter of Calvin Wells, the proprietor of the Philadelphia Press and millionaire iron manufacturer of this city,

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 15.--The schooner Co. Y. Gregory, lumber laden, which arrived here to-day, reports that on the morning of Oct. 14, when she was 18 miles southeast of Cape Ann, she was run into during a thick fog by the steamer Dominion, from Boston, for Yarmouth, Nova Scotia.
Mme. Judic is not seen to as much advantage in "Le Grand Casimir"--which was represented at Wallack's Theatre yesterday evening--as in the other pieces of her repertoire.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15.--There was yesterday received at the Navy Department from the Secretary of State a document which was marked in such a manner as to attract the attention of every official in the Navy Department who had an opportunity to see it.

Pastor Elsing and the Trustees of the De Witt Memorial Church, No. 280 Rivingtonstreet, last night began a series of entertainments for the working people of the district, which they propose to continue every Thursday night during the Fall and Winter.
The County Democrats of the Fifth Senatorial District last night nominated Michael C. Murphy for State Senator.
A prominent member of the Tammany Hall organization is quoted as saying, after the nominations had been made yesterday: "If the Republicans can poll ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15.--Dissensions have sprung up among the Tennessee delegation, growing out of the contest over the Postmastership of Jackson. This Post Office is of the Presidential grade, and is regarded as the most important in Representative Taylor's district.

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 15.--John B. Holbrook, one of three or four men who have a contract for some Government work on the river near Captina, 20 miles below this city, drew $7,200 from the United States Sub-Treasury in Cincinnati about Sept. 30.

During his recent visit to the Provinces Secretary of State Thompson found in the council chamber of the Governor of Nova Scotia three volumes of letters of Gov. Wentworth, covering his entire administration as Governor of the Province of New-Hampshire, with the exception of one year.

With very praiseworthy punctuality the Zingari were on the Staten Island Cricket Club's ground yesterday at 11 o'clock to play the cricket match with a team of the Staten Island Club, under the captainship of Harry Lambkin.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15.--The second day of the Maryland Jockey Club races was a greater success than the first. The day was lowering and threatening, but the attendance reached fully up to 2,500, with a much larger number of ladies.
COLUMBUS, Oct. 15.--John R. McLean arrived from Cincinnati this afternoon and has been closely engaged with the Democratic managers since his arrival.
HAVANA, Oct. 15.--Messrs. Brown Co., one of the most important houses in the island, closed up business on the 5th inst. Their action caused great surprise.

JOHNSTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 15.--Ella Marple, a farmer's pretty daughter, residing near Johnstown, recently eloped with John Blanchard, a farm hand, who deserted his wife and eight children. Eila took $400 belonging to her father. The pair have been captured and now languish in the Johnstown Jail charged with grand larceny. Marple is rice, but will not relent, and says he will cast the girl off.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15--Lieut. Frank E. Sawyer, having finished his examination for promotion, has been ordered to rejoin the Swatara at New-York; Ensign John T. Newton, having completed his examination for promotion, has been ordered to rejoin the ...

The dredging machinery of the Senate investigating committee struck a snag yesterday when it attempted to reach the surface with the inside history of ex-Controller Seth Hastings Grant's personal and official relations with Ferdinand Ward.
CHICAGO, Oct. 15.--Austin J. Doyle, Superintendent of Police, resigned to-day to become Superintendent of the new street railway company which is to operate in the west division.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15.--The Land Office has received a communication stating that Dr. Powers, who was a Government witness in the prosecution of a fraudulent land case in California, has been killed by J.F. Pruett, one of the defendants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15.--Assistant Secretary Coon has been put to some annoyance today by the inquiries of officeholders and correspondents who went to him to find out whether the report was true that Secretary Manninghan, demanded his resignation because he had expressed an opinion as to the probable effect of the Ohio election on the contest in New-York ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15.--In a dispatch to the State Department, dated Sept. 7, the dragoman of the United States Legation at Teheran gives the substance of a recent conversation with the Persian Minister of Foreign Affairs, in which his Excellency asked whether the Americans ...
LONDON, Oct. 15.--It is understood that the sentence of death passed on Louis Riel, the leader of the half breed rebellion in Canada, will be commuted to life-long servitude.
LONDON, Oct. 15.--The trouble between Burmah and the Government of India will probably lead to the annexation of Burmah to India. The matter was seriously discussed at the Indian Office to-day.
BLACKFOOT, Idaho, Oct. 15.--The United States District Court, Justice Noyes presiding, is in session here now and a large number of cases of polygamy are on trial.

The tenth semi-annual meeting of the Association of American Railroad Superintendents was held yesterday at No. 46 Bond-street. President W.H. Stevenson, of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Road, was in the chair, and nearly 40 members were present at some time during the day.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 15.--Gen. Nelson A. Miles, who is in this city, received a telegram yesterday from Lieut. Henry T. Allen, of the Second Cavalry, stating that he had arrived safely in San Francisco after his Alaska explorations, having completed a journey through the ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 15.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Pullman Palace Car Company was held here to-day. Out of a total of 159,000 shares 118,112 were represented. All the old Directors were re-elected.

Under water, in the Lower Bay, a mile and a quarter below Fort Lafayette, there is a shell composed of 100 pounds of explosive gelatine, a few pounds of dynamite, which serves as a core for the gelatine, a copper case, 3 feet and 4 inches long and 7 inches in diameter, a conical iron point, and a wooden "tailpiece."

As Winter approaches the ladies seek for new fur cloaks, sacques, and wraps, and nowhere can they find a more abundant and choice stock than at the new store of Mr. Kahn, No. 56 West Twenty-third-street.

An amusing incident occurred in Butler on Thursday morning, Oct, 1. At the hour of 1 o'clock A.M. every bell in town begun to peal forth its solemn sound, and many persons, not aware of the intention of the ringing of the bells, began to run and halloo "fire!"

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15.--Postmaster Bearson's long talk with Postmaster-General Vilas yesterday afternoon was of service to both those gentlemen in helping each to better appreciate the efforts that the other is making in his official capacity to secure an improved public service.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 15.--Francis Brown committed suicide last night by shooting him self through the head in front of the Custom House. Brown's parents were natives of Switzerland, who accumulated a fortune here in the saloon business. They returned to Paris about eight years ago, where the mother killed her husband and then poisoned herself. Brown had been on a spree.
OTTAWA, Oct. 15.--In 1882 J. Levecque, a native of this city, was sentenced to death for the murder of a man named Legault at Winnipeg.

QUINCY, Ill., Oct. 15.--Public announcement was made to-day that Henry R. Corley, late Secretary of the Quincy Gas Company, was short in his accounts from $15,000 to $20,000. He resigned his position by request the 1st of September, and is now connected with the Kansas City Gas Company.

ROME, Oct. 15.--The Italian Government has received advices confirming the report of the death of Osman Digna. Four hundred Abyssinians who were wounded in the recent fight with Osman's followers are camped at Ahmara. The march of the Abyssinians to Kassala has been checked.

MONTREAL, Oct. 15.--Judge Taschereau gave judgment this morning in the Practice Court on the petition of Mr. A.W. Atwater, acting on behalf of the Citizens' Committee, asking for a writ of mandamus against Police Magistrate Dugas to compel him to punish offenders under the act constituting the Central Board of Health, which was yesterday declared by the court to be legal and constitutional.

The dollars continue to pour steadily into the treasury of the Grant Monument Association. That they do not pour at present with greater abundance does not disconcert the more conservative members of the committee, for on every hand there are evidences of a willingness to contribute toward the fund, which it is believed will bear rich fruit in the future.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 15.--Canon Farrar's lecture on Robert Browning was listened to by a large and brilliant audience to-night in this city.

A warrant for the arrest of Miss A.R. Stevens, a teacher in Public School No. 5, Brooklyn, was yesterday issued by Justice Walsh on the complaint of Henry Johnson, one of her pupils, who charges her with assaulting him.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 15.--Gov. Hoadly to-day appointed Gen. John Beatty, of Columbus, a member of the Board of State Charities in the place of the Hon. Joseph Perkins, ot Cleveland, deceased. The law required the appointment of a Republican member.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 15.--A meeting of the Democratic State Commitee was held here today and the chances of Fitz Hugh Lee's election as Governor were discussed with much hopefulness. Democrats from some of the doubtful districts were present to ask for financial aid.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 15.--The attendance at Latonia to-day was very good. The weather was moderately warm and very pleasant, and the track stiff.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 15.--The race between Hanlan and Lee and Courtney and Conley was rowed this afternoon. The contestants were ready for the start shortly after 4 o'clock.

VALPARAISO, Oct. 15, via Galveston.-- Gold medals will be forwarded through their respective legations to officers of different nations who fought with the Chilian Army in its campaigns against Peru and Bolivia. Among the recipients of this honor are Capt. Auchand, of the British Army, and Capt. Malen, of the United States Navy.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 15.--The game between the Browns and Chicago here to-day broke up in a row in the ninth inning. Sullivan's umpiring was very unsatisfactory to the home club, he making several very bad decisions against them.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 15.--The election returns to THE TIMES last night need but slight correction--so slight indeed that they may be passed in view of the alarming developments of the day.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 15.--In Connecticut there has never been a final legal decision as to the liability of railroad companies in case of accident to passengers riding on free passes.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 15.--The Hon. Jeremiah Gatchell, Savings Bank Commissioner of Massachusetts, has been appointed a National Bank Examiner. His location has not been specified, and it cannot therefore be said that he will have the place of either of the Examiners now stationed in Massachusetts. Mr. Gatchell is a Democrat.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 15.--Crop reports to the Times show that in Washington County potatoes would average well with last year or former years were it not that they are rotting badly.

The Young Men's Institute, Nos. 222 and 224 Bowery, designed to afford opportunities for physical and mental development, social recreation, and special industrial instruction to young men of moderate means, was opened last evening.

The eleventh annual examination of the Nautical School of the Port of New-York was held yesterday afternoon on the school ship St. Mary's, which lay at anchor off the foot of East Twenty-third-street.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 15.--The Brassfield horse sale was concluded to-day. The best sales were Wick, bay gelding, 6 years, record 2:26 , by Justin, sold to Morgan J.W. Graham, Ohio, for $430; Rachel Wilkes's bay filly, 2 years, ...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 15.--The Internal Revenue authorities are endeavoring to secure evidence that will lead to the arrest and conviction of the moonshiners who murdered Deputy United States Marshal Hurst in Fentress County last Sunday.

Yesterday was the last day for the presentation of plans to the Electrical Subway Commission, and the rooms looked like a nomination convention, so closely packed were the inventors and lawyers, all jostling each other in their anxiety to get their own particular system before the Commissioners.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15.--Daniel O'Leary, the pedestrian, arrived here to-day. He is going to walk a mile in a skating rink to-morrow night while a man named Frank Gorman skates two miles.
MITCHELL, Dakota, Oct. 15.--The Territorial Democratic Central Committee was in session here yesterday and remained in consultation with leading members of the party until midnight.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 15.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, Hon. William C. Ruger, Chief Justice, and associates present, the following causes were argued:
The American Association and the National League begin their joint convention at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel at 10 o'clock this morning.

From his comfortable quarters in Ludlow-Street Jail FERDINAND WARD is sending out, ostensibly for the enlightenment of the public, long and carefully prepared statements in which he undertakes to show that his associates and those who did business with him were rascals, while he is suffering for having filled their pockets with money.

Andrew Werner, 74 years of age, a native of Mannedorf, Canton of Zurich, Switzerland, was found dead in his bed in a sleeping room on the third floor of No. 287 Bowery, last evening. Werner had lived alone in the room for two months.

Bad health has prompted E.S. Bowen, Vice President of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, to retire from active business, and the Erie Directors accepted his resignation yesterday after adopting resolutions of regret.

At a meeting of the Democratic General Committee of Kings County held last night at Jefferson Hall, Brooklyn, it was resolved to hold primary elections in the odd numbered wards of Kings County on Friday, Oct. 23--in wards that have 800 or more members, from 1 to 10 P. M.; wards of 800 or less, from 4 to 10 P.M.--for the purpose of nominating Supervisors.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 15--The Cornell University Baseball Club added another victory to their unbroken record by defeating the Syracuse Stare here to-day by a score of 8 to 5. As the Stars recently captured the New-York State League pennant, everybody here thought that they would beat the home team.
MARINETTE, Wis., Oct. 15.--Every sawmill at the mouth of the Menominee River is closed to-day, and at least 3,000 laborers are out of employment.
LONDON, Oct. 15.--Lord Salisbury declared at Brighton to-day that the French Government had disavowed the action of the French Consul in Burmah.
The Democrats of Westchester County held their County Convention in Lafayette Hall, White Plains, yesterday. Eugene B. Travis, of Cortlandt, was Chairman.
The Autumn race meeting of the Country Club of Westchester County was successfully inaugurated yesterday on the beautiful grounds of the association at Bartow-on-theSound, Pelham.
Patrick McCarthy, a Montreal merchant, was yesterday arrested by Officer Day, of the Sixth Police Precinct, and taken to the Tombs Police Court, suffering from insanity.
We must once more ask the forbearance of the Elmira Gazette for a publication which brings to the broad light of day the personal and political secrets of its early history.
The 1,300 anti-civil service delegates to the Tammany County Convention all had printed handbills ridiculing the civil service law when they entered Tammany Hall yesterday afternoon.

The body of Cardinal John McCloskey, robed in the vestments of sacred office and surrounded by all the impressive solemnity of Roman Catholic caremonial, was laid to rest yesterday in the vault beneath the altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
A sharp-featured German woman named Johanna Lessmann, attired in widow's weeds, is on trial before Judge Barrett, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, on an indictment for murder in the first degree.

Much excitement was caused on the floors of the Stock Exchange yesterday by a long series of resolutions from the Governing Committee announcing their intention to recommend sweeping changes in the duties and salaries of the Exchange's officers.

Officer Dixon, of the Tombs Police Court squad, took a female prisoner through Baxter-street yesterday, and as he was in citizen's dress he was accosted by nearly every clothing dealer along the sidewalk.

Frank Webb, of No. 121 West Twentyninth-street, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday on a charge of sending through the mails circulars offering for sale counterfeit money of the denominations of ones, twos, and fives in bills.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14.--The results of the Methodist Conference recently held at Elgin were to change the Pastors of 13 of the 22 Methodist churches in Chicago.

ALBION, N.Y., Oct. 15.--After a protracted deadlock, which it required 120 ballots to open, Samuel A. Bates, of Kendall, was nominated for member of Assembly by the Republicans in Orleans County at 4 o'clock this morning.
CHICAGO, Oct. 15.--The general Freight Agents of the roads forming the California Fast Freight Line held a meeting yesterday to decide upon a plan for running the line hereafter.

Some interesting testimony was given yesterday in the course of the trial of the suit of Mary Maud Watson against Messrs. Campbell Phyfe, by ex-State Senator Abner C. Mattoon, of Oswego, who was called to support the theory of Mrs. Watson, that her grandfather, Millionaire John Anderson, was not of sound ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15--In the Supreme Court of the United States to-day the following business was transacted: No. 722--John M. Stone et al., Railroad Commissioner, , appellants, vs. The Farmers' Loan and Trust Company:

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 15.--The Baltimore Manufacturers' Record will publish to-morrow its quarterly review of the Southern industrial growth, giving the name, location, and character of business of all new mining and manufacturing enterprises organized in the 14 Southern ...

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Oct. 15.--A sale of Clydesdale stock was held at the Rockford Farm yesterday. The sales numbered 62, aggregating $22,000. The highest price paid for a single animal was $1,355 for Queen of Quality, purchased by a citizen of Centreville, Iowa. Nancy Lee brought $1,155. The other sales ranged from $75 to $900 per head.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 15.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Nevada Bank, of San Francisco, was held here this afternoon. The old Board of Directors were reelected. The net earnings for the past year were reported to be $504,000. A dividend of 10 per cent. was declared.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15.--Sinewy young men in white flannels and neat striped caps were fighting for the glory of their respective colleges in the Intercallegiate Tennis Tournament on the New-Haven Club's grounds today, and scores of pretty girls were beaming upon them.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15.--It is stated here to-day that the Reading Railroad Reorganization Trustees will be antagonized by all the junior holders and the leased lines, and that this makes it absolutely impossible for the Trustees to reach a plan of reorganization and that foreclosure is inevitable.
CHICAGO, Oct. 15.--Landlady Laura E. Skells, who keeps a boarding house on West Madison-street, tells an odd sort of story in the Circuit Court, where she is suing to have a mortgage set aside.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 15.--Halil Bey, Turkish Envoy, telegraphs to the Porte from Nissa that he is satisfied with the explanations of M. Garachnine, the Servian Premier, in regard to Servia's armaments. It is reported that M. Garachnine stated that Servia meant to attack Bulgaria.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 15.--While at the Vanderbilt House here to-day Gen. H.W. Slocum was called upon by many of his Democratic friends, who sought his views on the elect of the Ohio election on that in New-York State. Gen. Slocum said that the result of the Ohio election was something of a surprise to him, but ...

PALERMO, Oct. 15.--A heavy shock of earthquake was felt here this morning. The disturbance caused a three-story house to fall, burying its occupants beneath the debris. Eight corpses have been recovered from the ruins.
CHICAGO, Oct. 15.--Small fry office seekers were much distressed to-day to learn that Collector Seeberger had received some letters from the Civil Service Commission of an interesting character.

Warnings continue to reach the Republican State Committee concerning the probability of attempts at illegal voting on the part of the thousands of laborers employed on the new aqueduct by Contractor John O'Brien, who is also Chairman of the Democratic State Committee.

ROCHESTER,, N.Y., Oct. 15.--The Executive Board of this city was served to-day with an injunction restraining the city from drawing water from Hemlock Lake, the sole source of supply. Judgment was appealed from and affirmed ...
BENNINGTON, Vt., Oct. 15.--The Troy and Boston Railroad bridge at State Line, near North Hoosic, N.Y., was burned to-day. It is supposed the fire was caused by a spark from an engine.

At the meeting of the Academy of Medicine lastevening Dr. Stephen Smith read a paper on the modern changes and improvements --mostly due to a heightened appreciation of antiseptics--in the surgical operations at Bellevue Hospital.
NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Oct. 15.--This afternoon Herbert J. Aldrich was killed and William Chapman probably fatally injured by falling from the roof of the new French Catholic church.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 15.--Several weeks ago a large cat was locked up in the cellar of a dry goods store, and has since refused to be released from its dark abode.

There were great times in the home of Matsada Sorakichi, the Japanese wrestler, at No. 216 West Thirteenth-street, on Wednesday night. Ellen Porter, of No. 207 West Thirteenthstreet, does Mrs. Sorakichi's washing.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15.--The Neww-York grouts won a splendidly contested game here today from the Cincinnati nine. There was a large attendance, and the spectators Gave evidence of their appreciation by vigorously applauding the players.

A candle which had been left burning in memory of a deceased member on the altar in the synagogue of the Jewish society Love of Israel, on the second floor of No. 48 Ludlowstreet, fell over yesterday afternoon and set fire to the coverings of the altar.

The letter in which Mr. HILL has finally announced his acceptance of the nomination of the Democratic Convention is more smoothly written and better arranged than the documents hitherto written by him; but whatever aid he has had in its preparation has not saved it from being, on the whole, a feeble attempt to cover up his own weakness and borrow the strength of others.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 15.--During the past two weeks the question of the improper selection of petit juries, because of the failure to include colored citizens in the jury lists, has been twice raised, and to-day the Executive Committee appointed by the colored State Convention last year has issued a call for a State Convention to demand civil rights under the law.

LONDON, Oct. 15.--The race for the Champion Stakes at Newmarket to-day wrs won by Capt. C. Bowling's 3-year-old b.c. Paradox. The Duke of Westminster's 4-year-old b.c. Duke of Richmond (late Bushey) came in second, and Baron de Rothschild's 3-year-old ch.f. Avelino third.
The game at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon was an exasperating exhibition for the spectators mho lad paid to seen game of ball.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15.--The respondents in the South Pennsylvania Railroad injunction hearing began the taking of testimony to-day. President Roberts, of the Pennsylvania Railroad, gave some additional details of the Merion conference and the meeting at Saratoga.
AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 15.--Sheriff Kendall, of Greeley, Col., assisted by local officers, to-day arrested Scott Ellis at Aurora, 17 miles from this city.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 15.--A large mass meeting, representing the Faculty, Alumni, and students of Cornell University, was held here to-night in Journal Hall for the purpose of extending to Governor-elect Foraker, of Ohio, a member of the first class that graduated from the institution, the congratulations of Cornellians.

Patrolman James Quinn, of the Thirtieth Precinct, was called before President French, at Police Headquarters, yesterday for trial on complaint of J.H. Drennan, who is the night manager of the American District Telegraph once at No. 105 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15.--It is not many months ago that Senator Eustis, of Louisiana, lifted himself into public prominence by roundly berating President Cleveland because certain persons of Louisiana recommended for appointment had been set aside for other persons indorsed by Senator Gibson and who appeared to ...

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 15.--The jury in the case of Mironowitch and his supposed accomplice, Bezak, charged with the murder of a Jewish girl named Sarah Becker, to-day brought in a verdict of not guilty.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 15.--A very fashionable wedding in high circles took place at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church here to-day.

Cammeyer Co. have added an entire new building to their already large store at Twelfth-street and Sixth-avenue, and their premises now cover three lots; an increase which speaks for itself. The display in their broad front of windows is extensive enough, and their custom seems to call tor all the supply.

The report just received at the Navy Department from Commander B.F. DAY on the performances of the Mohican during her first cruise, from San Francisco to Panama, at which latter point she is now lying, forms a good supplement to the recent report of the Board of Investigation of which Capt. IRWIN was President.
CHICAGO, Oct. 15.--The Rock Island, Davenport, and Moline pool, which has been in operation for about 18 months, was reorganized here to-day.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 15.--In the Connecticut Supreme Court to-day, the appeal of Putnam, Earle Co., of New-York, from the Hartford County Superior Court wss withdrawn.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 15.--The following letters of acceptance of Gov. David B. Hill, and Gen. E.F. Jones, Democratic candidate for Lieutenant-Governor, were made public to-day:

STAUNTON, Va., Oct. 15.--William M. Brown, a prominent citizen of this county, was shot and killed in the rotunda of the fair grounds to-day by Stuart Koiner. Intense excitement prevails. The killing is regarded as dastardly.

The weather in the early part of the day was cloudy and lowering, but brightened up when the warning bell of the first race rang at Brighton Beach yesterday, and the large crowd in attendance had a thoroughly good day's enjoyment.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--Leave of absence until Dec. 31, 1885, has, on account of ill health, been granted Cadet Robert L. Howze, second class, Military Academy.
LONDON, Oct. 17.--Mr. A. Sullivan declines to seek a re-election to the House of Commons.
The Brooklyn Athenaeum was crowded to the doors last night when the Democratic City Convention was called to order by Chairman Adams, of the Democratic General Committee.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Oct. 16.--The motion and reasons for a new trial in the case of John Laporte, son of Judge Laporte, of this county, who was found guilty of murder in the second degree two weeks ago, came up before Judge Furst at a session of argument court today.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, N.Y., Oct. 16.-- For the past two years Prof. S.F. Baird, United States Fish Commissioner, has been planting salmon fry in the tributaries of the Hudson in Warren and neighboring counties of Northern New-York.

A mass meeting, under the auspices of the Equality Asssociation, was held last evening at Clarendon Hall for the purpose of protesting against the manner in which the police authorities treated Norton and Fitzgerald, the dry goods clerks who were accused or having caused the dynamite explosions at Garry Brothers' store last February.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 16.--A general meeting of vessel owners and Captains of the National Association was held here this morning for the purpose of fixing a rate for carrying coal and the date on which the same shall go into effect. Some 75 gentlemen were present.

Mr. William G. Barney, 63 years old, of No. 47 East Twenty-first-street, who is connected with the dry goods firm of Tefft, Weller Co., left the store, No. 328 Broadway, at 6 o'clock on Thursday evening and boarded a Broadway car going up town.

READING, Penn., Oct. 16.--Two drunken men named Herb and Mutter terrorized the passengers on the Colebrookdale Railroad last evening by jostling them, using indecent language, and making a brutal attack on Conductor Lord, who was assaulted and held in the corner of the car with threats against his life.

When a man sets out to replenish the stock of clothing for himself and boys, his footsteps naturally turn to the old stand at the corner of Canal-street and Broadway, which for 17 years has been the headquarters of the readymade clothing trade of the city.
Policeman Edward Wicks, while patrolling Congress-street, Brooklyn, on Thursday night, saw a young woman lying in the gutter in an unconscious state.

Mr. Lawson N. Fuller continues his bitter warfare on the predatory goat, and announces his intention of so doing until there is not a tin-can ester to be found from King's Brides to Fifty-ninth-street.

LONDON, Oct. 16.--This was the last day of the second October meeting at Newmarket. The race for the Prendergast Stakes for 2-yearolds was won by Lord Rosebery's b.c. Koster, with Mr. Mainley's blk. or br. c. St. George second, and Lord Cadogan's b.f. Sagitta third.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--A German Democrat from Ohio, a merchant visiting this city, was interviewed to-day by a reporter of the Star, and gave some reasons for Hoadly's defeat that will sound very nice in New-York after election, when Mr. Hill's defeat has to be accounted for.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 16.--To-day's playing in the intercolligeate tennis tournament was the best ever seen in New-Haven, and the sets were closely and hotly contested. The number of spectators was larger than yesterday.
Baseball managers and baseball authorities swarmed about the pillars of the FifthAvenue Hotel yesterday.

The contributions to the Grant memorial fund continues to come in to the Monument Association, and if they come in slowly it should be remembered that the amounts reported from day to day are not to be regarded as indicative of the interest taken in the movement.
The people of Cincinnati are greatly excited over the frauds upon the ballot box which were committed at the election in that city on Tuesday.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 16.--The Evening Record having made a statement that Gen. Butler declined to run for Vice-President in 1864, not because he thought the duties of the position thankless, but because he did not ...

BUFFALO, Oct. 16.--The commission to take testimony in the case of the Rev. Dr. George H. Ball against the Boston Herald for libel issued to Walter S. Jenkins by the Massachusetts court, has been in progress in this city for the past two weeks.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 16.--Mr. William R. Travers, of New-York, who came to Baltimore at the beginning of the week for the Pimlico race meeting, is confined to his bed with an attack of throat trouble at the Hotel Rennert.

The Thalia Theatre was crowded to suffocation last evening on the occasion of the first appearance in this country of Herr Ferdinand Wachtel, son or the well remembered tenor, and an artist who is understood to have won a fair measure of favor from German audiences abroad.

The Executive Committee of the NewYork County Democracy met last night at No. 1 Union-square. The Chairman, Fire Commissioner Henry D. Purroy, in opening the meeting, said that the committee had met to inaugurate a short and bitter local campaign.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 16.--The Cornell University nine administered another defeat this afternoon to the Syracuse Stars, by a score of 7 to 5. The game was the finest ever played in Ithaca, and was witnessed by one of the largest crowds that has gathered on the Cornell campus.
The problem of cheeking intemperance in a society like ours is one of the most difficult ever forced on a legislator.

LONDON, Oct. 16.--The Marquis of Ripon, late Governor-General of India, delivered an address this evening, in the course of which he said that if war with Burmah was the best way to depose King Theebaw, who was a cantankerous devil, he (the Marquis) was opposed to annexing Burmah to India, as such a course would frighten the other Indian Princes.

BOSTON, Oct. 16.--At the South Boston Iron Works this afternoon the casting of a 54-ton 12-inch breech-loading rifle gun for the Government occurred in the presence of a large number of persons, among whom were Lieut. Borup, Superintendent of Ordnance, and Lieut.-Commander Lyon, United ...
Gen. Alexander Shaler, of the Board of Health, tried in vain yesterday to induce the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to make several transfers of money for the use of the Health Department.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 16.--Congress having failed to provide funds for the payment of the Custom House employes in this city for the month of June last, Messrs. Kidder, Peabody Co. have consented to advance the money for that purpose, taking the chance of reimbursement from the Government at some future time. The pay roll for June was $30,000.

Within the past day or two it has become evident that the projectors of a horse railroad through Fifth-avenue are to meet with a determined opposition from influential citizens of New-York, not only of those who own property ...

TROY, Oct. 16.--The firm of Wilbur, Krum Wilbur--composed of Harvey Wilbur, Franklin Krum, Jr., and George W. Wilbur--collar and cuff manufacturers, doing business in this city, has made a general assignment for the benefit of its creditors to Frank B. Twining.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--The New-Yorks met a defeat here to-day in a game in which the umpire was an important factor. The visitors outbatted and outfielded the victorious nine, but they were handicapped by the poor work of Umpire Holland.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 16.--The foreclosure sale of the Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad took place to-day. The property was put up in four lots: Steam canal boats; 187 shares of the stock of the East Buffalo Terminal ...

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 16.--The damage caused by the burning of the Troy and Bennington Railroad bridge at North Hoosic, yesterday, will reach $12,000. The bodies of Robert Burke and James Wardell, who were crushed by the bridge spans falling on them, were almost entirely consumed.
The litigation over the administration of the estates of the late Francis B. Cutting and Heyward Cutting was before Surrogate Rollins in seven different forms yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16.--Annie E. Cutler, the young colored woman who pleaded guilty in May last to shooting and killing her lover, William H. Knight, a colored waiter, on April 22, was sentenced this afternoon by Judge Mitchell to be hanged.

DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 16.--Dr. Aaron Greer, the principal actor in the Osgood tragedy, which occurred on the night of June 11 last, escaped from jail at Greenville this evening at 7 o'clock. His wife called at the jail shortly after supper, and asked to see her husband.

NYACK, Oct. 16.--The Republicans of this place are getting ready for active work in the campaign. A large and attractive room has been secured on Main-street for a clubroom, and tomorrow evening a rousing meeting is to be held there, at which time the Young Men's Republican Club will be thoroughly reorganized.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 16.--Diphtheria is prevalent in some parts of this city, particularly in the First Ward. Quite a number of cases have been reported to the Health Officer during the past week. The disease was brought here by a woman who came from Dutchess County.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 16.--The attorneys of Thomas Cottrell to-day filed a petition in the Circuit Court on application for a recount of the ballots cast at the municipal election on Tuesday, when Cottrell was defeated for Mayor by 60 votes. Fraud is not charged, but it is claimed that mistakes were made in computing the number of votes cast.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 16.--It has just leaked out that Miss Stella Woods, a young heiress of 15, was secretly married a few days ago to William A. Phillips, a glass blower, dependent for his livelihood on his weekly earnings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--In the Supreme Court of the United States to-day the following business was transacted: No. 1,117--Three trunks, containing 718 dozen kid gloves, , Sampson Levy, claimant, plaintiff in error, vs. the United States.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 16.--A special to the Pioneer Press from Aitken, Minn., says: "Five cars loaded with wheat were ditched on the Northern Pacific Railroad, five miles east of here, yesterday.

Patrick Hardy, a laborer, who resides on Vernon-street, near Twelfth-street, Long Island City, killed his wife Thursday night. The couple were married 11 years ago, but have not lived together all of that time.
The Governor of Texas is determined that his descendants shall not be pushed into the Gulf of Mexico by a horde of immigrants.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 16.--The latter part of last June a difficulty arose between the management of the Daily Evening States and their pressmen, whereupon the union compositors struck and left the office.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 16.--"Jones of Binghamton," who is on a tour of the State in the interests of the head of the Democratic State ticket, of which he is the tail, arrived here this afternoon from Utica, where he had had a conference with ex-Gov. Seymour.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 16.--The Fall meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association opened successfully to-day. The horse fair was a good attraction and the races were very interesting. Following is a summary:

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 16.--Farmer Peter Henger has lived for a number of years with his wife and child and his younger brother Nicholas on a homestead seven miles out of Wahoo, in Saunders County, 40 miles west of this city.

BISMARCK, Dakota, Oct. 16.--National Committeeman Pat Kelly, the Democratic boss of Minnesota, who carries the Democratic city of St. Paul in his trousers pocket, has scored a victory over ex-Speaker Carlisle in the appointment of ex-Alderman Michael Patrick Slatterly as Postmaster of this city, in place of O.A. Lounsberry, resigned.
COLUMBUS, Oct. 16.--Gov. Hoadly concedes the election of a Republican Legislature on joint ballot.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16.--Gertie Smith, a young woman not far along in her teens, recently left her mother's house and went to live with a Mrs. Cravers.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 16.--At the Mystic Park races to-day the stallion A.C. Dewey started in the free-for-all race. Just as he was about to reach the wire at the conclusion of the first heat he fell dead, having either burst a blood vessel or died from congestion of the heart.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 16.--Arrangements are being made for an "exposition of Buffalo's retail resources," to open on Oct. 31. The entire new Becker Building has been leased for the purpose, and space is being rapidly taken by business men. The exhibition will be free, and will continue for about two months.
The twenty-seventh field meeting of the Columbia College Athletic Association was held yesterday afternoon on the grounds of the NewYork Athletic Club, at Mott Haven.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 16--Mrs. James Quayle, wife of a prominent young attorney, has been missing since Wednesday noon. She has been in ill health for some time, and her friends think she has wandered away in a fit of insanity.

The track at Brighton Beach yesterday was in splendid condition, and visitors saw some good racing. The short horse of the day was Spartacus, which won the first race in good style, and paid his few backers $159.25 for $5 straight and $64.35 for a place. Following is a summary:

While Virginia Lauretica, an Italian girl, was passing through North Second-street, near Seventh-street, Brooklyn, about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, she heard a man cry: "My God! I am stabbed!" and on looking around saw a man fall to the sidewalk, while a second man, clad in a brown cardigan jacket, disappeared around the corner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--Judge Vincent, of New-Mexico, who has been suspended by the President, was backed by Representative Sprigner, and it is now said that Mr. Springer has made some investments in the Territory, besides concerning himself in appointments.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16.--Although Austin J. Doyle yesterday resigned the office of Superintendent of Police and his resignation was accepted, he was to-day made defendant in a suit begun against him as Superintendent of Police by the Pennsylvania and Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad Companies to prevent him from carrying out an ordinance of the City Council.

Fifty members of the Association of American Railroad Superintendents, with 100 of their friends, both ladies and gentlemen, went on a picnic yesterday to West Point. The Hon. Joun H. Starin placed the steamer Castleton at their disposal.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 16, via Galveston. --The President has granted full pardon to all political prisoners except Editor Chivarri, of the Monitor Republicano, and Editor Carrillo, of the Correo de Lunes.
ELMIRA, Oct. 16.--The methods of any politician who aspires to be Governor of this State are as fair a subject of inquiry and criticism as his public record.

Scarcely a day passes that the Republican County Committee does not receive verbal or written assurancres from old-time Democrats that they intend to vote for Davenport. In many instances business men in this city who have heretofore voted the Democratic ticket ...

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 16.--John Teemer, of McKeesport, Penn., who is to row a three-mile race with Hanlan over the Pleasure Island course, commenced practicing to-day, making his headquarters at the Cohoes Clubhouse.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 16.--The American Woman Suffrage Association adjourned yesterday after a three days' successful session. The Church of the Redeemer was crowded, many being unable to set standing room.

Jay Gould will not get the Commodore's Cup, which his steam yacht Atalanta raced for against the Stiletto on July 16 last, if John B. Herreshoff, the owner of the latter, can prevent it. Mr. Herreshoff has written a letter to Alfred De Cordova, the Commodore of the American ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 16.--The failure of D. Danziger, dry goods merchant of Canalstreet, is reported to-day. The liabilities foot up $235,000, and the assets, mainly stock in hand, $20,000. Nine-tenths of the creditors are NewYork houses.

TORONTO, Oct. 16.--The defalcation and forgery of Alexander Armour, the late Treasurer of Brampton, is causing a great sensation in the town, as each day since the discovery of his fraudulent transactions brings more startling developments to light.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 16.--The third day of the Fall meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club was the most successful thus far. The weather was fine, the track in very fair condition, and fully 3,000 persons were present to witness the contests.

EL PASO, Texas, Oct. 16.--Judge Alexander Cochrane, ex-member of Congress from the Pittsburg district and the confidential adviser of Capt. James B. Eads, arrived here last night from the city of Mexico, en route to NewYork.

MONROE, Ga., Oct. 16.--William McGaughy was hanged here to-day for the murder of his wife. He fell seven feet, and was pronounced dead in 20 minutes. He went through the trap advising his fellow-men to avoid base women.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 16.--Henry Murphy, a well known planter, living near Desarc, shot and killed George Clark and wounded his wife, Wednesday night. Clark was a tenant living on Murphy's plantation.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 16.--The weather today was very pleasant, the track a little stiff, and the attendance large. The first race, (fiveeighths of a mile,) for a purse of $250, was won by Fabius. Time--1:04 .
Steamship Breakwater, Jenny, Norfolk and Newport News, with mdse. and passengers to Old Dominion Steamship Co.

Charles H. Glover, an eminent lawyer of this city, died at his home, in Brooklyn, yesterday, from a complication of diseases. He had been confined to his house for several months. A widow and five children survive him.

The rebuilding of Mountstuart, Lord Bute's place near Rothesay, has now been completed, and it is one of the most magnificent mansions in Great Britain. The house covers an acre, and is in the mediaeval Gothic style of the thirteenth century.

People who listened to brokers on the Petroleum Exchange yesterday and did not doubt the truth of all they heard, were edified with one entertaining story which represented the Prince of Wales as a speculator in oil.
Minister Jarvis writes to his friend, Capt. Isaac Sugg, of Greenville: "Mrs. Jarvis and myself have a teacher and are taking lessons three times a week in Portuguese.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 16.--No such scene as was witnessed on the scaffold at Crawfordsville, at noon to-day, probably ever was witnessed in this vicinity. Last January James McMullen and his wife were murdered in a most diabolical manner. John W. Coffee was arrested for the crime.
BELOIT, Wis., Oct 16.--The hog disease which has been raging in this locality for the last two months is spreading, causing a great fatality wherever it makes its appearance.
BATH, N.Y., Oct. 16.--William P. Sedgwick, of this village, was nominated to-day for member of Assembly by the Republicans of the First District of Steuben County.

The Republican primary elections for delegates to the County, Senatorial, Assemby, and Aldermanic Conventions, to be held next week, took place last night. There were no con tests, except in the Fifteenth and Sixteenth Districts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16.--Mr. Calhoun, the expert accountant who has been engaged in remodeling the system of book and account keeping of the Navy Department, to-day described the changes which he has recommended to the Secretary of the Navy, and which have been approved up to the present time, and the ...
Officer William Dakin, of the Thirtyfifth Precinct, was run over and killed on the Hudson River Railroad track near the King's Bridge Station early last evening.

MONTREAL, Oct. 16.--A solemn religious service was held this morning in the Church of Notre Dame, at the request of the Judges and members of the Bar of this city, the object being to offer prayers for the disappearance of the smallpox epidemic.

"Tony" is the title of the official bootblack to the Produce Exchange. He pays $650 a year for the exclusive privilege of having his assistants go on the floors of the Exchange at certain hours of the day to polish the boots of the brokers.

Mr. Mapleson's prospectus in relation to his approaching operatic season at the Academy of Music, bearing the imprint of a London house, was received in this city yesterday. It is a tribe briefer than usual, and quite unpretentious in tone.

While laborers were at work digging a trench near the foundation of the new St. Thomas's Episcopal Church, at Mamaroneck, late on Thursday afternoon, one of them threw up with a shovelful of dirt a man's right hand.
Servia has at last crossed the Bulgarian frontier in force, and the difficulty of securing a peaceful solution of the Balkan problem is at once greatly increased.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16, 1885, The President has virtually decided to post pone the appointment of a Superintendent of the Coast, and Geodetic Survey until after the meeting of Congress. It has been suggested to the President that an engineer officer of the army or navy might properly be detailed to perform the duties of the office, and that question is now under consideration.

Mrs. Lewis Kamberger, who lives with her husband and family on the second floor of No. 81 Sheriff-street, went out early yesterday morning, leaving a little 6-months-old infant-- Lena--in bed and three small children--Gustav. Charles, and Freda--in the room.
The mystery connected with the death of Andrew Werner, who was found in his room at No. 287 Bowery, was not cleared up yesterday.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 16.--The report of the Department of Agriculture shows that the condition of the cotton crop has been constantly falling off since the 1st of September.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 16.--The Detroits defeated the home team to-day by a score of 8 to 4. ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 16.--The Browns won to-day's game from the Chicagos in the first inning, making 5 runs in that inning. The total runs were--St. Louis, 7; Chicago, 4.
Tammany and Irving Hall have united in nominating, for the State Senate, John J. Cullen in the Ninth Districts and George W. Plunkitt in the Eleventh.

BELGRADE, Oct. 16.--Servia has protested against the decision of the Ambassadors on the Roumelian question, and has commenced military operations against Bulgaria. A large force of Servian troops crossed the Bulgarian frontier from Nissa at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

PETERSBURG, Va., Oct. 16.--Senator Mahone and John S. Wise, Republican candidate for Governor, addressed a large meeting of Republicans here to-night, and the Senator, as Chairman of the State Committee, presided and introduced Mr. Wise.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 16.--The municipal authorities received instructions to-day from Attorney-General Colt to exhume the body of Benjamin Burton, with a view to holding an inquest to determine whether he was murdered.

Mr. S.W. Thompson, representing the Grant Monument Association of New-York, is again in Newburg soliciting subscriptions in behalf of the fund suggested. He is meeting with encouraging success. Mr. S.R. Van Duzer says: "You may put me down for $1,000." Under certain conditions Mr. Van Duzer will increase the amount named.

The Bostons turned the tables on the Brooklyns yesterday, and the League secured a victory over the American Association. There was a large attendance and the game was brilliantly played by the Bostons.
Pugilistic circles in Brooklyn are greatly excited over a mill between Jack Nelson and Jack Masters Thursday night, in which the latter was knocked out in seven rounds.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 16.--For several weeks a large number of workmen have been engaged in tearing down an old warehouse and excavating for the laying of the new foundation at Main and Tenth streets.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 16.--Last night James L. Jackson, a young man of excellent reputation, died here of consumption. His only horror was that body snatchers might desecrate his grave.

A competitive examination for the position of Weigher will be held at the rooms of the Board of Examiners for the Customs Service in the Post Office Build ing on Friday, Oct. 30.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 16.--The story of a terrible murder in Jackson County, this State, has just been received here. An old negro named Albert Kirkland was called upon to pay a debt of $5 which it was claimed he owed.
Mr. Sutherst has done well to call public attention to the way in which railway servants are overworked. It seems that 70 hours a week is quite a common thing.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 16.--The withdrawal of the suit of George E. Ingraham against Putnam, Earle Co., of New-York, from the Supreme Court docket attracts attention to a case which has an unusual record.
Detective McCarthy, of the Eighteenth Precinct, took a 16-year-old boy, who gave his name and address as James McArdle, of 224 East Twenty-eighth-street, to the Yorkville Police Court yesterday.
CORK, Oct. 16.--The attempt to boycott the Cork Steamship Company by the cattle dealers has failed. The Cattle Dealers' Association has resumed the shipping of cattle by the packets of that company.

BOSTON, Oct. 16.--The young woman who told the thrilling story of her abduction from the Old Colony Station one evening last week, where she was about to take the Fall River boat for New-York, now admits that her story was all imagination.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 16.--McGeoch, the Board of Trade operator, was stricken down by something like apoplexy at an early hour this morning, and for several hours it was thought that he would die.

The Board of Excise Commissioners unanimously passed a resolution yesterday that all persons holding licenses from the board, and also licenses for places of amusement, be notified to permanently close any openings that may exist between such places.

Felix McCloskey, politician and man of general business, walked jauntily to the witness chair in Judge Van Brunt's court room yesterday morning, sat down and began to caress the tuft of red hair that nestled modestly in a little hollow under his lower lip.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 16.--As the Canadian Pacific Railway will be running in a few weeks from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean it is understood that the restriction placed upon construction of lines from points is the Northwest and Manitoba to the international boundary, to connect with the American railway system, will be withdrawn.

Druggist Am Ende, of Hoboken, who caused the death of two daughters of Restaurant Keeper Holtz several weeks ago by filling a prescription with morphia instead of quinine, was arraigned in Judge Knapp's court, in Jersey City, yesterday, on two indictments charging him with manslaughter.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 16.--Andrew Stewart and Newton Davis, two negroes, will be hanged for burglary. Three weeks ago they came here from Wilmington.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16.--The reorganization Trustees of the Reading Railroad Company at their meeting to-day reported that the acceptances to the plan of foreclosure proposed under the general income and consolidated mortgages were sufficient to warrant the application to court.

The Bulletin of the Geographical Society of Marseilles estimates the total number of Jews in the world at 6,377,602; that is, 5,407,602 in Europe, 245,000 in Asia, 413,000 in Africa, 300,000 in America, and 12,000 in Oceanica.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17.--The task of winning a game of baseball in this city is no easy one. On Friday bad umpiring imposed a defeat upon the New-Yorks and gave a victory to the Nationals. The Now-York men refused to play the game to-day with Holland, the man who umpired yesterday.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 17.--This evening while the wife of Jean Baptiste Romilly, a farmer residing near the village of St. Vincent de Paul, 10 miles from here, accompanied by her 2-year-old child, was feeding her fowls.

The steamship Hekla, of the Thingvalla Line, moored at the wharf at the foot of Fourthstreet, Hoboken, was damaged to the extent of $5,000 by fire and water last night. The fire broke out in the hold. It was a case of spontaneous combustion. The Hoboken Fire Department flooded the vessel, with water.

GALVESTON, Texas, Oct. 17.--The steam lighter Star, laden with 500 bales of cotton for the steamer Almandine, lying in the outer harbor, caught fire to-day just as she left the wharf. The flames spread with remarkable rapidity, but the crew succeeded in throwing the cotton overboard. The total loss on the cotton and lighter will probably aggregate $20,000. The cotton was insured, but the lighter was not.

Madison-Square Garden was well filled last night, when a testimonial benefit was given to L.E. Myers, the champion amateur runner. The Manhattan Athletic Club made the most points, and won a handsome stand of colors presented by G.L.M. Sacks.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 17.--For two weeks the trial of William Gooch and James A. Smith, young white men, for the murder of John A. Cheatham, a merchant of this city, has been in progress here.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 18.--Mrs. Amelia Opper, of Clyde, has just died. Her husband was killed in the battle of the Wilderness in 1864, and the news of his death drove her insane. Mrs. Opper's life was a blank until four weeks before her death, when her reason returned and she retained her senses until the last.

Edward Walburger, a candlemaker, residing in Delancey-street, New-York, while on a visit at the house of Mr. Landrix, on the Paterson plank road, near Hempstead station, N.J., yesterday afternoon picked up an old shot gun. BLACKFOOT, Idaho, Oct. 18.--The United States Grand Jury, discharged yesterday, found during their six days' session 29 indictments for unlawful cohabitation. Chief-Justice Hayes, in discharging the jury, thanked them in a very impressive manner, and remarked that, if the trial jury did their duty as well, the laws of the country would be rigidly enforced.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 18.--The mystery surrounding the disappearance of Mrs. James Quayle, who left home on Wednesday last seems to thicken. No reliable information regarding the lady's whereabouts has yet been received. Searching parties scoured the surrounding country to-day, but without success. The whole city is interested in the case, and it promises to be a ten day's wonder.

The debts of the King of Bavaria amount to 1,500,000. The private theatrical performances at Munich have been suspended, all building operations at the new castles have been stopped, and the royal stud has been largely diminished.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18.--Every pleasant afternoon the candidates for the 'Varsity nine of 1886 may be seen busily engaged in practice on Holmes Field. The number of candidates is unusually large, especially from the Freshman Class.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 18.--Intelligence from the Indian Territory is to the effect that the Cherokees are considerably stirred up concerning the misapprehension made in the sale of certains lands to the United States Government for $300,000.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 18.--The members of the National Prison association heard a number of sermons on "Prison Reform" to-day by several local Pastors. TROY, N.Y., Oct. 19.--Postmaster Robertson, of Troy, to-day received from Washington orders for the discontinuance of the West Troy office, and directing the establishment in its place of a branch of the Troy Post Office, to be under the control of the Postmaster of this city. Four auxiliary letter carriers, at a yearly salary of $600, are allowed. This order takes effect Nov. 1.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 19.--Benjamin W. Baum, of this city, a member of the firm of Baum, Richardson Co., of Gilmore, Penn., was thrown from his carriage here to-day and probably fatally injured. WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--The Secretary of War directs that hereafter details of artillery Lieutenants to the light batteries for two years' course of instruction shall be made, first, from civilian appointees who have not been at the Fortress Monroe school, and, secondly, from young graduates who have not been there. He was found seated on a stoop, with blood flowing from a wound in his head. He was taken to Police Headquarters, where it was found that his skull was fractured.

TAYLORSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 20.--Abraham Kyle, a wealthy farmer and formerly County Commissioner, was fatally shot at 10 o'clock last night by Barney McEvenie. The shooting grew out of a lawsuit in which the two were concerned.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20.--Application was made to-day by J.H. Cheney, as Receiver of the Lake Erie and Western Road, to Judge Gresham for leave to buy 3,000 tons of steel rails and to issue Receiver's certificates in payment therefor.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 20.--A largely attended mass meeting was held at the Grand Opera House this evening to listen to the report made by the Board of Management of the work done in preparing for the opening of the North, Central, and South American Exposition on Nov. 10.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--This was the second day of the racing meeting at Ivy City. The first race, one mile, for all ages, was won by Jim Douglas by a length in 1:43, Strathspey second, 15 lengths ahead of Rica.

The war upon alleged violators of the excise law in the town of Southampton, Suffolk County, still continues. Recently John H. Hildreth and D. Harold Rose pleaded guilty to violation of the law and were fined $50 each by Justice Foster.

The session of the Cabinet to-day was almost entirely devoted to matters relating to the postal union. At the office of the Register of Wills yesterday an inventory was filed by the Executors of the estate of the late Edward A. Rollins. TROY, N.Y., Oct. 21.--The Presbyterian State Synod met at 9 o'clock this morning. Resolutions deploring the publication, sale, and reading of Sunday newspapers and asking Pastors and Elders to use their influence against them were adopted.

ALBANY, Oct. 21.--The Democratic State Committee has a branch headquarters in this city whose employes are being taxed to their uttermost to find campaign material and furnish suggestions to the parent body at the Hoffman House in the city of New-York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21.--First Lieut. Robert Craig, Fourth Artillery, has been relieved from duty in the Signal Service and assigned to temporary duty in this city until his accounts with the Treasury Department are adjusted, when he will proceed to join his battery.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 21.--The British bark Robert S. Bernard, Capt. Andrews, from Hiogo, Japan, to this port, laden with camphor and rage, attracts much attention on account of her crew, which consists of 14 Japanese sailors, none of whom can speak a word of English or understand an order from their officers without the aid of signs. With this novel crew Capt. Andrews made the voyage from Hiogo in 157 days.

MONTREAL, Oct. 21.--The East End health offices formally opened to-day, but there was no trouble. There were only 37 deaths from smallpox in the city yesterday and 14 is the outlying municipalities. This makes a total of 177 in the district for the past four days, a considerable reduction.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 21.--Miss May A., only daughter of Mr. James M. Wentz, a retired New-York merchant, was united in marriage this afternoon to Mr. Thomas F. Balfe, a young Newburg banker.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21.--The shipment of fruit from California, to the East continues. The rate per passenger train for green fruit is $600 for each car of 20,000 pounds.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 21.--Leland Sulgrove, an Assistant Professor in the Indianapolis High School, was accidentally killed to-night in the yards of the Pan Handle Railway Company. Two trains passed over his body, literally cutting it in pieces. He was a son of Berry R. Sulgrove, for many years editor of the Journal.

Health Officer Raymond, of Brooklyn, notified the Police or Hoboken last night that Mrs. Mary Hammel, whose 9-months-old child is sick with smallpox, had left Brooklyn with the No. 6 Adams-street. The County Physician does not think the child has the smallpox, but the people in the house, which is a four-story tenement, are excited. Mrs. Hammel refuses to say from what part of Brooklyn she came.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 21.--William Boyd, charged with murdering Birdie Patterson, his mistress, July 5, 1883, was found guilty today and sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment. Boyd, who is highly connected, was convicted principally on circumstantial evidence, he being found in an intoxicated condition in the room with the woman when people who had heard the pistol shot rushed into the apartment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21.--The supports under a two-story and basement cottage at No. 1,425 Wabash-avenue were found to be unsafe the other day, and last Thursday it was moved to the rear of the lot for the purpose of putting in a new basement.

The Republicans of the Fifth District of Jersey City, N.J., have nominated Ex-Freeholder William B. Shrope for the Assembly. Frank Track is the nominee in the Tenth District.

The Rev. Dr. Curry, the newly appointed Minister to Spain, in an interview to-day, denied a published statement that he was at one time in command at Andersonville Prison. Tarrant, a counterfeiter, who was arrested last week in Jackson, Miss., was to-day arraigned before the United States Commissioner and committed to jail in default of $3,000 bail. PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27.--The widow of Gen. Grant has been greatly grieved and pained by the public discussion of the domestic affairs of her daughter, Mrs. Sartoris. VICKSBURG, Miss., Oct. 27.--The Mississippi Colored State Fair was opened at Jackson, the capital, to-day. Gov. Robert Lowry addressed the assembly and declared the fair formally opened. The speeches of Mr. Montgomery and Gov. Lowry were to the point and appropriate.

MOBERLY, Mo., Oct. 27.--A new system of water works, including an artificial lake of 110,000,000 gallons capacity, for this city, and costing $125,000, was formally accepted from the contractor by the Mayor and Common Council to-day. The event was celebrated by a public demonstration by the citizens. The works insure a water supply to Moberly for all purposes for a population of 40,000.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Oct. 27.--Twenty cases of scarlet fever were discovered to-day in tenement blocks owned by the Tecumseh Mill corporation. Children from these blocks attended the Davenport School, having over 700 pupils. All pupils from the infected blocks were dismissed for two weeks, and every effort will be made to check the spread of the disease.

BUFFALO, Oct. 27.--A faith cure convention was opened here to-day. Among the noted people present from abroad are Mr. and Mrs. Michael Baxter, of London, England; the Rev. A.B. Simpson, of New-York; the Rev. N. Cookman, of Brooklyn, and John Currie. Participants in the convention give interesting accounts of cures from disease wrought through faith.

ASTORIA, Oregon, Oct. 27.--On the arrival of the American ship Olive S. Southard, from New-York, to-day, James Maxwell, a seaman, was lodged in jail to await examination on the charge of having murdered Thomas Welch, another seaman, on shipboard on Oct. 16. During a quarrel Maxwell stabbed Welch in the breast. Welch died on the 18th, and was buried at sea.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 27.--The Rev. Henry Ward Beecher will possibly appear in this city next week as defendant in a civil suit for damages which is assigned for trial in the Court of Common Pleas.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27.--Weiler Brothers, wholesale liquor dealers, at No. 147 First-avenue, New-York, recently sold John Lawless, a saloon keener in this city, five barrels of whisky stamped by the United States as containing 40 gallons each and taxed accordingly.

A letter received in Charleston yesterday from Mrs. John E. Owens conveys the gratifying information that the veteran comedian, who has been desperately ill at his residence near Towson, Md., is recovering gradually. Mrs. Owens says in her letter, which is dated the 20th: "His suffering was intense for a week, ...
NEWBURG, Oct. 27.--The Standard Dramatic Company, under the management of Jacob Wettlaufer, of this city, has been playing at Middletown for several weeks.
Lieut. John Marion Cunningham, stationed at Fort Clark, Texas, was married on Monday evening to Miss Helen Hayt, daughter of Mr. M. Hayt, of Yonkers.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Oct. 27.--The inclines for the transfer of the Queen and Crescent Railroad over the Mississippi were completed to-day and the steamer Northern Pacific made a successful transfer of three loaded freight cars and one 50-ton engine from the Mississippi to the Louisiana side.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27.--The September Grand Jury, after changing its alleged mind two or three times, decided not to indict Jasper E. Sweet, the printer who shot and killed Dr. Thomas Waugh for undue intimacy with Mrs. Sweet.
Gen. JOHN B. WOODWARD in accepting the Citizens' League nomination for Mayor of Brooklyn has defined the policy he sustains and which, if elected, he would carry out.
