BOSTON, Oct. 27.--It appeared at the meeting of the New-York and New-England Directors to-day that $600,000 only of the $2,000,000 of the preferred stock offered to the stockholders had been subscribed for by them.

Evidences are multiplying that Gov. Hill and his friends have overdone the labor business. Members of trades unions are growing indignant at the idea of handing over their votes to Gov. Hill at the command of so-called leaders.
The city of Jeffersonville, on our southern border, is becoming a sort of Gretna Green for runaway couples from Kentucky.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 27.--The shipping of apples to European cities is being largely carried on by farmers in the Hudson Valley. The crop is unusually large hereabout. It is estimated that there will be exported from this region about 9,000 barrels, mostly Newtown Pippins. A number of fruit growers will also export large quantities of cider.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 27.--McLachlin, Conde Co., proprietors of the Imperial Hosiery Mill, employing 65 hands, recently discharged six hands, as they had no work for them.
An old and a good friend of Newfoundland's appeared in the streets of our city to-day after an absence of something like 35 years.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27.--Kunan Hancock, a stock yard firm, have just completed the collection and classification of important statistics relating to the cattle, also the crops of corn and hay, of the States of Illinois, Iowa, Missouri, Kansas, Nebraska, Wisconsin, and Minnesota.
There was great activity in the stock market yesterday in the securities of the Nickel Plate and Erie Railroads.
JAMESTOWN, Oct. 27.--The registry books closed here to-day. Over 3,000 names were entered. Women appeared at all the places of registration, but the inspectors refused to accept their names.

For more than six hours yesterday James D. Fish sat in the witness's chair giving testimony and listening to the arguments of counsel in the case of the people against Ferdinand Ward. His demeanor was calm and unconcerned ...

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 27.--The campaign for the prohibition of liquor in Atlanta is now in full blast. Every night colored churches are filled with white Democrats who are advocating prohibition. John E. Bryant is freely referred to as "Brother Bryant."
LITTLEROCK, Ark., Oct. 27.--To-day Gov. Hughes offered a reward of $500 each for the arrest of any or all of the mob who burned the jail of Pike County on Oct. 13.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 27.--The passenger agents of west-bound roads help an important meeting to-day, and the local ticket brokers did the same.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 27.--The largest single shipment of cotton ever made from this city was made to-day by C.W. Mosby Co. to William Blake, New-Orleans. It consisted of 1,100 bales, and the train bearing it was decked with blue ribbons.

I have had the opoortunity, through the kindness of Mgr. Domonico Jacobini, Secretary of the Propaganda, of making a long and minute examination of that "precious antiquarian treasure," the celebrated map on which Alexander VI. drew the line "qua dominium ...

SANTIAGO DE CHILI, Oct. 27, via Galveston.--The Fiscal Court passed a note to the Triunal of this city representing that the two NewYork insurance companies doing business in this country should pay taxation for their Chilian agencies in place of the present license fee. Should this be approved, taxes to a considerable amount may be imposed.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27.--Edward S. Stokes, of New-York, is in the city. With William King, of Minnesota, ex-Postmaster of the national House of Representatives and ex-Congressman, ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 27.--Vignaux, Slosson, and Schaefer played their first practice game together here to-night. Vignaux ran 251 points in 15 innings, his highest run being 76; Slosson 400 points in 14 innings, highest run 73; Schaefer 600 points in 31 innings, highest run 101.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27.--A correspondence has been opened between bankers of this city, New-York, and Baltimore with a view to the presentation of a bill in the next Congress for the redemption of the trade dollar. Each city is to consult with its Congressional delegation on the subject.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27.--At a special town meeting to-day New-Haven voted to appropriate $3,000 for free vaccination. The city is often visited by French Canadians, and there is danger that cases of smallpox may be imported. The meeting was called to-day through the efforts of the Board of Education.
A more delightful day for racing than that of yesterday could not have been desired, and a large crowd gathered at Jerome Park to witness the fine sport which the programme promised.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27.--The Democratic Campaign Committee to-day nominated as Judge of the Superior Court William J. Hynes.
When William H. Williams, President of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club, stepped on the platform in Historical Hall, Brooklyn, last evening, he was warmly greeted by ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27.--The Hon. Augustus Schoonmaker, of the New-York State Civil Service Commission, who has been here on a short visit, returned to New-York this afternoon after he had discussed with the President an offer made three weeks ago ...

Andrew J. White, the County Democracy candidate for Sheriff, has received a letter from Prof. Charles F. Chandler in regard to the offal contracts, in which he says that the statement of Justice White's relation to the Health Board is absolutely false.

For nearly eight months Mr. CLEVELAND has been President of the United States. He is an industrious man. He rises at an early hour every morning and is soon at work. Blessed with good health and a strong constitution, he has been ...

HARTFORD, Oct. 27.--The Republicans of the Third Senatorial District, in their convention at Windsor Locks to-day, followed the example set by the Democratic Convention, which met at the same place last week, and passed a resolution opposing the military commutation tax which is yearly laid in support of the National Guard. The action taken is considered ...

ST. PAUL, Oct. 27.--Telegrams were received here to-day stating that the Lake Superior Transit Company would hereafter decline to receive any freight for east-bound shipment except with the explicit understanding that the transit company can divert it east of Buffalo to any line it may choose.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 27.--Private information was received here to-day to the effect that John McBride, formerly President of the Miners' Union, which was crushed out by the long strike in the Hocking Valley, is again endeavoring to encourage the miners to make a demand for an increase from 50 to 60 cents per ton. The miners are assured by McBride that 60 ...
EMPORIA, Kan., Oct. 27.--In the Walkup case this morning Dr. Charles W. Scott, of Kansas City, testified regarding Mr. Walkup's call upon him in December last.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27.--The commission of the House of Representatives, consisting of Congressmen Randall, Hewitt, Burnes, Crisp, Hiscock, Reed, and Phelps, appointed to report upon the policy to be adopted by the Government to secure a supply of ordnance and armor plate, has sent a circular letter to the ...

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Oct. 27.--In a case where the Bell Telephone Company had refused to furnish telephones upon applications made by merchants here with whom the agents of the company were not on good terms, Judge Garrett has decided that this is not just ground for refusal; that the telephone company is bound by the laws governing common carriers to make no discrimination between the different applicants.
PARIS, Oct. 27.--M. Fremsel, a prominent banker of this city, committed suicide to-day owing to financial embarrassments. The Bourse was flat in consequence.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27.--A committee of the first mortgage bondholders of the Oil Creek Railroad Company issued a notice to-day stating that, as the interest on those bonds had been defaulted, active measures would be taken to collect the same or obtain possession of the road by foreclosure.
Great curiosity is felt regarding Dr. Schliemann's forthcoming work on Tiryus, just announced by Mr. Murray.

In Mr. C.T. Dazey's play called "For a Brother's Life," now to be seen at the ThirdAvenue Theatre, there is plenty of action, and several situations are developed which call from the lads in the gallery expressions of frantic joy.
Canon Farrar was entertained at breakfast yesterday morning at the Union League Club by Mr. Logan C. Murray.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 27.--The situation in Grundy County has become interesting. United States Marshal Tillman of this city, today complied with the request of leading residents of Tracy City, who asked that men be sent to that section to aid in the suppression of the moonshine whisky business and the capture of the people engaged in it.
DAVID B. HILL is unworthy of the votes and the confidence of the people of the State of New-York.
WELLINGTON, Kan., Oct. 27.--It is rumored here that a colony of "boomers" will start for Oklahoma to-morrow morning.

DETROIT, Oct. 27.--It is stated in political circles in this city that there is a strong probability that Attorney-General Garland will retire from the Cabinet in the course of the next month and will be succeeded by Don M. Dickinson, a prominent lawyer and leading Democratic politician of this city.

NEWBURG, Oct. 27.--This morning J.H. France, station agent of the West Shore Road at Malden, attempted to cross a track upon which a freight train was standing. He walked ahead of the locomotive, which started sudden ly, threw Mr. France to the ground, and crushed one of his feet.
In ordinary times a person who professes himself opposed to vaccination and talks and writes against it may contribute to the amusement of his neighbors.

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 27.--The train on the Northern New-Jersey Railroad that reaches Sparkill at 11 o'clock A.M. brought to that place to-day the remains of Commander Henry H. Gorringe, to be taken to Rockland Cemetery for interment. The burial was, from choice of ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27.--The meeting of the Naval Advisory Board called for yesterday to take into consideration the subject of completing the unfinished cruisers did not take place, owing to the detachment at his own request of Admiral Simpson, President of the board, whose successor has not yet been appointed.
The members of the New-York Mercantile Exchange held a meeting yesterday to memorialize Congress to prohibit the further coinage of the standard silver dollar.

During the fog which prevailed yesterday morning over the entire water front of the city the Hoboken Ferry Company's boat Hackensack collided with the steamship Servia, of the Canard Line. One life was lost, but the damage to the vessel was comparatively trifling.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 28.--The Chautauqua County Shorthorn Breeders' Association sold over $3,000 worth of stock on this its first annual sales day. Prices averaged over $70, a few bulls brining over $200 each. Buyers were here from different parts of the State.

The appearance of Mr. W.J. WARNER as a witness for WARD was a highly interesting event. It was made more interesting by the disclosure in a newspaper on the very day of his appearance of his relations with the man whom his testimony was intended to help.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 28.--Edward F. Read, chief clerk of the Providence and Stonington Steamship Company, who absconded on the 14th inst. with about $2,000 was brought back this morning from Sherbrooke, Canada, by Detective Parker, of the Providence Police Department. Read returned $1,900 of the money taken to the detective.
The parlors of the Manhattan Hotel were filled yesterday with glistening instruments and immense drawings of animal and vegetable fibres magnified to the size of seaserpents.

Before a large assemblage in the Metropolitan Opera House last evening Signor Salvini presented his splendid portrayal of Lear. The performance of Shakespeare's tragedy, which did not end until nearly midnight, was listened to with eager attention ...

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 28.--Nearly 3,000 people witnessed the single scull boat race, three miles with a turn, for $500 a side, this afternoon between George H. Hosmer, of Boston, and Joseph Laing, of Montreal, the amateur champion of Canada.
MONTREAL, Oct. 28.--Bishop Fabre is highly incensed at the complaints made against the nuns who have charge of the smallpox hospital.

Some striking coincidences in the time of the arrival of the Cunard Steamship Servia in this port are furnished by five passages during the present year from Liverpool to the Sandy Hook Lightship. Capt. McMickan entered port on Sunday on each of the passages.

Warren S. Pennell, a real estate agent of Cleveland, went to the Tombs Police Court yesterday and swore out a warrant for the arrest of Ceni Della Watson, an actress, of No. 236 East Twenty-seventh-street, and she was arraigned in the afternoon.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--In the crowd of people hurrying through Monroe-street on their way home between 5 and 6 o'clock this evening was a neatly dressed young man carrying on his arm a light overcoat.
Adrian H. Muller Son sold the following securities at auction yesterday at the Real Estate Exchange, in Liberty-street:
AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 28.--Gov. Ireland wrote a letter to Secretary Bayard yesterday that will probably shock that functionary when be readsit.

LEOMINSTER, Mass., Oct. 28.--Arthur Spill left here for Worcester yesterday. He returned on the evening train and went to the house of Edward Crockett, who is employed at Northborough, his wife and children being at home.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 28.--The movement of wheat in the Northwest the past week has been heavy and receipts at Minneapolis have largely exceeded those of any previous week. Receipts at Duluth have also improved, but the increase in that direction seems to have no effect in diminishing the volume which is pouring into Minneapolis.

In carrying out their scheme to capture the votes of trades unions and labor organizations the friends of Gov. Hill have not hesitated to mangle the truth on many subjects in which workingmen have an interest.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 28.--One of the saddest cases that has come before the Criminal Court for some time was decided to-day, F.W. Schramm being found guilty of forgery and sentenced to one year in the penitentiary.

There was a large and enthusiastic gathering of Republican and independent voters of the Fifth Assembly District at No. 123 West Houston-street, last evening. They had assembled to ratify the nomination of James D. Hawes, the Republican candidate for the Assembly.

Miss Gertrude Whittemore, daughter of the late E.A. Whittemore, and Mr. Charles Benner, of the late firm of Johnes, Benner Willcox, of this city, were married yesterday afternoon in St. George's Episcopal Church, Astoria.

BOSTON, Oct. 28,--The residents of Weymouth, Braintree, and Quincy have for two weeks been greatly alarmed over the bold work of incendiaries. During that time over 10 dwellings, coal and lumber yards, and the almshouse have been partially or totally destroyed by ...

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28.--Robert J. Cook, Treasurer of the Press Publishing Company, was murderously assaulted at an early hour this morning and very dangerously injured. Stephen McPhearson, the assailant, is a strapping, full-blooded negro of an ugly disposition, who for some time had been employed as janitor in the Press Building.

LA GRANGE, Ga., Oct. 28.--The Synod of the Presbyterian Church of Georgia met here tonight, with the celebrated Dr. Woodrow preent. The discussion of his evolution theory will begin to-morrow, and will be a heated one.

SEATTLE, Wyoming, Oct. 23.--All the Chinamen employed by the Cedar Mountain Coal Company, about 40 in number, have been discharged. All the mines in the Seattle coal region are now operated without Chinese labor.
The annual lawn tennis tournament of the Olympic Athletic Association, of Sing Sing, which had been in progress for three days, was finished yesterday afternoon.

The entries for to-day's races at Jerome Park are very large and the sport promises to be very interesting. James Sheridan will be the starter, and his experience in handling large fields of horses insures immunity from annoying and unnecessary delay. The full entry list is as follows:

LONDON, Oct. 28.--The Genesta, which was defeated in the recent races for the America's Cup by the Puritan, arrived at Portsmouth at 9 o'clock this morning. She came into port flying three first prize flags won in her contests with American yachts.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 28.--A fashionable wedding occurred in the Free Memorial chapel, at Fallsington, Penn., three miles from here, at ...
TORONTO, Oct. 28.--A strange story is told here by a city detective, which clears up a mystery that has been unsolved for half a century.
MONTREAL, Oct. 28.--Twenty-two months ago a young Englishman named A.W. Biddells, accompanied by his brother, arrived in Montreal from their home in one of the English midland counties.

Augustine R. Macdonald has been in Ludlow-Street Jail for nearly seven years. He is a British subject, having once been a Captain in the English Army. Prior to the war he went South, from Boston, where he had been studying law. He amassed a fortune, but it was dissipated by the rebellion.

In a frantic effort to eclipse the County Democracy demonstration of Tuesday night the committee in charge of a ratification meeting at Tammany Hall last night put out very alluring bait to Democrats in advertising yesterday morning a list of speakers from which hardly a prominent Democrat in the county was omitted.

The jury in the case of Mary E. Jones against Oliver L. Jones and others, which has been on trial for two days in the Kings County Supreme Court, at Long Island City, gave a verdict of $75,000 in favor of the plaintiff yesterday. The case was a peculiar one.

The earnestness which horse car conductors and elevated railway brakemen frequently display in the discharge of their duties, even going so far as to supplement moral suasion expressed in the most emphatic terms in the language of impolite society with muscular arguments of a painfully convincing nature, has been a subject of much comment.
The trial of Ferdinand Ward for grand larceny, in obtaining the certification of a check for $71,800, and obtaining the money thereon by false pretenses, was closed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28.--The Pennsylvania Railroad Company issued an order to-day advancing the price of its hard white ash coals shipped to Baltimore, Washington, and points further 10 cents per ton. The Reading Company still insists that its coals for outside shipment will be advanced on Nov. 1.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment considered yesterday the estimates of the Board of Education and for the Department of Charities and Correction.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Oct. 28.--The hurricane that recently raged on the Labrador coast was unprecedented, even in that inclement region. Over 70 vessels and probably 300 lives were lost. The particulars so far are meagre, there being no telegraphic communication. Following is a list of the vessels completely wrecked:

Charles H. Biller was presented with a gold medal, at Newark, N.J., last night, for rescuing a young man from drowning at Asbury Park last Summer. The presentation took place in the hall of the Catholic Institute, which was crowded. Speeches were made by Congressman Lehlbach, Mgr. Doane, Mayor Haynes, and exJudge Lomax.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 28.--William L. Goodrich has been connected with the Schenectady Bank 52 years, for 40 of which he has been Cashier. Recently he was asked to assist the bookkeeper. He refused and the Directors requested him to resign. He refused to do this, and at their last meetiing the Directors passed a resolution removing him from the office of Cashier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--The following business was transacted in the Untted States Supreme Court to-day: No. 31--The Merchants' Exchange National Bank of New-York City, appellant, vs. the Board of Chosen Freeholders of the County of Bergen.--Argument continued by Stephen P. Nash for appellant, by Hamilton Wallis and J.D. Bedle for the appellees and concluded by E.L. Fancher for the appellant.

MONTREAL, Oct. 28.--Mr. L.O. David this afternoon received information from Ottawa to the effect that the Cabinet had notified Mr. Lemieux that as soon as additional affidavits were forwarded a medical commission would be appointed to pronounce upon Riel's mental condition. Mr. Lemieux leaves for Quebec this evening for the purpose of obtaining the affidavits asked for.

Charles A. Swan, who was at one time proprietor of the Hanover Hotel, on Fifth-avenue, and more recently the landlord of a hotel at Tarrytown, N.Y., was reported to the police last night as missing since Monday. His wife, who is staying at the Hotel Royal, informed the police of Mr. Swan's disappearance.
RANGOON, Oct. 28.--The rumor telegraphed yesterday that a revolution had broken out at Mandalay, and that King Theebaw had been murdered, is not true.

MONTREAL, Oct. 28.--Russell Green, the messenger of the National Express Company arrested and remanded until Friday at the instance of James F. Wolfe, Special Customs Agent at this port, on a charge of smuggling ...

"I judge by expressions I have heard and comments I have seen in some newspapers and periodicals," said a member of the Grant Monument Association yesterday, "that $100,000 is but a trifling amount of money.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 28.--James Hodges was to-day elected Mayor of this city on the regular Democratic ticket, defeating Judge George W. Brown, the fusionist nominee, by a majority of about 2,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--Dominic C. Fabronius, an artist, pointed early last year a fine life-size portrait of a little girl standing in an expectant attitude, with a dog by her side. He thought the painting was worth $5,000, and aside from the ...
Alfred Jacquin, who had a diamond store at No. 253 Fifth-avenue, was convicted yesterday in Part II, of the Court of General Sessions of grand larceny.
United States District Attorney Dorsheimer has appointed Macgrane Coxe, a rising young lawyer of this city, an assistant in the civil department of the District Attorney's office.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28.--The athletic association of Harvard College held a meeting to-day on Holmes field, as a preliminary meeting to the university meeting to be held next Saturday.

There are signs that County Democracy leaders and certain machine Republicans of this city are to make an organized attempt to "knife" Judge SEDGWICK, the candidate for re-election to the Superior Court, in favor of RASTUS S. RANSOM, the Tammany nominee.

Bayonne people and those of Bergen Point have an abiding faith in Capt. Joe Ellsworth, who was the pilot of the Puritan in her race with the Genesta, and they believe that to him was due the Puritan's victory notwithstanding the fact that three wise men, not of Gotham, officiated as sailing masters.

A correspondent writes to THE TIMES warning the public of a counterfeit silver dollar bearing the date 1884, which, he says, is being widely circulated. Chief Drummond, of the Secret Service Division of the Treasury, says ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 28.--A homicide with some extraordinary features occurred last night. Edward Renecke, a negro, got on a spree, and, as is usual with his kind, abused and beat his wife. She fled to the neighbors for safety.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 28.--Hamilton Station, a few miles south of Avon, Livingston County, was the scene of a murder late Tuesday night. Emory Thayer, a well-to-do farmer, had sold wheat and was supposed to have considerable money in the house.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 28.--Interest in the election cases seems to increase with each step in the legal proceedings. The criminal prosecutions thus far instituted by the Committee of One Hundred have been--with one exception the case of Chief of Police Hudson--directed against the rank and file of the organization of rogues who perpetrated the outrages.

ITHACA, Oct. 28.--When Gov. Hill traveled several hundred miles in order to attend a little country fair held in the neighboring village of Dryden on the 1st of October, be had a reason more pressing than that which dictated his other rural peregrinations.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 28.--A cable dispatch was received to-night at Harvard College Observatory announcing the discovery by Perrotin of an asteriod. Its position Oct. 27, 7 hours 12 minutes, was right ascension 1 hour 8 minutes 53 seconds: declination, north, 7 degrees 8 minutes 19 seconds; motion minus 36 seconds south 7 minutes.
WASHINGTON, Oct 28.--A series of ill digested charges were brought against Mr. Eaton in the New-York Tribune yesterday.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 28.--The Republican Convention for the Second Assembly District of Monroe County was held to-night. There was a full attendance of delegates and a harmonious session.

BOSTON, Oct. 23.--In the Taber divorce hearing to-day Fred J. Taber, the libellant, concluded his testimony, and the case for the petitioner was closed. Evidence for the other side was then heard, Mrs. Annie F. Taber being the first witness examined.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28.--The members of the board appointed by Congress to inspect different steel and iron works in the country to ascertain their capacity for making ordnance, ...

Mr. JOHN W. JACOBUS, in the letter which he recently addressed to the Bar Association of this city, gives distinct pledges that if he is elected to the office of Sheriff he will thoroughly reform the abuses which have long existed there.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--The Hon. Levi M. Vilas, of Eau Claire, Wis., brother of the Postmaster-General, and Miss Lizzie Stewart Ludlam, daughter of Major James D. Ludlam, of Pullman, were married in the church at Pullman to-day by the Rev. Mr. Warne.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 28.--Scott Thomas, a molder, employed in the foundry at Twelfth and Paine streets, met with a horrible death yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 28.--William J. Best, the whilom Receiver of the Pacific Bank, is to-night a prisoner in a cell at the Charles-Street Jail. After his many months of wandering as a fugitive from the law, he is at last under strict police surveillance.

MONTREAL, Oct. 28.--Gold has been discovered on the Hibernia road, a mile and a quarter from Caledonia, Queens County. There is said to be no less than eight lodes within a radius of 40 feet, five of which show gold, and one of which is said to be over 6 feet in width.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 28.--Richard Pritchard, a married man, 33 years of age, was cut to pieces by the cars at the Pittsburg crossing this evening.

The annual meeting of the Home for Seamen's Children was held yesterday at Sailors' Snug Harbor, Staten Island. George William Curtis presided. After prayer by Chaplain Jones, of Snug Harbor, addresses were made by the Rev. J.C. Eccleston, of Clifton, and the Rev. Dr. Buckley, of Massachusetts. The receipts for the year were $13,335 and the expenses $11,539. There are 100 children in the Home.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 28.--Mr. John S. Wise, the Republican nominee for Governor was in the city to-day on his way to Gloucester County, where he speaks to-morrow. He is in excellent spirits and feels confident of election.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 28.--Mrs. George F. Illedge, of No. 37 Leonard-street, was awakened about midnight last night by some one moving about her room. She started up, and saw a masked man standing by the side of the bed.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 28.--Owen N. Denny, formerly American Consul at Shanghai, has been appointed Foreign Adviser to the King of Corea, to replace Herr Mollendorff, formerly German Consul at Tien-Tsin. The appointment of Mr. Denny to this high position indicates that German influence in Corea, which, since the advent of Herr Mollendorff had been paramount, is on the wane.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 28.--Boston Buck and the members of his notorious gang of counterfeiters were sentenced to the penitentiary in the United States court this afternoon. Buck was sentenced to seven years; Ed Harmon, four ...

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 28.--When Lawyer Z.M. Ward returned from the Fort Lee murder trial at Hackensack at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon he found waiting for him Thomas H. Dowling, a traveling salesman for Francis H. Leggett Co., wholesale grocers, of NewYork.

A Brooklyn mechanic has written to THE TIMES that the Scriptural figure used to illustrate the impossibility of a rich man's entrance into the kingdom of heaven is equally applicable to the chances of Republican workmen getting employment in the navy yard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--By direction of the President an army retiring board will convene at the call of the President thereof at Port Snelling, Minnesota, for the examination of such officers as may be ordered before it.

COHOES, N.Y., Oct. 28.--This week money was sent by friends to John Biscornett, formerly of this city, who recently went with his family to Colorado. Biscornett worked here for over 30 years in the Weed Becker axe factory.

BOSTON, Oct. 28.--The latest reports in the alleged Baltimore-Boston conspiracy, which has for 48 hours shared with the church scandal the sensational interest of the town, would seem to strengthen the belief that the affair was a blackmailing scheme, as intimated last night.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 28.--A fight occurred this forenoon at the little village of Haymarket, in Prince William County, between three well-to-do farmers named Pat Sweeney, Frank Gibbs, and Charles Meeks.

MONTREAL, Oct. 28.--Diphtheria has broken out in several parts of Prince Edward Island, and threatens to become epidemic in Charlottetown, the capital of the Province.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct., 28.--Quite a sensation was created in court here this morning. John Gorman, a member of the Luzerno Bar and a resident of Hazleton, was employed a year ago by a Hungarian named John Beguere, of Hazleton, to procure a liquor license for him. Gorman procured the license, and charged $60 for his services.

The ninth annual meeting of the American Academy of Medicine began yesterday afternoon at the rooms of the New-York Academy of Medicine, No. 12 West Thirty-first-street. Dr. Albert L. Gihon, Medical Director, of the United States Navy, President of the Academy, called the meeting to order.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 28.--An adjourned meeting of the Albany Presbytery is sitting in this city with closed doors.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--Weyman McCreary, of St. Louis, who is considered the best amateur billiard player in the country, was to-night chosen by the Tournament Committee and the contestants as referee in the coming match between Vignaux, Slosson, and Schaefer. He has not yet been communicated with, but it is believed he will accept.

The schedules of Soutter Co., filed in the Court of Common Pleas, show that the insolvent firm owes $1,712,253.52, of which $955,776.51 is secured, and has assets nominally worth $1,840,072.78, but really worth only $173,912.50.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28.--The Yale University football team played the best college game of the season in this city with the Wesleyan University eleven this afternoon on the Yale athletic field and scored an easy victory.

The sudden death of the soldier who organized the Army of the Potomac and commanded it through the first stages of its career will occasion widespread sorrow among thousands of his old comrades and, indeed, throughout the country.
Car No. 16 of the Cortlandt and Grand Streets Cross-town Line jumped the track on Cortlandt, between Washington and Greenwich streets, at 10:30 yesterday morning.

The storm of yesterday was a very severe one in New-York and its vicinity, and is likely to continue well into to-day. The rainfall here was heavy, 1.15 inches fall being recorded at the United States ...
The action of the United States Civil Service Commission in the Sterling-Bacon case in the Custom House in this city has attracted much attention.

The candidacy of Rastus S. Ransom for Judge of the Superior Court is likely to become unsavory to Tammany Hall. Lawyers remember what a lucky strike Mr. Ransom was supposed to have made when he was appointed Receiver of the Open Board of Stockholders' Building Association, early in 1882.

A very funny scene, of which the Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby was the central figure, occurred a few days ago in a Fourth-avenue car. The doctor and some ladies had just taken their seats when a man who was considerably under the influence of liquor boarded the car and sat down opposite them.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--The demand for steel rails continues to increase and prices have strengthened $1 per ton since last week, making the ruling price now $32 per ton.

ELMIRA, Oct. 29.--The Democratic masses of Chemung County and of the southern tier generally are in open revolt against Gov. Hill. No such mutterings as are heard to-day have ever been uttered since he has dictated the politics of Chemung County.

BOSTON, Oct. 29.--The committee on the Grant eulogy decided to-day to give the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher a medal to the value of about $250 in appreciation of his services in delivering the Grant eulogy. Miss Guiney will receive $100 for her poem, and Mrs. Julia Ward Howe the same amount for her ode. Prof. Brown, the reader of the poem, receives $25.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 29.--A private message received here announces that the Florida Railway and Navigation Company's affairs were to-day placed in the hands of a Receiver, H.R. Duval, formerly General Manager of the Erie fast freight lines.
CHICAGO, Oct 29.--Miss Walters and her half-sister, Mrs. Goode, who were shot last evening by A.J. Burras, are still in a comatose condition and will probably die.

The Board of Excise received a letter from Clarence A. Seward yesterday, in which he inquires whether the Academy of Music license, which will expire in November, will be renewed. Mr. Seward, after stating that he is a stockholder and Director in the Academy, says it has a theatrical and an excise license.

MONTREAL, Oct. 29.--The Chairman of the Civic Finance Committee announced to-day that local improvements would have to be stopped as the city had already run in debt over $500,000, caused by the ertra, expenditure incurred through the smallpox.

Gen. George B. McClellan died suddenly at 2:45 o'clock yesterday morning, at his residence on Orange Mountain, New-Jersey, of heart disease. He had been under medical treatment for over two weeks, but his death was not expected, nor was his condition considered dangerous.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 29.--The Albany Presbytery took no action in the case of the Rev. Erastus Ford, accused of plagiarism, extravagant living, and frivolities.

EAST SAGINAW, Mich., Oct. 29.--The bodies of Albert Schemwelski, a Pole, and John Cleary, victims of last night's bridge disaster, were recovered to-day, making three bodies so far recovered. Three or four others are missing and it is thought they are among the lost. James Twaits, who was rescued last night, will probably die, as he is in a critical condition from internal injuries.

LAREDO, Texas, Oct. 29.--About midnight last night Lieut. W.A. Thurser, of Company E. Sixteenth Infantry, stationed at Fort McIntosh, fatally shot Thomas Collins, proprietor of a saloon known as the "Fashion Theatre."

WHITEWATER, Wis., Oct. 20.--Leo Lesquereaux, the alleged geologist, who is wanted in various parts of the country for a variety of offenses, and who was recently arrested in Milwaukee for stealing a number of valuable books from a State Normal School Professor here, was to-day sentenced to three months' imprisonment in the County Jail.

READING, Penn., Oct. 29.--A laborer at the North Lebanon furnaces, named Josiah Gray, was burned to death yesterday afternoon while packing a valve in an iron hot blast oven. He had with him a tin coal oil lamp.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--The reorganization Trustees of the Reading Railroad Company have reached a stage in the formulation of a plan for the rehabilitation of that property that warrants them in stating that it will be ready for submission next week.

The Brooklyn Eagle should at once add to its staff either a young man of good moral character capable of correctly translating ordinary German prose into idiomatic English, or a devout parson to lecture its editor upon the sinfulness of deceit.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--The operation of trepanning, which was performed on Robert J. Cook at the University Hospital last night, is pronounced a success by the physicians, who say that the first danger is passed. The doctors are hopeful of Mr. Cook's recovery.
BOSTON, Oct. 29.--Taber, the libelant, was the subject of many uncomplimentary allusions in the testimony to-day in the Taber divorce suit.

EMPORIA, Kan., Oct. 29.--In the Walkup trial this morning Mrs. Wallace, mother of the defendant, testified regarding the history of the courtship that Mr. Walkup was very anxious to marry her daughter, but the latter at first laughed at the idea.

A photograph has now been received in England of the portrait of Beethoven recently discovered at Freiburg. It was painted in oil by J. Mahler, of Vienna, in 1815, and it is now in the possession of Herr Victor von Gleichenstein.

BOSTON, Oct. 29.--A year ago a jury in the Superior Civii Court returned a verdict for $3,025 for the plaintiff in the suit of Henry A. Greene against the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, in which Greene sought to recover $4,000 for an injury to a bass viol made by Stradivarius. The case has been finally settled by the payment of $1,800.

TORONTO, Oct. 29.--The 10-year-old daughter of Amos Attwood, of Norway tuburb, who had been missing for two days, was found to-day in an old root house 200 yards from her father's residence, lying on some straw.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29.--A number of students recently offered to wager $50 that one of their classmates, C.H. Tyler, '86, of Winchester, could not walk from Cambridge to Worcester, a distance of 44 miles, in 20 hours.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 29.--Dr. D.G. Overand, who has been practicing in this city 15 years, was arrested to-night for malpractice on Adele S. Leonard, an American domestic, 26 years old, who died this morning.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29.--Judge Moran rendered a final decision to day in the long contested case of J. Young Scammon against Samuel D. Babcock and the United States Mortgage Company of New-York, of which he is President.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29.--John Cameron and 20 other frugal citizens of the village of Hyde Park to-day brought a bill in the Circuit Court to enjoin the officers of that municipality from binding the village by a contract with the Holly Manufacturing Company to pay $51,000 for a new pump and engine at the water works.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 29.--The trial of Lodi Smith for the murder of his father was continued to-day. Counsel for the defense completed their argument, both sides summed up, and Judge Magie charged the jury, who retired at 4 o'clock. They were still out at a late hour last night.

The ninth annual commencement of the training school for nurses of charity and maternity hospitals was held yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction, in the amphitheatre of the new Carnegie Laboratory in East Twentysixth-street.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 29.--The annual statement of the Boston and Albany Railroad for the fiscal year ending Sept. 3O shows that the gross earnings decreased from $8,148,713 in 1884 to $7,637,982 during the past year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--The Star to-night says, regarding the trial by court-martial of the Signal Service class at Fort Myer, that the men who are being tried emphatically deny that they held a meeting and combined for the purpose of obtaining redress.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 29.--Capt. Theodore Yungst, of the North German Lloyd steamer Rhein, was indicted by the United States Grand Jury for carrying 134 passengers more than the laws allows for the vessel.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 29.--The Democratic friends of Judge Isaac H. Maynard in the Prohibition districts of the State will soon have the opportunity of squaring an account with the Democratic candidate for Secretary of State, Mr. Fred Cook, of this city.

BOSTON, Oct. 29.--Carl Schurz has been in this city negotiating for the purchase of the Boston Post. He has made an offer for the property, and the statement is made that it was accepted to-day at a meeting of the corporation, although those most concerned decline to give any information about the matter.

The Cabinet meeting to-day was shorter than usual. Postmaster-General Vilas was the only absentee. The preparation of the annual reports of the Cabinet officers was the only General question considered.
Wong Ta Yin, who replaces On Yang Ming as Chinese Consul at this port, was feted by his compatriots yesterday in genuine Oriental fashion at No. 16 Mott-street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--First Lieut. George H. Evans, Tenth Cavalry, has been appointed to act as inspector on certain Signal Service property at Fort Thomas, Arizona, reported as unserviceable and requiring the action of an inspector, and for which Second Lieut. Robert B. Watkins, Signal Corps, is responsible.
Mrs. Louisa Hollingsworth Whyte, wife of ex-Senator William Pinkney Whyte, died at her residence, No. 87 West Chase-street, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, from a complication of diseases.

A "grand" Democratic mass meeting and reception to Gov. David B. Hill was held in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening. The rain poured down in a truly Democratic manner that made the blue and red lights burned outside the Academy sputter wildly.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 29.--The village of New-Hartford, in Litchfield County, suffered severely from a fire which broke out in Patrick Myers's saloon at 4 o'clock yesterday morning.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 29.--President Porter has sent to the corporation his resignation of the Presidency of the college, the resignation to take effect at Commencement in the latter part of June.
QUEBEC, Oct. 29.--The Riverside Worsted Factory has been obliged to dispose of the balance of its stock by auction and close its doors, owing to the lack of a market for its goods in Canada.

MONTREAL, Oct 29.--The Inspector of Animals boarded the steamer Three Rivers while on her way up to Montreal with a cargo of sheep from Yamaska, and seized 500 of the animals, which were suffering from scab. They were at once sent to the abattoirs and killed.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 29.--The dome of St. John's College in this city was struck and fired by lightning this evening and, owing to its extreme height, burned fiercely for some time before water could be got up to it.

A special examination of applicants for the position of Weigher in the United States Customs Service at this port will occur in the room of the local Civil Service Examining Board, Post Office Building, to-day.

Louis P. Haver, the proprietor and publisher of Thompson's Bank Note Reporter, who was recently convicted of a misdemeanor in sending annoying letters for the purpose of extorting money, was arraigned before Recorder Smyth, in Part 1. of the Court of General Sessions, yesterday morning, for sentence.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 29.--The Gallatin County Grand Jury at Bozeman, Montana, have discovered a startling condition of affairs in the accounts of some of the lately retired county officers.

BOSTON, Oct. 29.--The casting of the 54ton gun at the South Boston Iron Works was a failure. The men, upon stripping the mold from the gun, found that owing to the unequal cooling caused by the core having given way on one side during the process of casting it cracked open, destroying the gun, which will have to be recast.
The Taxpayers' Association of the City of New-York, composed almost entirely of Germans, met last evening at Beethoven Hall, in East Fifth-street.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 29.--The Courier-Journal publishes a long interview with Senator Beck upon the Johnson-Grant-Depew matter. Mr. Beck was a Representative from Kentucky in Congress during Johnson's impeachment, and all of his recollections are contrary to the theories of Mr. Depew.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--Lightning tonight struck and ignited a tank containing 400 barrels of benzine, at Gibson's Point, causing a loss of about $3,000. The flames were confined to the tank, and no further damage was done.

ITHACA, Oct. 29.--Some 25 Professors and students will participate in the Cornell tennis tournaments on Saturday. The athletic council has decided to bring Cornell into close contact with Eastern colleges in the several athletic sports, and they will therefore send representatives to the American intercollegiate meeting in New-York.
Senator SHERMAN made his first speech in Virginia last evening. It confirmed the wisdom of the police of eminent Republicans going into the South to argue the cause of the party.
The American Oriental Society held its regular semi-annual meetings on Wednesday and yesterday. Three sessions were held--one at the residence of A.J. Cotheal and two in Columbia College.
COLORADO, Texas, Oct. 29.--Deputy Sheriff Wayne Parks was killed at an early hour this morning by an unknown person lying in ambush.

Z.M. Ward, the Paterson lawyer who was shot on Wednesday afternoon by Thomas A. Dowling, was quite uneasy last night regarding his condition and the probable result of his wound, as the physicians, after repeated trials, had been unable to find the bullet.

The ease of the Consolidated Electric Light Company against the Edison Electric Light Company, to restrain the latter from using fibrous filaments for carbons in the incandescent electric lamps, came up on demurrer before Judge Wallace, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday.

In the security vault of the American Safe Deposit Company, Fifth-avenue and Fortysecond-street, one's valuable personal effects are beyond the reach of harm, loss, risk, or interference of any kind, and are always accessible to the owner. Private safes from $10 a year upward.--Exchange.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 29.--A female sea lion, supposed to be the one that escaped from Druid Hill Park, Baltimore, a few weeks ago, was killed in the Satilla River, 75 miles south of here, on Sunday.

NEWBURG, Oct. 29.--Zach Masten, for some years a traveling salesman for the Newburg wholesale grocery and shipping firm of William O. Mailler Co., is short from $300 to $600 in his accounts, being money that he had collected from Chester and Port Jervis merchants.
BOSTON, Oct. 29.--The trouble between Mr. Fuller, of the Traveller, and Chairman Beard, of the Republican State Committee, has been amicably settled.

VICKSBURG, Oct. 29.--Under order of the United States Circuit Court Mr. Frank S. Bond, President of the Cincinnati, New-Orleans and Texas Pacific Road, was appointed Receiver of the Vicksburg and Meridian Road.

PHILIPPOPOLIS, Oct. 29.--The war fever has abated considerably during the past few days. The schools have been reopened and affairs are assuming a normal aspect.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 29.--A number of prominent citizens have tendered the Hon. J.L. M. Curry, the new Minister to Spain, a public banquet as a testimonial of their high esteem for him and their appreciation of his pre-eminent qualifications for the position to which he has been appointed.

The annual meeting of the United Hebrew Charities of the City of New-York was held last night at No. 58 St. Mark's-place. During the year ending Oct. 1 the Executive Committee held 39 meetings, and acted upon 2,615 new applications for aid and 2,377 cases for reinvestigation.

ALBANY, Oct. 29.--The Democratic Convention of the Third Assembly District of this (Albany) county nominated Norton Chase on the hundredth ballot.

LONDON, Oct. 29.--One of the most daring robberies on record occurred last night in the vicinity of Carlisle. Netherby Hall, the residence of Sir Frederick Ulrich Graham, was robbed of most of its valuables by a gang of burglars.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 29.--A special cable dispatch to the Globe says: "A letter appears in the London Times which is believed, on good evidence, to have been written by Lord Bramwell, condemning the action of those who are urging a reprieve for Riel.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 29.--Alexander Murdock, a boy of 14, was arrested a week ago in this city. He was charged with nothing in particular, but nevertheless was kept in confinement at the Central Police Station until to-day.

PETERSBURG, Va., Oct. 29.--Senator Sherman spoke here to-night in the Academy of Music to a crowded audience. The stage was filled with white people, while the body of the building and galleries were occupied by colored people, the outskirts of the crowd being fringed with whites.

READING, Penn., Oct. 29.--Robesonia Furnace, at Robesonia, in this (Berks) County, which has been closed for the past two years while being enlarged, resumed operations today with a large force of men. Its capacity is now about 500 tons a week.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 29.--David B. Vinton, of Southbridge, on trial at the Superior Court for killing his father with a cart stake, was acquitted this morning on the ground that he acted in self-defense.

Egbert were among those present. Prof. Charlton T. NEWARK, Oct. 29.--Timothy Regan, of Orange, met his sister and Michael McCarthy, of New-York, on their way to be married to-day and assaulted the intended husband. He was arrested. Regan some days ago assaulted Father Fleming because he had published the marriage of his sister and McCarthy.

READING, Penn.,Oct. 29.--Clayton Bucher and James Haller, two young men who were partridge shooting behind the hills of Adamstown, to-day about noon started a cover. Haller raised his gun and fired, missing the birds. His companion drew his gun to his shoulder to try his luck, when the gun was accidentally discharged, blowing off the back of Haller's head. Haller died almost instantly. He was 20 years of age.
BOSTON, Oct. 29.--The Powlett pneumatic gun carriage was subjected to a private test here to-day which was in every way successful.

BOSTON, Oct. 31.--Contrary to expectation the Taber divorce hearing was not continued to-day. All the principals were on hand promptly, and the court room was crowded, as usual, when the Judge came in; but Mr. Butterworth, Mrs. Taber's counsel, asked for a postponement until Monday, as he was ill.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31.--The State Board of Equalization at its last meeting made a 12 per cent. increase in the assessment roll of property in this city and county. NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 1.--All Saints' Day was observed with the usual solemnity in all the Roman Catholic churches here. NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Nov. 1.--The Trustees of Williams College had a meeting yesterday and voted President Carter an indefinite vacation. It is understood that this is caused by President Carter's health, which has been poor of late, and not because of any dissatisfaction on either side.

A draft of thoroughbreds from the Erdenheim stud farm will be sold at auction at Jerome Park to-morrow morning at 11 o'clock. Nineteen head are catalogued for sale, including the imported stallion Midlothian, four broodmares, a trio of 3-year-olds, four 2-year-olds, and seven yearlings.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 1.--The Democratic candidate for Secretary of State appears to be impressed with the prevailing want of confidence in the head of the ticket.

LITTLE ROCK, Nov. 2.--Reports from the Indian Territory say that Sam Newton was shot, according to Choctaw law, to-day for the murder of his wife in 1884. Newton was a Choctaw Indian. He killed his wife on the public highway, having persuaded her to accompany him on a journey.
Mr. Wilkie Collins, who has been hard at work during the Autumn on a new novel and a new play, has gone to Ramsgate for a few weeks to recuperate in his favorite sea air.

ORTONVILLE, Minn., Nov. 2.--A lunatic named Herrich fired the county building last night and perishes in the flames. Tim Corwin, confined in the same room for drunkenness, says the lunatic made an assault on him, overturning the stove and firing the building. The loss to the county is $3,000. WASHINGTON, Nov. 2.--The QuartermasterGeneral in his annual report says the necessity of assembling the troops in larger and more permanent posts near Indian reservations and in proximity to the great strategic points of the country adjacent to its valuable public reservations, harbors, and ports becomes daily more and more apparent.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 2.--Articles of incorporation of the St. Paul Ice Palace and Winter Carnival Association were filed to-day, the capital stock being $15,000. Work on the ice palace will be begun at the earliest moment practicable.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 2.--A searching investigation into the alleged murder of Benjamin Burton proves beyond a doubt that the man committed suicide. It was found that he had previously purchased a pistol and several stowed away among his effects.

HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 3.--Hattle Egan, the girl who diappeared from her home in NewLebanon on Oct. 10, was discovered on Hancock Mountain Saturday. She had been wandering in the woods for 20 days without food except nuts, which are abundant. When found she was in a deplorable condition. No cause is assigned for her leaving her home.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 3.--Three men arrived here lately from New-York with a large quantity of jewelry consigned here. They engaged an office ostensibly to make sales, but they had no money to pay the customs duty.

MONTREAL, Nov. 3.--William A. Ashe, who has spent a year in an observing station at North Bay, on the north side of Hudson Straits gives some of his experiences during the year. Snow fell on 147 days and rain on 40 days.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6.--At a meeting to-day of the Directors of the German Society the agent reported that immigration to the West is on a decrease. RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 6.--A woman, partially demented, giving her name as Mary Davidson, appeared on the streets here to-day. She came to this place from Hudson, N.Y.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 6.--David Collins died at Fayetteville, near this city, in November, 1884, after making a will bequeathing property worth $100,000 to his son and $50 apiece to his three daughters and their children. CLEVELAND, Nov. 6.--A peculiar accident occurred this afternoon, resulting in the death of John Boehm. He was driving through Ioniastreet, when one of the wheels of the wagon went into a deep hole in the pavement. Boehm was thrown from his seat and struck the curb head first. He was picked up dead, his neck having been broken. He was a married man and owned a great deal of property in the Twenty-fourth Ward.

YORKVILLE, S.C., Nov. 6.--Mrs. Mary Ellen Williams, colored, has been sentenced to be hanged on Feb. 12 next. She married a widower, with three children, early in the Spring. TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 6.--The loss caused by the destruction of Chinatown amounts to about $25,000. The burned buildings were mere shanties, but a large quantity of merchandise was consumed. The buildings were fired by the anti-coolie agitators, who expelled the Chinese, so that in case they should ever return they would have no habitations. There were only two Chinamen in the city at the time of the fire, all the others having, been driven out.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Nov. 8.--Marfield and Beecher, the most desperate burglars ever captured in this vicinity, broke jail here to-night by sawing off the bars in the upper corridor and dropping to the ground, 10 feet below.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 8.--It has been learned from Vancouver that indictments have been found against 32 persons for participation in the outrages against the Chinese at Tacoma. Warrants for the arrest of the persons indicted have been placed in the hands of United States Marshal J.W. George,

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8.--Private advices from Yokohama announce the loss of the yacht Loiterer on Oct. 16 off the Japanese coast, near Simoda. The Loiterer was owned by Dr. Weld, of Boston, who, accompanied by Dr. Elliott and Mr. Charles Longfield, was on a cruise. All the persons aboard the yacht were saved, but a valuable collection of curios was lost.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8.--The Tribune prints this morning the results of inquiries made by its representatives in the 33 largest cities in the United States in point of population relative to the management and tariff of local telephone exchanges.

An Advertiser reporter yesterday saw a beautiful piece of jewelry which has a very interesting history; it is not likely that there is another such in America. It is a present from the Emperor of Austria to a little child here in the city.

--The Athenoeum says that the reading public will be disappointed if they expect any new information in the promised American edition of Carlyle's "Reminiscences." Its chief feature will be "the correction of a number of small errata, including some alterations and omissions in the English edition."
CLEVELAND, Nov. 8.--The singular death of a boy is reported from Canton. Arthur Criss was severely bitten in the hand several months ago by a rat, which was dying from a dose of "Rough on Rats."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 9.--The people of two villages in this county are greatly excited over the fact that a pretty young girl is missing from each. Near Baldwinsville James Selieck has lived for many years on a farm, and has two sons who have always borne good reputation.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 8.--The preparations for the opening of the third America's Exposition on Tuesday have all been completed, and the event will be a great popular demonstration.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 8.--John G. Lonngren's store was entered last night through a rear window and several hundred dollars' worth of clothing and men's furnishings were stolen. Officers are looking for the thieves and the goods.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8.--Manton Marble, who returned from Europe a few days ago, has reported in person to Secretary Bayard and President Cleveland the results of his confidential mission, in which he has been employed since last May.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the delegates from the German bakers said that their fellow-workmen in 15 different cities had expressed their determination to send delegates to the bakers' convention that is to be held in this city.
OGDENSBURG, Nov. 8.--St. Lawrence County gives Davenport a majority over Hill of 6,234 votes.

MONTREAL, Nov. 8.--Capt. Smeltzer, of the ship Scotia, notified the owners to-day that smallpox broke out on board 24 hours after they left Blc, and, on account of contrary winds, it was five days before they reached Sydney, Cape Breton, by which time the patient was beyond recovery.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 8.--William Schaude and two companions were going up Gist-street this morning about 2 o'clock when Schaude was attacked from the rear and dangerously stabbed in the neck. The injured man and his friends say they know the party who made the assault, but refuse to give his name. The affair is very mysterious and the police are trying to clear it up. Schaude is still living, but probably will not recover.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 8.--Mrs. Warren Derthick, of Bedford Township, is prostrated over a terrible mistake on her part which resulted in the death of her 6-year-old daughter.

Cavanagh visited the Star Theatre on Saturday evening, and between the acts went into the barroom in the basement of the building, where he purchased a glass of whisky for 15 cents. BALTIMORE, Nov. 8.--The Rev. Dr. O'Connell, bearer of the decrees of the late Plenary Council approved by the Pope, is expected to reach this city early in the present week. He sailed on Saturday a week ago, and may arrive in New-York at any time. He will, before publishing any of the matters, confer with Archbishop Gibbons.

A.W. Hight, of Centralia, Wyoming Territory, has recently had an experience in Spiritualism of a more practical, businesslike nature than the vapory manifestations usually presented for the regalement of believers.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 8.--The Porte has renewed the contract with the Austrian Lloyds for the transportation of troops from Asia Minor to Salonica. The Government has armed 60,000 irregulars in Albania and Macedonia with Martini rifles and has informed the powers that that a Servian invasion of Bulgaria will be regarded as casus belli.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8.--Janitor Vance Wilson, colored, took to his home in Fulton-street last night a pig's head. His wife, who two years ago was the Widow Thompson, was ill in bed.
LIMA, Nov. 8, via Galveston, Texas.-- The flag upon which Piura declared its independence has been brought to this city and will be placed in a museum here.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 8.--Andrew R. Geistwite, charged with firing the store of Henry Wolf, a cabinet manufacturer, which was destroyed Saturday night, was arrested by Officer Roadman this evening and locked up for a hearing. Geiswite, it is alleged, was seen near the building just before the fire by several women, who say he ran away when he saw them.

READING, Penn., Nov. 9.--A special committee of the City Council, appointed to examine the accounts of ex-City Solicitor Wayne Hayman, reported this evening that Mr. Hayman was short $1,000, which had been collected by him and had not been turned into the Treasury. Ex-Solicitor Hayman, it is said, claimed an offset for extra services. He left here about two months ago for Missouri, where he is engaged in ranching.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 9.--James Gibson, of St. Louis, was shot and mortally wounded at Jackson to-day by Watchman Strong, of the Illinois Central Railroad. Gibson arrived on the early train and asked to be allowed to warm by the fire in the yard. He wanted to replenish the fire when Strong knocked him down and shot him in the abdomen. Strong fled.

MUSKEGON, Mich., Nov. 9.--The schooner R.B. King left Chicago Friday night, light, bound for Muskegon. During the heavy gale Saturday evening she attempted to enter this harbor, but was dashed to pieces against the pier.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 9.--The National Flying Target Company has been forced to make an assignment. The liabilities will probably exceed $15,000; nominal assets about $10,000.

GLAVESTON, Nov. 9.--The results of yesterday's agreement between the Citizens' Committee and the State Executive Committee of the Knights of Labor were manifest on all sides to-day. Every Knight being at his post, the wharves, railroad yards, and cotton presses presented scenes of the greatest activity.

When the Cutting estate case came up before Surrogate Rollins yesterday, Mr. Bartlett, of Mrs. Heyward Cutting's counsel, asked for attachments for the Wall-street brokers who had been subpoenaed but were not present.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 9.--In the case of James McCormick, the young farmer indicted for abducting and marrying Mary Anna Vanderveer, the 14-year-old daughter of D. Augustus Vanderveer, the jury to-day rendered a verdict of guilty after deliberating only five minutes. It is rumored that McCormick has run away, but his friends say he is in Trenton, and will return for sentence to-morrow.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9.--Before the Kent Club of the Yale Law School, Prof. William G. Sumner talked to-night about high school education and assistance to the unemployed.

BOSTON, Nov. 9.--Gov. Robinson, upon the recommendation of the Attorney-General, issued a requisition upon the Governor of Maryland, this afternoon, for the extradition of A.L. Mellon, of Baltimore, against whom an indictment, has been found in the alleged conspiracy case. Inspectors Gerraughty and Houghton left at once for Baltimore.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 9.--A fearful disaster occurred on Lake Superior, off Port Arthur, early Friday night. The ironclad steamer Algoma, of the Canadian Pacific Railroad, was wrecked and 37 lives lost, the crew of 13 sailors and two passengers only being saved.

A package of of 150 letters, all addressed to Henry Smith, No. 21 Cortlandt-street, were found in the East River at the foot of Washington-street, Brooklyn, on Sunday.

BOSTON, Nov. 9.--The new Hollis-Street Theatre was opened to-night. This elegant house stands on Hollis-street, between Washington and Tremont, in an accessible neighborhood. The new theatre was crowded to-night by an audience which came from among the best people in Boston.
Frederick Cocheu, examiner at the First Division Stores of the Appraising Department, has been removed from office by recommendation of Appraiser McMullen.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 9.--The members of the Class of '87 of Cornell University have developed into genuine college martyrs, and their trials and tribulations are only equaled, in their opinion, by those of the Patriarch Job.

RANGOON, Nov. 9.--The reply of King Theebaw of Burmah to the British ultimatum has been received, and is hostile and inadequate.
CLEVELAND'S, Nov. 9.--Clevland's new Music Hall was opened to-night with a grand musical festival. The hall, which seats 4,500 persons, is pronounced perfect in arrangement and acoustic qualities.
BUFFALO, Nov. 9.--The elevator blockade that has lasted most of the time for a month has put quite another face to the situation in Buffalo Harbor.

The New-York Indian Association held the first meeting of the current year yesterday morning in the chapel of the Broadway Tabernacle. The President of the association, Mrs. D. P. Kidder, in discussing last year's work, paid President Cleveland a compliment for his attitude toward the red man.

BOSTON, Nov. 9.--Just at the close of the session of the Supreme Court this afternoon Judge Charles Allen filed his decision in the notorious Taber divorce case, granting a decree nisi to Frederick J. Taber and dismissing the cross-libel of Anna J. Taber.
REGINIA, Northwest Territory, Nov. 9.-- Riel has been respited until the 16th inst. Preparations are already being made for his execution on that date, although the warrant has not yet arrived.

The barracks for the soldiers at Camp Grant, in Riverside Park, have been completed, and yesterday the men moved in. The barracks are built in L shape, 60 feet long and 25 feet wide at the base of the L.
The Westchester County Grand Jury yesterday found an indictment for rape against the Rev. Robert F. White, Pastor of the Methodist church at Purdy's Station.

The interest of Mr. GLADSTONE'S second "stumping tour" in Scotland is almost purely personal. The spectacle of a man of 76 undertaking such a task is sufficient to account for the enthusiasm that attends his progress.

COLUMBUS, Nov. 9.--The strike of the coal miners in the Hocking Valley is far-reaching in its effect, and has already caused the closing of the railroad workshops of the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Company, in this city, and the laying off of several hundred workmen and train crews.

WELINGTON, Kan., Nov. 9.--The Purcell House, in this town, was burned to the ground this afternoon with all its contents. In the excitement attending the outbreak of the fire Mr. Purcell's boy, 18 months old, was forgotten.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 9.--The sexton of the Western Cemetery made a remarkable discovery this afternoon while exhuming the body of Mrs. J.W. Taylor for reinterment.

The presence of a large and brilliant concourse of spectators at the Academy of Music, last evening, indicated that the public's fondness for Italian opera in general, and for "Lucia di Lammermoor" in particular, is not quite as extinct as a small but noisy fraction of the community would have people believe.

BATH, Me., Nov. 9.--At a meeting of the Board of Trade this afternoon a resolution was adopted concurring in the opinion of the NewYork Maritime Exchange that the foreign Commerce of the country will perish unless the United States Government steps in and assists American ship owners. They agree that the French plan will be satisfactory of the ship owners of Bath.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9.--George Chipman, of Fairhaven, while cleaning out a cider barrel to-day put in some chemicals to assist in the process. Instantly an explosion followed. There was a loud report and the barrel was blown to pieces. Chipman was knocked down and his neck, face, and hands were badly scorched. His mustache and eyebrows were burned off.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 9.--The Assessors of the town of Hoosick assessed the value of the real property of the Boston, Hoosac Tunnel, and Western Railway in that town at $255,000.

The funeral of the late Henry Underhill, the veteran soldier, who died at the residence of his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Cora L. Underhill, in this city, last Saturday, occurred yesterday, and was without display of any kind.
PESTH, Nov. 9.--Fifty Servians recently crossed the frontier near Trn and attacked a Bulgarian outpost guard of 10 men. One of the Servians was killed. The attacking party subsequently retired.

The people of Stroudsburg, Penn., have raised $20,000, which they propse to lend to John C. Ryie Co., of Paterson, N.J., at 5 per cent, if that firm will remove their extensive silk throwing establishment to the former place.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 9.--Gentlemen in this city interested in racing have formed a society to be known as the Bascomb Jockey Club. It is the intention or the club to have an annual racing meeting. The first meeting will begin Dec. 1 next and continue for five days.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9.--Frank C. Tilton, a well known Board of Trade man, shot himself in the head at his residence, in Stanton-avenue, this afternoon, with intent to commit suicide, and will probably die.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9, 1885. It is expected that William E. Smith, the re cently appointed Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, will assume the duties of that office to-morrow.
A fair in aid of the new Manhattan Hospital, at One Hundred and Thirty-first-street and Tenth-avenue, began last evening in the University Club Theatre, Madison-avenue and Twenty-sixth-street.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 9.--It the learned to-day that the Texas and St. Louis Railroad will at once be changed from narrow to standard gauge.
There was only one race at Fleetwood, on the grounds of the New-York Driving Club, yesterday, and the prospect of a heavy track diminished the expected crowd.
LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 9.--The Chicago limited express on the West Shore Road, which left New-York at 6 o'clock last evening, had only a small number of passengers.
The Government of the United States has succeeded by treaty with China in putting a very close restriction upon the immigration of Chinese to this country.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 9.--O.D. Crocker was bound over to the Court of Common Pleas here this afternoon under $3,000 bail on a charge of obtaining 17,500 shares of Arizona mining stock ...
LONDON, Nov. 9.--Mr. Gladstone started from Hawarden to-day for Edinburgh in good health and spirits. In replying to an address at Chester, the ex-Premier said:
Capt. Conklin, of the schooner Magellan, which was picked up in an abandoned condition by the pilot boat Charles H. Marshall and ...
BALTIMORE, Nov. 9.--Archbishop Gibbons, who has just returned from Washington, says he expect Dr. O'Connell's arrival to-morrow with the decrees of the late Plenary Council, approved by the Pope.
CHESTER, Penn., Nov. 9.--Roach's yard started this morning with 170 men. At 7 o'clock upward of 1,000 men had assembled around the gates, and when the whistle gave its accustomed ...

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 9.--Deputy County Clerk Eli B. Morgan was arrested this afternoon on a warrant issued by William H. Davis, a Democratic Justice of the Peace, charging him with stealing the election returns from the Court House on Friday afternoon.
EL PASO, Texas, Nov. 9.--The settlements in Southern New-Mexico are again terror-stricken by the presence of hostile Indians.
NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 9.--The report of the National Cotton Exchange for October says of the cotton crop: Picking has progressed satisfactorily during the past month, the proportion ...

Mrs. Percy Smith, a cabin passenger on the Cunard steamship Aurania, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, died on board that vessel on Nov. 8. She had been suffering for some time from an abscess. She was a resident of Brooklyn, whither the body was taken.

Every seat in Historical Hall, Brooklyn, was occupied last night when the members of the Broolklyn Training School for Nurses, clad in their blue and white dresses, filed upon the platform, the front seats being taken by the 10 ...

COHOES, N.Y., Nov. 10.--The high water in the Mohawk River seriously interferes with canal navigation here. Canalboats in attempting to cross the river frequently break their tow lines and float down on the State dam.

JOLIET, Ill., Nov. 10.--A convict named James Young, serving here a 10-year sentence from Carroll County, recently made a confession that he was the murderer of Dr. Allen, who was found dead in his residence at Sandwich, Ill., about five years ago.
Sixty-three horses were sold at MadisonSquare Garden yesterday. Among them were many fine animals and several winners of prizes in the horse show.
Several prominent Irish-American gentlemen met Monday evening to consider the question of supporting the fund to aid Mr. Parnell in his Parliamentary agitation. Eugene Kelly presided.

EVERGREEN, Ala., Nov. 10.--J.A. Stewart, a merchant, at Ireland, Monroe County, was assassinated last night. He was sitting in his store with two friends when a concealed enemy fired on him. The gun was loaded with buckshot. The assassin is unknown.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 10.--Mr. Henry Mosler, the American artist, now a resident of Paris, has received an order from H.H. Warner, of this city, to paint three pictures for his private gallery.

TOCCOA, Ga., Nov. 10.--A mysterious murder is under investigation in Habersham County. Jasper Henderson, a well known citizen here, had quarreled with his wife last weak, when she left him and went home.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 10.--President Adams's inauguration is set down for Thursday of next week, and, judging from present indications, it will be a big affair. Several thousand invitations have been extended, and not a few colleges are expected to send representatives.
MONTREAL, Nov. 10.--The Bank of Montreal's statement for the six months ending with Oct. 31 is published today, and when compared wich former years shows the following profits:

LONDON, Nov. 10.--Mr. Gladstone's health has not been affected in the least by his exertions yesterday. He slept soundly last night and not a particle of his hoarseness reappeared to-day. He made no political speech to-day, but has taken considerable walking exercise in Dalmeny Park.
One of the most important and interesting events of the current theatrical season will take place at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight, where Signor Salvini will act the character ...

ATCHISON, Kan., Nov. 10.--Judge David Martin rendered a decision to-day in the whisky injunction cases recently brought before him by Attorney-Greneral Bradford against five prominent saloons of this city under the nuisance clause of the prohibitory act.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Nov. 10.--A distinguished gentleman of this city, who has shown in the United States Senate an intimate acquaintance with questions concerning finances, said to-day that Minister McLane's dispatch to the State Department relative to the new monetary convention between France, Greece, Italy, and Switzerland was misleading.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Nov. 10.--The last spike in the California Southern Railway was driven yesterday at Cajon Pass. This gives the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad through connection to the Pacific coast, with San Diego as its terminus.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--Since the birth of her child three weeks ago Mrs. Susan Blatchere, wife of the principal mechanic at the Standard Theatre, has been delirious.

The auction sale of seats for the Brooklyn Philharmonic concerts, which begins on Nov. 21 at the Academy of Music, took place last evening at the Brooklyn Art Association rooms. The first box sold for $100.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10.--Carl Tiernann and his wife, Bertha, live in a tenement house on Oak-street, this city. They have been married for some years, and have three children.
A ludicrous incident occurred at a rabbit hunt near Hohokus, N.J., on Saturday. The bound started the "cottontail" in a piece of short brush on a side hill.
LIMA, Nov. 10, via Galveston.--Ica has been reoccupied by Government troops under Gen. Echenique, at whose approach the rebels retired.
The Stevens Institute football eleven will play a match to-day against the Lafayette Club at Hoboken. On Saturday they will play against Rutgers College.
Mahone weighed 92 pounds before election. Now he could be weighed on grocer's scales.--Boston Post.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--The President has removed James S. Smart, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Fifteenth District of New-York, and in his place has appointed Col. Samuel J. Tilden, Jr., of Gov. Hill's staff.
The Newark police are hunting for a pretty 16-year-old girl who is charged with having swindled a number of Newark tradesmen.

When Edward L. Francke returned from Europe late in June, and a few days afterward took to his home a young bride, his friends called him a very lucky man. He agreed with them, for he said that the girl he had married was not only beautiful, as every one could see, but was heir prospective to a fortune.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--The representatives of the railroads running east from this city today received orders from New-York to advance freight rates to the East on Nov. 23 to a basis of 25 cents on grain to New-York.
LONDON, Nov. 10.--A private telegram from Rangoon states that war between Burmah and the Indian Government has been formally declared.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Nov. 10.--The steamer Noma, owned by Ohlernocher Brothers, of this port, and valued at $15,000, caught fire in some unknown manner while lying at the dock here last night and was badly damaged. Capt. Sleuky and the cook, named Beach, narrowly escaped being burned to death. The loss is estimated at $7,000: insurance only $500.

The Church of the Heavenly Rest was well filled last evening at the wedding of Miss Kate Irene Hamel, daughter of Lieut. Hamel, of the Old Guard, to Mr. William Edward Schaffner. The ushers were Messrs. I.H. Hamel, Charles E. Schaffner, George Miller, and George R. Farlee.

READING, Penn., Nov. 10.--The managers of the Home for Widows and Single Women, a public charitable institution supported by general contributions, are having a handsome stone structure built in East Reading.

After rehearsing all Monday night at the Star Theatre with the elaborate scenery of "Romeo and Juliet" in position Mr. Abbey determined at 5 o'clock yesterday morning to postpone the play until to-night. The machinery did not work smoothly enough to suit him, and he made up his mind to lose another day for the sake of securing a perfect representation. The tragedy will surely be given to-night, with Miss ...

The State Civil Service Commission yesterday approved certain amendments to the rules and regulations governing the examination of applicants for positions in the public employ, submitted by the City Supervisory Board.
