"L'Africaine" will be sung at the Academy of Music this evening, with Mme. Hauk as Selika, Signor Giannini as Vasco, and Signor De Anna as Neiusko.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 10.--Martin Fryer, of White Plains, N.Y., committed suicide here today by taking poison. He left his family at White Plains and followed a young woman to this city. In a note found on his body he stated that he loved the woman, and had taken the drag because he could not live without her. Fryer was 40 years old.

A suit in which the Executors of the will of George A. Osgood were plaintiffs and Theodore Moss and Lester Wallack were defendants was tried before Judge Beach and a jury in the Supreme Court yesterday.

The contributions to the Grant Monument fund yesterday amounted to $349. This brought the total figures up to $97,256 41. Preliminary work connected with the canvass of the city is under way and will soon be finished.
Archbishop Corrigan, the Very Rev. Mr. John M. Farley, and Mr. Eugene Kelly left yesterday for Baltimore, and at Philadelphia ...

NEWBURG, Nov. 10.--Judge Brown has rendered his decision in the case of the appeal of the West Shore Railroad Company from the assessment of its road as made by the Assessors of the city of Newburg in 1884.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 10.--William N. Carpenter, Vice-President of the Peninsular Stove Company, was driving a young, spirited horse down Fifth-street, this afternoon, when his horse shied, violently overturning the buggy and throwing the occupant several feet.

Mr. and Mrs. David C. Bowne celebrated the fifteenth anniversary of their marriage in very pleasant fashion at their home, No. 124 River Terrace, Hoboken, last evening. Mr. Bowne is one of the principal European buyers for R.H. Macy Co., of this city, and he has a very extensive acquaintance.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 10.--The officers of the United States court returned to-day from Jackson, Tenn., where 42 moonshiners were tried, all except four being convicted.

LITTLE ROCK, Nov, 10.--O'Neal Stevens Company, the leading wholesale and retail dealers in books and stationary, failed yesterday. This morning O'Neal had Stevens arrested, charging him with embezzlement.

DEMING, New-Mexico, Nov. 10.--The band of Indians who raided the Missouri Florida Cattle Company's ranch Saturday killed a man named Hay, a rancher at Indian Springs, the same night. The same band was seen Sunday night near Cambray Station, 20 miles east of here.

As a specimen of an "indignation meeting" the effort made to please Cyrus W. Field by a few of his friends in Tappan Monday night was simply amusing. The correspondent that made the Associated Press put 130 people in it figured on the basis of the old nursery rhyme which tries to prove that "one and one make eleven."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--Capt. Beardslee, commanding the Powhatan, has telegraphed the Secretary of the Navy from Colon that his vessel has been "considerably, not seriously, damaged" in a gale. He will probably be ordered to take her to Key West for repairs, as he suggests, as repairing cannot be done at Colon without great expense and difficulty.

GENESEO, Nov. 10.--Following is the official vote of Livingston County: For Governor --Davenport, (Rep.,) 4,504; Hill, (Dem.,) 3,552; Bascom, (Proh.,) 447; Jones, (Grbk.,) 53. For Lieutenant-Governor--Carr, (Rep.,) 4,538; Jones, ...

VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 10.--The rapid and permanent increasing business of Vicksburg in the last two years is a source of much gratification to the business men and citizens generally. The cotton receipts this year are about 6,000 bales over the corresponding date last season.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 10.--An ancient rusty sabre was found by William A. Thompson, who plowed it up on his farm on Goodwin Point.
A new atlas designed expressly for the needs of business men has just been issued by A.A. Grant, of No. 300 Broadway.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 10.--The Coroner's jury in the case of Mrs. Pratt, who was killed in the accident on the West Shore Railroad, near Little Falls, yesterday morning, have rendered a verdict, charging the railroad company with gross negligence in not having provided a culvert at the place of the accident to carry off the water in the time of a freshet, that place being a natural outlet.

ROME, Nov. 9.--Contrary to the reports erroneously telegraphed from home the Pope's encyclical letter has not yet been published, but will be in a few days. The entire proof sheets of this important document were placed at my disposal on the condition that they should not be communicated to any European newspaper.

BOSTON, Nov. 10.--In the equity session of the Supreme Court to-day, Judge Devens, in the case of Lamb against the New-York and New-England Railroad Company, ordered an injunction to issue to restrain the defendant company from issuing preferred stock to pay off its floating debt.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 10.--Notice has been telegraphed from Columbus this evening to the various parties in interest in this city that application has been made in the Supreme Court for a writ of mandamus to compel the Clerk of the courts in this county to issue certificates of election to the Democratic candidates for the State Senate.
It seems to be the general conclusion that the Republican county ticket was sold out at the recent election by some of the local leaders for money.

A cluster of the barnacles that adhere closely to the political pickings in the County Clerk's office was uncovered by the dredging committee from the Senate yesterday. For the present the sessions will be continued at the Morton House, Fourteenth-street and Broadway.
Some time ago several families living in an up-town apartment house near Fifth-avenue came to the conclusion that there was sewer gas in the house and that they had been poisoned by it.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 10.--A clear, cloudless day, with the thermometer not exceeding 74 , was vouchsafed the good people of the Crescent City for the opening of the North, Central, and South American Exposition.

HENRIETTA, Texas, Nov. 10.--Intelligence has just been received here from Fannin, a small town 15 miles south of here, of one of the most cruel crimes ever perpetrated in North Texas. Elizabeth Sanford, the wife of Charles Sanford, a well-to-do planter, was killed by her own son, Valentine, a boy 13 years old.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--Mr. Frederick Ullman, representing the dry goods firm of Barber, Hartman Co., which failed for $88,000 Nov. 1, to-day met the creditors and offered them 25 cents on the dollar in secured notes running three and six months.

When the guests in the Metropolitan Hotel went down stairs to dinner last evening the double doors through which they had been wont to enter the large restaurant were locked against them. A paper sign said "Entrance on Broadway."

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--The Pennsylvania and Vanderbilt lines are anxious to abandon their limited trains, and have asked the managers of the roads running west and northwest from this city to arrange their time tables ...
BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 10.--By the will of the late John P. Howard, about $500,000 is bequeathed to his sisters, nieces, and friends, including a bequest of $200,000 to his niece, Mrs. ...

MONTREAL, Nov. 10.--Sir Adolphe Caron, Minister of Militia, notified the Health Department to-night to remove the disinfecting building from the Champ De Mars, which is used as a parade ground for the troops.

NYACK, Nov. 10.--The days of tollgates in Rockland County are nearly past, but occasionally in passing through the remote districts of the county one comes across visible reminders of the time when post riders and travelers in vehicles were years ago obliged to pay tribute ...
The Baptist Autumnal Conference for the discussion of current questions began its annual meeting yesterday in the Calvary Baptist Church, on West Fifty-seventh-street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--First Assistant Postmaster-General A.E. Stevenson has submitted to the Postmaaster-General his annual report upon the operations of his bureau for the fiscal year ended June 30.

A statement prepared by the officers of the Charity Organization Society shows that since it began its work in July, 1882, the number of cases of families and persons seeking relief registered on its books is 68,122.

LIVINGSTON, Ala., Nov. 10.--Teddy Meehan, a peddler, was found near here yesterday with his skull crushed and his throat cut. Amos Washington, a colored associate, was captured and confessed that robbery was his motive in committing the murder.

PORT ARTHUR, Ontario, Nov. 10.--The latest information to be gathered here in regard to the sinking of the Canadian Pacific Railway steamer Algoma on Saturday last is that 48 persons were drowned and 2 passengers and 12 of the crew alone survive.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--A little corner of an office at No. 155 Washington-street, in this city, where sewing machine attachments are alleged to be sold, is represented as the once of Stone Murray, agents for a lottery doing business in Louisiana.
Isaac G. Johnson's hen coop got on fire yesterday afternoon. Issac G. Johnson is a Spuyten Duyvil foundryman, and lives on Spuyten Duyvil Hill, not far from King's Bridge.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10.--The details of Senator Stanford's scheme for the establishment in California of a great university were to-day made public for the first time.
Mayor Jonathan Scoville, of Buffalo, is at the Windsor Hotel.
SOPHIA, Nov. 10.--The Bulgarian and Servian patrols on the frontier are daily exchanging shots. The Servians have crossed the frontier near Trn and advanced three miles.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., Nov. 10.--David Tiffany, a well-to-do farmer of the town of Mohawk, died yesterday from lockjaw caused by an injury to his hand in a corn husker. Exactly a year ago his son met a similar fate.

The suit of Franklyn Bassford against Hermann Oelrichs for the recovery of $500, which, he claimed, was due him for painting a picture of the defendant's sloop yacht Hildegard, was continued yesterday morning in the Circuit Court of Kings County before Judge Brown and a jury.

EUFAULA, Ala., Nov. 10.--A dinner was given to Senator Pugh by friends here this afternoon. It is presumed that during his stay here he will take occasion to explain to his constituents what ethics of the Democratic Party prompted him to appoint his nephew Postmaster at this point in opposition to the wishes of the people.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 10.--The arguments in the railroad tax cases were begun in the main branch of the Supreme Court to-day. The contest was opened by ex-Gov. Bedle, who represents the Morris and Essex, the Warren, the Sussex, and the Passaic and Delaware Railroad Company.
HONESDALE, Penn., Nov. 10.--Two years ago Alfred A. Thomas was one of the richest farmers in Clinton Township, this county. He sold his farm and removed with his wife and son to Wyoming County.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Nov. 10.--An attempt was made last night to assassinate Joseph Jeffries, a respected citizen of Centreville, by shooting at him through the window while he was reading a paper. The man who did the shooting has not yet been arrested.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--The city of Chicago covered about 33 square miles, but it was not big enough to-day to contain the 500 members of the National Butter, Cheese, and Egg Association, when their President, John D. McDonald, ...

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 10.--The testimony taken in the inquest relative to the death of Frederick McAllister, the 5-year-old orphan who was caught fast in a clay pit, where he remained for 20 hours until death relieved him from his sufferings, shows that he was pushed into the pit by Edward Townsend, a boy aged 12 years.
"Reader."--The price of the book is $15 and the place of publication No. 82 Nassaustreet.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 10.--The situation to-night touching the settlement of the recent strike does not promise an amicable adjustment. Adjt.-Gen. King arrived in the city last night from Austin to personally investigate the causes which led to the recent boycott.
Owing to the fact that the presence of Secretary Lamar was desired at the Cabinet meeting to-day, the hearing in the telephone case was postponed until to-morrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10.--The arrangements for the funeral of John McCullough are about completed. The private funeral services will be held at his residence, No. 219 East Thompson-street, at 9 o'clock to-morrow evening, when the Rev. Dr. Hunter will officiate.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--The Daily Commercial Bulletin publishes to-day returns from 240 of the leading hog producing counties. As to the quality, the result of the inquiry shows it to be uniformly good, 72 per cent. of the replies making the quality equal to that of last year.

It is extremely annoying to an experienced politician to sell out his party and not get his pay. It is equally annoying to experienced politicians to buy the treachery of another with promise of place and not be able to keep their promise.

GLENCOE, Ontario, Nov. 10.--George J. Pryer, express and telephone agent and Postmaster here, his absconded, taking with him between $6,000 and $7,000 left with him by banks to be expressed. He took a woman with him, leaving his wife in destitute circumstances.

ALBANY, Nov. 10.--Ex-Assemblyman Charles P. Ingersoll, of Chautauqua County, is a candidate for the Clerkship of the new Senate, and he is making an active canvass against John W. Vrooman, who is a candidate for re-election on the strength of the very excellent record he has made during the half dozen years he has held the office.

NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 10.--Two years ago Miss Agnes Corey, the daughter of E.H. Corey, one of the wealthiest citizens of this city, met Albert Lowe, a well-known young man of the West District.
Many men were disappointed at the Liberty-Street Real Estate Exchange yesterday. They met to bid upon up-town real estate advertised for sale at auction by the Executors of the estate of E.D. Morgan.

WINNIPEG, Nov. 10.--The granting of a respite to Riel has roused the people of the Canadian Northwest almost to a frenzy. The course the Government is pursuing gives the impression that the sentence of law will not be carried into effect.

PARIS, Nov. 10.--M. Blanc presided at the opening of the Chamber of Deputies to-day and delivered an address. M. Floquet was elected temporary President, and MM. de la Forge and Blanc Vice-Presidents.

The Tammany braves in the Committee on Organization had a political love feast last evening in Tammany Hall. The great council chamber, which was rarely filled at the meetings held before election, was crowded even beyond the doors. Standing room was at a premium.

SEATTLE, Washington Territory, Nov. 10. --Last night a meeting was held in the opera house, attended by the clergy, lawyers, merchants, manufacturers, and law-abiding citizens generally.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 10.--There were 1,785 cars of wheat standing on the side tracks in Minneapolis this morning, five cars only less than yesterday at the same hour.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 10.--The representatives of the various coal companies doing business in the Hocking and Sunday Creek Valleys held a long meeting here to-day discussing the situation and the effect of the coal miners' strike.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Nov. 10.--William Evans, an extensive coal merchant at Cannonsburg for many years, died suddenly of heart disease this morning. Dr. Christy, a prominent physician of Paris, also died suddenly last night from heart trouble.
ALBANY, Nov. 10.--The following certificates of incorporation were filed to-day: The Eagle Land Company of New-York, capital stock $1,000,000; the Fibre Curling Company of New-York, capital $250,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--The President gave an audience to-day to the committee appointed at the recent conference at Lake Mohonk, New-York, to present to him the result of their deliberations on the Indian question.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10--As the Faculty have forbidden all intercollegiate football, the entire interest of the college in the sport centres in the class games for the championship of the college.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 10.--Social circles here were thrown into turmoil to-day by the announcement that Mrs. Clara Bronner Waterman had applied in the Common Pleas Court, New-York City, for a divorce from her husband, B. Frank Waterman.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 10.--Joseph Lane, a young man of the village of Monroe, Orange County, married Susan Conkling, a good-looking young woman, about a week ago.
Four special services were held in the Madison-Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday. At 8:30 A.M. a meeting for business men was held, led by Bishop Foss.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10.--It was currently stated in financial circles this afternoon that the amended contract between the Baltimore and Ohio and the Reading Railroad Companies has been signed.

An Italian laborer at work on an excavation in a vacant lot in North Eighth-street, near Third-street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, struck his pickaxe into a human skull which was imbedded in the dirt.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 10.--Considerable excitement has been created in this city to-day by the publication in Virginia of a report of the Grand Jury on the official actions of several city officers.
Minnie Simon, a young woman, obtained a summons from Police Justice O'Reilly, in Essex Market Police Court, yesterday, for Rachel Lindenthal, a boarding house keeper at No. 148 Mulberry-street.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 13.--Dr. George O. Warner, of Leicester, died last evening of malignant diphtheria, after a five days' illness. Dr. Warner has practiced medicine in Leicester for 20 years.

His excesses in this direction led to fits of despondency in sober moments.

GENEVA, N.Y., Nov. 13.--Prof. Hitchcock, of Amherst College, is here, with a large force of men, digging for the bones of a mastodon. CLEVELAND, Nov. 13.--Two weeks ago while John C. Coffee, an attorney, was reading an evening newspaper in his parlor some one shot at him, but the bullet went wide of the mark. HALIFAX, Nov. 15.--Two sudden deaths occurred at Pictou this morning. Councilor John Bayliss was taken suddenly ill while sitting in his chair. William Ross, who lives across the street, was sent for, and assisted in removing Bayliss to bed. Bayliss died just as he was lifted on the bed. Ross was placing one of Bayliss's hands on his breast, when he himself dropped dead. Ross was 82 and Bayliss 64.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 16.--About one year ago Q.A. Gates, a well known attorney of this city, opened a letter addressed to another lawyer, named William C. Price, who occupied the same office. The letter contained a collection order from a New-York merchant, which the Wilkesbarre lawyer was to have collected.
DUBLIN, Nov. 16.--The Nationalists of South Londonderry have selected T.M. Healy as their candidate for Parliament.

It is quite likely that "Amorita," under which title Czibulka's new operetta was revealed at the Casino last evening, will have a profitable career. Its story offers opportunities for scenic attire of unusual picturesqueness and brilliancy, and as it enlists, moreover, the services...
About 150 primary school teachers met at School No. 47, in Twelfth-street, yesterday afternoon to exchange views upon Commissioner Holt's proposed schedule for grading salaries.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16.--An autopsy is to be held on Wednesday morning on the brain of John McCullough, the dead actor, in the receiving vault of Monument Cemetery, where the body was placed last Thursday afternoon.
The Brooklyn Young Republican Club held ward elections for members of its Advisory Committee last evening. This body controls the policy of the club and elects its officers.

A political cyclone burst upon the Democracy of Richmond County yesterday, the General Committee of which met at Tompkinsville, Judge John G. Vaughn presiding. A lively time grew out of a desire to know by what authority a late meeting of the committee had...
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 16.--The Cosmopolitan Polo Club, of New-York, beat the Casino Club, of Poughkeepsie, three straight games to-night at the Casino Rink before a large audience.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16.--Maurice Vignaux and George F. Slosson crossed cues to-night at the Central Music Hall in the first game of the 14-inch balk-line tournament for the championship of the world, special purses aggregating $2,500, and the net receipts.

WINNIPEG, Nov. 16.--Word has just been received here that Jackson, who was Riel's lieutenant throughout the rebellion, and who was found insane by a jury, has made his escape from the lunatic asylum at Selkirk.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 16.--Senators Cullom and Harris, of the Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerce, met for the purpose of hearing the views of business men on the issues under consideration. Messrs. B.D, Wood, J.B. Woods, and J.W. Bryant were prepared to answer...

Mr. Thomas Willey and his wife lived together in Boston, Mass., with their children, two boys and a girl. Willey was a bookbinder and his wife kept boarders. Among the inmates of Mr. Willey's house was a young man named John Force.
BELGRADE, Nov. 16.--After desperate fighting yesterday the Servian troops occupied positions at Raptcha. The losses on both sides were heavy.

"Tim" McCarthy, the notorious Oakstreet "dive" keeper, was brought up for trial in Part I, of the Court of General Sessions yesterday, charged with assaulting, on May 25, Kate Barrow, one of the inmates of his house.

The situation in which the President will find himself with reference to the Senate on the meeting of Congress will be in some respects a peculiar one. The majority of the Senators are opposed to the President in politics.
Adrian Gillam, the manager of the Brooklyn Music Hall, at Flatbush and Fulton avenues, is the defendant in a suit for divorce instituted by his wife, Martha Gillam, on the ground of infidelity.
LONDON, Nov. 16.--Ford Randolph Churchill, Secretary of State for India, is suffering from a bad cold, and all his engagements to deliver public speeches have been postponed.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16.--The two south side elevators near Thirty-second-street, in this city, built for the accommodation of the Wabash Railway, have a capacity of 1,000,000 bushels, and are owned in common partnership by Jay Gould, Russell Sage, the Perry Smith estate, Columbus R. Cummings, and A.L. Hopkins.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 16.--W.P. Fishback has addressed the following letter to the Journal in answer to Judge Vincent's charges in his letter to President Cleveland:

NEWPORT, Nov. 16.--According to newspaper reports the facts relating to the death of Benjamin J. Burton were to be presented to the Grand Jury to-day, as it was alleged that he was murdered either by his daughter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.--Chief Naval Constructer Thomas D. Wilson, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy, submits estimates for completing the four double turreted monitors, amounting to $2,923,656, of which $955,842 is for the Puritan, $627,288 for the Terror.

The legal contest over the admission to probate of the will of the late Louis De Comeau will be resumed to-day before Surrogate Stephens, of Richmond County, at New-Brighton. Mr. De Comenu was a broker of this city, and lived at Staten...

RIEL met his fate bravely, without showing either timidity or bravado. His demeanor will doubtless increase the resentment which his sentence has inspired not only among the half breeds of the Northwest, but among the whole French population of Lower Canada.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 16.--The annual meetting of the stockholders of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad was held to-day. The annual report of the President and Directors shows the revenues of the company from, the main stem...

Vice-President Borrowe, of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, filed plans at the Bureau of Buildings yesterday for extensive additions and alterations to the Eqitable Building, at No. 120 Broadway.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 16.--There is considerable excitement among the business men in the city over the means used by the St. Louis, Iron Mountain and Great Southern Railroad Company to prevent the Arkansas Telegraph Company from erecting telegraph poles along the railway from Little Rock to Malvern.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16.--The third of the Class games at Harvard, for the football championship of the college, was played this afternoon on Jarvis Field, between the Juniors and Sophomores.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 16.--A few minutes before the adjournment of court at noon to-day Abe Buzzard, Ike Buzzard, John Lippincott, George Brimmer, and James Clifford, all long term convicts, were arraigned on the charge of jail breaking. All entered pleas of guilty. Sentence was deferred.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16.--The Mayor has issued an order prohibiting employes at the City Hall from smoking during office hours. Asked for the reason he said: "I have gone into offices and found clerks with cigars and pipes in their mouths. Complaints were made about this smoking, which was very offensive.

MONTREAL, Nov. 16.--The wildest excitement reigns in the city, and over every building in the east end the French flag draped with crape floats at half mast. The French newspapers came out with mourning borders and the offices are profusely draped.
PARIS, Nov. 16.--Prime Minister Brisson, in accordance with the programme announced on Saturday, made a statement in the Chamber of Deputies to-day of the intentions of the Government.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16.--Senator Allison, of Iowa, was in the city to-day on his way to Washington. When asked what was likely to be done in Congress this Winter regarding the coinage of silver he replied that he was...

WASHINGTON, Penn., Nov. 17.--The Rev. J.L. Simpson, of Waynesburg, deposited $510 in a cupboard a few days ago for safe keeping. This morning, when he went after it, the money was gone, having been stolen.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 17.--Joseph Fisher, who was struck on the head with a hammer by John Duff, Sr., near Hartwood, Sullivan County, will probably die. His head is paralyzed. He and David Jackson, who has since died, were stabbed twice by John Duff, Jr.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 17.--Andrew J. Bruon, ex-President of the Hot Springs National Bank, was acquitted to-day in the United States District Court. He was charged with making false entries on the books of the bank and with perjury.

Alexander Sweeney, the young man who, with Peter Smith, was charged with the killing of John Hannon, the watchman, at the foot of East Thirty-eighth-street on April 7, was found guilty of murder in the first degree yesterday.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 17.--The creditors of John A. Lowell Co., the engravers and art publishers, held an adjourned meeting to-day, when the special committee reported in the offer of the firm to pay 25 cents on a dollar and on the condition of the affairs of the firm.

The elections which were held in nearly every ward in Brooklyn on Monday evening for members of the Advisory Board of the Young Republican Club resulted in a vindication of President Williams and of the action of the club in indorsing Gen. Woodward for Mayor.

DES MOINES, Nov. 17.--At Eddyville today Mollie McKee, aged 17, pointed a pistol at a young lady friend, saying: "Your money or your life," and pulled the trigger, but the pistol hung fire. She cocked the weapon again, and turned it against her own forehead. The pistol went off, the ball crashing into her brain. She died this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--The President has received the following letter: To his Excellency the Hon. Grover Cleveland, President of the United States of Amercia:

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 17.--The Rev. Arthur S. Hoyt, a graduate of the Auburn Seminary in the Class of '72, and valedictorian of the class, was to-day elected Professor of Rhetoric in Hamilton College. Mr. Hoyt is now Pastor of a Presbyterian church in Oregon, Ill. He was for three years teacher in Roberts College, Constantinople.

WINNIPEG, Nov. 17.--Last evening THE TIMES'S correspondent visited Riel's old home at St. Boniface, a French town across the river from Winnipeg, where Riel's mother, wife, and relatives reside, and found all people in the town terribly excited.

"E.L.H." and "K.D.P." are the initials of two little girls who live in this city, and who contributed $4 yesterday to the Grant monument fund.

It is a notorious fact that the administration of the excise law in this city has long been in many respects a failure. The difficulty has been partly with the authorities vested with the duty of enforcing it and partly with the law itself.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--Ex-County Commissioner Coburn has brought suit against Henry S. Hayden, a lumber merchant, to recover $50,000 for alienating his wife's affections.

Samuel B. Goode, the colored man who stabbed and killed Officer James North, of the First Precinct, on Aug. 21, was arraigned before Recorder Smyth yesterday afternoon. He was represented by Lawyer Charles H. Reed, while Assistant District Attorney Nicoll conducted the prosecution.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--After eating his breakfast in the dining room of the National Hotel, in Clark-street, this morning, Edward Quevit, a Frenchman, 30 years old, went up to his room to get his hat. Behind the door, where he could not see her, stood Adeline Duval, a Frenchwoman, a year his senior, whom he recently case off, after living with her 10 months.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 17.--There is no change in the contest between the Arkansas Telegraph Company and the St. Louis, Iron Mountain and Southern Railway. Fifty employes of the telegraph company have spent the day digging holes and setting in poles, and 50 railway men have taken them down as fast as they were erected.

DES MOINES, Nov. 17.--The official returns of the Iowa election are all in, with the exception of Wright County, and Senator Larribee's majority for Governor will be almost exactly 5,000. Hull, for Lieutenant Governor, will have 7,500, and Akers, for Superintendent of Instruction, 8,000.

Mrs. Anna Farrell, of No. 452 Courtstreet, Newark, was bitten on the hand by a mad dog about a week ago. On Saturday she showed symptoms of hydrophobia, and yesterday afternoon she died in great agony.
NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 17.--The date of the Yale-Princeton football game is still undecided. To-night Capt. Peters went to New-York to meet Capt. Decamp, of Princeton.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--The State Board of Charities began to-day in investigation of the charges made by the Citizens' Committee and the Women's Club against the management of the County Insane Asylum.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 17.--A serious accident occurred yesterday evening at Doristown, eight miles from Gallatin, Tenn., in watch seven persons were injured, some seriously. Public baptizing was the immediate cause of a large number of persons coming together at that place.

The agitation for the opening of museums and libraries on Sundays is carried on with a persistence that of itself proves how important many intelligent people consider it. That favorite argument of inert conservatism--"the entering wedge" --can scarcely now be urged against the proposition.

Mr. Lawson N. Fuller has begun anew an uncompromising warfare against the predatory and omnivorous goat. It would appear that the animals which he fondly imagined he had driven from the northern part of the island learned of his recent severe illness and returned in force to browse upon the tender sapling and fatten upon the stone walls and iron fences of the gardens on Washington Heights.

Trinity Chapel, on West Twenty-fifthstreet, was the seene of a pretty wedding last evening, Miss Annie E. Schenck, daughter of Peter Meserole Schenck, of Irvington, being married to the Rev. Samuel Borden Smith, Assistant Rector of Trinity Chapel, by Bishop Starkey, of Northern New-Jersey.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 17.--Lizzie Roberts and Ella Kelly, who were respectively Captain and Lieutenant of the Salvation Army at Asbury Park, appeared in the Court of Chancery to-day and made affidavit that they were unable to pay $31.48, the cost of court for arraigning them for disobeying an injunction restraining them from making noises at their religious meetings.

The American Athletic Club has elected these officers for the ensuing year: President-- George G. Bolden; Vice-President--L.R. Watkins; Treasurer--L.H. Jones; Secretary--George R. Simpson; Captain--Harry Young, Jr.; Lieutenant--Edward J. Welling; Members of the Board of Management--Duncan Campbell, Daniel N. Giet, M. Pretzfelder; Delegates to the National Amateur Athletic Association--Cyril Robinson and Mortlmer Bishop. The club is in a flourishing condition, and has more than 150 active members.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 17.--The Superior Court to-day granted a motion of the Erie Company in the suit of Proctor and others against it and the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Company and others, consolidating this...

Health Commissioner Raymond, of Brooklyn, had an interview with Mayor Low yesterday in regard to the typhoid fever epidemic which has been reported as raging in South Brooklyn, and pronounced the accounts greatly exaggerated.

A preliminary meeting of the Baseball League was held in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel last evening.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--The proceedings of the Supreme Court of the United States to-day were as follows: No. 62--George Place et al., appellants, vs. Norwich and New-York Transportation Company.--Argument concluded by Charles R. Ingersoll for alppellants, No. 63--H.G.C. Paulsen, appellant; No. 352--Gottfried Bachman, appellant, vs. The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company et al.--Argument begun by Edwin C. Shaffer for appellants. The court did not desire to hear further argument in these cases.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 17.--In the Police Court this morning the case of Emil Kiesewetter, who was charged with shooting with intent to kill W.J. Elliott, editor of the Sunday Capitol, was continued before the Mayor.
Though the terms of Charles J. Osborn's will have not yet been made public, personal friends quote what they think they have reason to believe it provides.

Fur hat manufacturers from Connecticut, New-Jersey, Pennsylvania, and New-York met at No. 100 Prince-street yesterday, to organize an association to serve as a medium through which to deal with the various associations of journeymen and to prevent strikes. The needs and demands of the workmen will receive attention through conference committees representing manufacturers and workmen, and the rights or manufacturers will be adjusted through the same medium.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 17.--Col. Peter C. Doyle has generally been agreed upon by the officers of the Eighth Division of the National Guard as Brigadier-General, in the place of Gen. Edgar C. Jewett, whose resignation will soon be tendered to the Governor.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 17.--The Reformed Dutch Church, of Six Mile Run, Franklin Park, N.J., near New-Brunswick, will celebrate to-morrow its one hundred and seventyfifth anniversary.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17.--There were lively times at Glence, Mo., last night, when the Catholic Protectorate, until recently known as St. Joseph's Industrial School for Boys, was discovered to be on fire.
The centennial address before the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen was spoken by Gen. Stewart L. Woodford in Steinway Hall last night.

M. Ovide Musin, a violinist favorably known to the frequenters of the concert room, and Mr. August Hyllested, a young Danish pianist whose earliest appearance in this country was recently effected, under Mr. Van der Stucken's direction, gave the first of three matinee entertainments at Steinway Hall yesterday afternoon.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 17.--The Mississippi River Commission's boat, the Mississippi, arrived at this city this morning with the members of that body on board--Major C.R. Suter, United States Army; Gen. S.W. Ferguson, Judge R.D. Taylor, Prof. H. Mitchell, and Major B.M. Harrod, Gen. C.B. Comstock, who had left the commission at Greenville in order to go to Galveston, returned from that city in time to meet the commission here.
WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 17.--Representatives from the Waterbury, Meriden, and Hartford Baseball Associations met in Waterbury this afternoon to arrange for next season's games.

The Congressional committee appointed to investigate and report upon the policy to be adopted by the Government to secure a supply of ordnance and armor plate began a session in the New-York Hotel yesterday afternoon.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 17.--Mrs. Mary Casey, wife of Thomas Casey, a retired tanner, committed suicide this morning at her home in Middletown by cutting her throat with a carving knife. Mrs. Casey had taken chloroform to end her sufferings, but a physician, by prompt action, saved her life.
When Mayor Edson classified the employes of the city under the Civil Service act, be included the subordinates of the Aqueduct Commissioners among them.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--Court Attendant J.P. Jackson and a number of lawyers were riding up in an elevator in the County Building to-day, when the standpipe running up through the elevator well burst.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--The President has designated Capt. S.M. Mills, Fifth Artillery, to accompany Lieut.-Col. Lazelle to India as representative of the United States Army to witness to manoeuvres of the British Army in January.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 17.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20; drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 25.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 17.--Patrick Murphy, station agent of the New-York, NewHaven and Hartford Railroad at Westport, has been in the service of the company for 25 years and has been a faithful and trusted employe.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 17.--The Orange County Farmers' Milk Company, which met at Goshen, has decided to continue the company's store in New-York City.
The charges of treachery and misman agement on the part of Republican workers will be investigated by a committee appointed for the purpose by the Republican County Committee last night.

SING SING, Nov. 17.--Gov. Hill, I.V. Baker, Superintendent of Prisons; the pardon clerk, and their stenographer spent the day at Sing Sing Prison to-day examining convicts who have made applications for pardons. Altogether they saw about 60 of them, heard their cases, and reserved decision.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 17.--Robert Stapleton, the young man arrested at Woodbury on the charge of having stolen a horse and buggy from E.S. Wood, a liveryman at Bridgeport, Conn., has been locked up in Goshen Jail in default of $1,000 bonds for his appearance before the Grand Jury.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 17.--There is three inches of snow of the ground at Stamford, Delaware County, and at various point in the Catskill Mountains snow has covered the ground for a fornight. Ice half an inch in thickness has formed in a number of cloves in the mountains.

The Philharmonic Club entered last evening upon the eighth season of its existence and gave the first of its series of four concerts at Chickering Hall. This body is not exactly the typical representative of chamber music that a metropolis ought to possess, nor is Chickering Hall...

EDINBURGH, Nov. 17.--West Calder was to-day handsomely draped with flags and bunting and decorated with evergreens in honor of the visit of Mr. Gladstone. Great enthusiasm prevailed, and crowds of people lined the streets.

NASHVILLE, Nov. 17.--Since the Tracy City regulators inflicted 15 lashes upon a colored man and woman and notified several ex-convicts to leave the town, most of the disreputable women and former penitentiary birds have sought refuge elsewhere, fearing a visit from the nocturnal raiders.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 17.--Matthew Gorman, a brakeman on the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad, while crossing the railroad bridge last night was struck by a train and knocked into the river. His body has not yet been recovered.

LONDON, Nov. 17.--The Bulgarians are on the run all along the southern frontier of their country. The occupation of Sophia by King Milan's forces is only a matter of a couple of days.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 17.--The hearing on the application for a Receiver for Charter Oak Life Insurance Company was resumed at 10 o'clock to-day.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 17.--Oliver Terry, a farm laborer, who worked for his brother-inlaw, John Crane, at Circleville, Orange County, committed suicide with a pistol yesterday morning.

DUBLIN, Nov. 17.--The Irish National League has withdrawn its opposition to fox hunting on condition that obnoxious landlords do not take part in the sport.

BUFFALO, Nov. 17.--John C. Rowe, of Buffalo, one of the "big four" ball players, this evening was listed for a permanent position, but which is not expected to interfere with his work next season. He was married to Mrs. Louise Schachtel, a Buffalo widow of wealth and beauty. A bridal trip takes them to New-York and Washington. In New-York "Jack" expects to sign articles with the Detroits for 1886.

SALEM, Oregon, Nov. 17.--The Legisture took the first ballot to-day for United States Senator. The Republican votestood: John H. Mitchell, 24; George H. Williams, 15, and the remainder scattering.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 17.--Reuben S. Allen, who has been an engineer on the Central Road for nearly 40 years, has traveled about 2,000,000 miles in that time, estimating the monthly runs at from 4,000 to 4,500 miles. "Uncle Rube" said to-day that since he became an engineer he had only paid one fare, and that was 50 cents, in 1853, to a conductor who did not know him.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 17.--A great many people are figuring on relief plans and projects just now. Members of the Relief Committee are pretty well agreed tonight that about 800 families will have to be assisted and helped to begin life anew.
NANUET, N.Y., Nov. 17.--A drummer named Paul Blummer, who claimed to hail from Paterson, N.J., reported this morning having had an unpleasant experience last night.

At the meeting of the Pilot Commissioners yesterday the survivors of the pilot boat Mary and Catherine, No. 6, which was lost off the New-Jersey coast on Nov. 6 were examined. Oscar Stoffenden, who was in charge of the vessel at the time, said that at 2:20 A.M. he saw the green light of a steamer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--Commodore Schley, chief of the Bureau of Equipment and Recruiting of the Navy Department, reports the expenditure of small sums in excess of the appropriations for "equipment of vessels" and for "transportation and recruiting.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 17.--The fortythird annual meeting of the Grand Encampment of New-Jersey, I.O.O.F., was held in Masonic Hall, this city, to-day. Fifty local encampments were represented.

BOSTON, Nov. 17.--Judge Devens, of the Supreme Court, to-day so far modified the temporary injunction against the New-York and New-England Road restraining it from issuing its preferred stock in payment of its unsecured...

Bishop Littlejohn presided over the closing deliberations of the Church Temperance Society yesterday morning, and in his address congratulated the society in hearty terms for the progress it had made in molding public sentiment against the evils of intemperance.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--The third annual convention of the National Cattle Growers' Association was called to order to-day by D.W. Smith, of Illinois, the President. Henry E. Alvord, of Massachusetts, was made temporary Chairman. The roll call showed there were delegates present from 23 States and Territories and from Canada.
The annual report of the New-York Cooking School shows that in the course of the past year $280 were received in donations and $220 in annual subscriptions.

Many thousand copies of a petition requesting the Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the American Museum of Natural History to open, free of charge to the public, these institutions on Sunday are being circulated in various parts of the city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17.--Collector Hedden has made a report to Secretary Manning in the case of Leopold Lehmann, who demands an inquiry to ascertain why invoices of glassware consigned to him should have been advanced 100 per cent. while, as he asserts, invoices of similar goods were passed at invoice prices.

Angeline M. Brown occupied the witness stand in Part 3, Superior Court, for four hours yesterday, detailing to Judge Ingraham and a jury the story of her removal to the smallpox hospital on Blackwell's Island, on Nov. 18, ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--Chief-Justice Rogers, of the Cook County Circuit Court, has sustained the demurrer to the petition of William Costello for a mandamus to compel the United Order of Bricklayers and Stone Masons to reinstate him in his rights.

On Monday afternoon a man who registered as John W. Evans, and who was so deformed in one leg that he wore a thick sole on one boot, engaged board at Herschmann's Hotel, No. 19 Great Jones-street, and was given Room No. 6. He had supper and retired at 8 o'clock, leaving directions to be called at 6 o'clock yesterday morning. At that hour he was found dead on the floor of his room.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17.--While practicing this afternoon, W.R. Crawford, Yale, 80, of Chicago, half-back on the University football eleven, collided with Bishop, one of the Freshman eleven, and was knocked insensible.

BISMARCK, Dakota, Nov. 17.--Although the report that Senator Mahone is about to leave Virginia and take up his residence in the Red River Valley has been denied, it is reiterated in letters recently received here from Virginia. These letters, however, state that he intends to settle in the Valley of the Missouri.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17.--The arrangements for making the autopsy of the brain of John McCullough, the dead actor, were completed this afternoon. It will be made by Dr. Hugo Engel, assisted by three other physicians, in the vault at Monument Cemetery, at 11 o'clock to-morrow morning.

The returns from the Twenty-second, Twenty-third, and Twenty-fourth Assembly Districts were canvassed by the Aldermen, acting as County Canvassers, yesterday. Alderman Hartman during the session claimed that Ferdinand Eidman, one of the Republican candidates...
CHICAGO, Nov. 17.--Maurice Vignaux won in 24 innings to-night his first game in the 14-inch balk-line tournament, scoring 600 points, when his opponent, Jacob Schaefer, had counted up only 445.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 17.--During the past week wheat receipts at Minneapolis were 1,018,000 bushels, or 200,000 bushels less than the week previous. Shipments were 95,200 bushels, an increase of 18,000.

Register Reilly, prompted by a veteran clerk, told the Senate committee yesterday about the duties of employes in his department. Last year he employed about 30 men on an average. In this year's estimate he asks for $62,525 for copying libers, or nearly double the amount appropriated last year.

BOSTON, Nov. 17.--In the Loud divorce case, which was heard by Judge Devens last week, a decree nisi was given to-day for the libelant, young Mr. Helen C.J. Loud, formerly Miss Mack, with leave to resume her maiden name when the decree becomes absolute. The court rendered the following decision:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 17.--The Hon. D. M. De Witt, of this city, was to-day nominated by a caucus of the Democratic Supervisors for Surrogate to fill the vacancy caused by the appointment of A.B. Parker to the Supreme Court bench. As the Board of Supervisors is Democratic, the nomination is equivalent to appointment.
TOLEDO, Nov. 17.--Messrs. C.A. King Co., of this city, have received 800 crop reports from Ohio, Michigan, Indiana, Illinois, Kansas, and Missouri during the past five days.

The third of the Thomas popular concerts was given in the Academy of Music last evening in presence of a very large and fashionable audience. That these entertainments are really popular, as truly as performances of pure music can ever be popular, there is no doubt; ...

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 17.--Schenectady water bonds to the amount of $90,000, bearing 4 per cent. interest, redeemable in 1902 and succeeding years up to 1917, were sold in one lot at auction to-day.

Trinity Chapel, West Twenty-fifth-street, near Broadway, was crowded last night. The occasion was the singing of the choirs of Trinity Parish. It was the thirteenth annual festival.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 19.--Quinn Harrison, a grandson of the Rev. Peter Cartwright, a pioneer Methodist minister, assaulted his sister, Mrs. A. Ely, of Chicago, yesterday, breaking one of her ribs and inflicting, it is feared, fatal injuries.

PLANO, Ill., Nov. 19.--Willie Gruhn, aged 12 years, picked up a loaded shotgun yesterday, and calling to his 15-year-old sister pulled the trigger, and the entire charge passed into her side. She died in about 30 minutes. The boy, as usual, didn't know the gun was loaded.

The Old Guard left its armory, at Fifthavenue and Fourteenth-street, at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, with Major George W. McLean in command.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 19.--A man who had registered at the Troy House as J.A. Heath, of New-York, was arrested to-day for swindling hotel proprietors. He said his right name was James H. Stewart, and that he lives in Tennessee.

The Pope having early this year entered into direct communication with the Emperor of China has now taken the same step with regard to the Mikado of Japan, in both cases with the happiest consequences, so far.

Hopkins, the first witness, said that four and one-third grains of arsenic in the stomach would produce the symptoms which Winifred Hanley saw in Clara Groblewski.

Shortly after midnight on Wednesday two of the four large plate glass show windows of the dry goods establishment of I. Steuerman, on Third-avenue, near One Hundred and Twentythird-street, were broken by unknown persons, who disappeared immediately afterward.

DETROIT, Nov. 19.--Charles R. Wardwell, a well known auctioneer and jeweler of this city, has made an assignment. The immediate cause was the pressure of several Eastern creditors who had become suspicious of him through certain rumors which had been in circulation identifying him with the firm of Thomas Walsh Co., against whom some recently discovered forged paper was held.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--William Walter, a Riverdale dairy farmer, is missing. Since his departure four mortgages on his property and promissory notes aggregating $20,000 have come to light.

ALBANY, Nov. 19.--The People's and Consumers' Gas Company, of Brooklyn, filed a certificate of incorporation to-day, with a capital stock of $3,000,000.
QUEENSTOWN, Nov. 20.--The Guion Line steamship Nevada, Capt. Douglass, from New-York Nov. 10, for Liverpool, arr. here at 1 P.M. to-day.
NANTUCKET, Mass., Nov. 19.--The cable connecting this island with Martha's Vineyard was successfully landed at noon to-day.

Miss Zaidee Van Santvoord, a daughter of Mr. Alfred Van Santvoord, was married last evening to the Rev. Wilson Merie Smith, Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Cleveland.

The annual meeting of the Woman's Hospital was largely attended yesterday at the hospital, Forty-ninth-street and Fourth-avenue. The President, Col. George T.M. Davis, read the annual report.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--Mr. John G. Carlise arrived here to-day ill and travel-worn, and has declined to see visitors, many of whom called at his hotel to pay their respects and to talk with him about the organization of the Forty-ninth Congress.

It was announced last Monday that the Park Commissioners were considering the advisability of changing the name of West Roxbury Park to Franklin Park. This change has been officially made.

The most valuable present which Princess Marie of Orleans received on her marriage was a magnificent riviere of diamonds valued at 10,000, which was given by the Duc d'Aumale. It was one of the wedding presents of the late Duchesse d'Aumale.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Nov. 19.--Although the weather was inclement, Gen. Hancock, attended by Gen. Walker, of his staff, historian of the Second Corps; Col. Wilson, Major Miller, Col. Batchelder, Government historian of the battlefield; Col. Nicholson, Recorder of the Grand Commandery, Loyal Legion, and others, visited the battlefield to-day.

PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 19.--Henry Moore, a condemned negro murderer, escaped from the Greensville County Jail in June last, on the day before the time appointed for his hanging. Since his escape, although a price has been set upon his head, he has avoided capture by remaining hidden in a dense swamp.

FORT COVINGTON, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Edward Gower, of this township, while intoxicated last night shot his wife dead with a revolver. He was arrested.

THE TIMES acknowledges the receipt of a check for $300 from Mr. R. Fulton Cutting for the relief of the sufferers by the fire in Galveston, Texas. The amount has been forwarded to the Mayor of Galveston.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 19.--At the time of Dr. Eliphalet Nott's death, over 20 years ago, there was a great deal of discussion on the subject of removing Union College to Albany. The people of Albany urged the project strongly.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 19.--A train on the Vicksburg and Meridian Railroad, loaded principally with cotton, caught fire this evening. About 60 bales of cotton, a car of furni ture, and two cars were burned. The loss is about $5,000.
The dilatory manner in which the commission appointed to have the electric wires placed under ground in this city is proceeding has led to no little uneasiness as to its purposes.

HELENA, Montana, Nov. 19.--James Dempsey reached the city last night from Fort Maginnis. He tells of pitiable story of his two companions being devoured by wolves while on their way across the mountains.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Nov. 19.--The Helfenstein Colliery, near here, for which the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company paid a fortune and subsequently spent a large sum in improving, has been permanently abandoned, and the force of carpenters is now at work tearing down the large breaker.

OTTAWA, Nov. 19.--The official statement of the Canadian chartered banks for October shows a slight expansion of business compared with the returns for the previous month.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 19.--Allen W. Dorsey, a medical student at the College of Pennsylvania, and a son-in-law of Benjamin Burton, and Maria Dorsey, his wife, were arrested this morning charged with willful murder, and taken to the police station.

The death of Dr. William Frothingham by his own hand was uppermost in the talk of the people on Washington Heights yesterday. He was the must popular physician in that section. Every one knew him, the poor as well as the rich.

The New-York State Conference of Unitarian Churches met yesterday at the Church of the Saviour, Pierrepont-street, Brooklyn. Reports and addresses were given by members of the Women's Auxiliary Conference.
PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 19.--Warrants were served on Judge John C. Yates to-day by the Deputy Sheriff, at the Judge's residence, in Richwood township.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19, 1885. At the meeting of the Cabinet to-day each of the members submitted a statement of affairs in his department deemed of sufficient consequence to be brought to the attention of Congress in the President's forthcoming message.

The eighty-eighth anniversary of the Society for the Relief of Poor Widows with Small Children took place yesterday afternoon. The report of last Winter's work showed an outlay of $10,132 66 in necessaries distributed among 553 widows, of whom 344 were Protestants...

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Judge Osborn to-day, in the Circuit Court and Court of Oyer and Terminer, held in Kingston, reproved the lawyers present for not having their cases ready for trial. He said if they were not more prompt he would adjourn the Circuit without a day.

After an absence abroad of three months, the Empress Eugenie has returned from Italy to Farnborough. The Empress crossed from Calais to Dover by the mall boat on Saturday afternoon, and was looking very ill and worn.

ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, Nov. 19.--The Scott Temperance act was defeated in this city by 550 majority.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 19.--T.W. Eck lowered the ten-mile processional tricycle record here this afternoon in the presence of a number of bicycle experts. His time was 35:32 2-5, beating the best record, by Harry Higham, by 4 minutes and 28 seconds. Jack Prince made the pace.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 19.--Colorow, with 14 lodges and 500 ponies, is camped on the Yampah River, 25 miles above Cross Mountain. The Indians burned the cattle ranges along the trail, leaving 75,000 cattle without food.

Hugh Gilmour, a Manchester furniture dealer, was yesterday fined 30, and bound over in 100 to be of good behavior, for forcibly kissing a young lady in a railway carriage. At Romford Petty Sessions a laborer was fined 5s. for assaulting a female member of the Salvation Army by kissing her.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--Sheriff Hanchett slipped quietly out of a side door in the County Jail at high noon to-day with Joseph C. Mackin, the Democratic "fine worker," convicted of perjury and sentenced to five years' imprisonment in the penitentiary.

SPARTA, Ga., Nov. 19.--The Congressional campaign in this (the Eighth Georgia) district promises to be one of the most notable in the South.

Last Tuesday afternoon Mrs. ANNIE FARRELL died of hydrophobia in the city of Newark. Nearly three months ago, while walking in a street of that city, she stooped to caress a dog that lay near the curbstone moaning and whining as if in pain.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 19.--The Cincinnati Price Current states to-day that the total number of hogs packed in the West last week was 447,000, against 300,000 last year. The total number to date since Nov. 1 is 940,000, against 566,000 last year.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Nov. 19.--The defense in the case of the Commonwealth against James S. Hammond, Chief of Police, chargad with manslaughter in the killing of John B. Wolf, who was shot while attempting burglary, closed this afternoon.

MONTREAL, Nov. 19.--The Riel Defense Committee met to-night on the Champ de Mars, over 10,000 people being present. After the meeting the mob formed in procession and marched along Craig-street, shouting and singing.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 19.--A stove exploded in the City Hospital at 2:20 o'clock this afternoon and started a fire in the elevator way between the third and fourth floors.

A correspondent of the Dexter (Me.) Gazette tells the story of an old-time Bangor sea Captain's escape from a Sheriff many years ago. The Sheriff went aboard the schooner with a warrant for the Captain's arrest.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 19.--The Stand and Oil Company has petitioned the city authorities here for permission to erect a fireproof warehouse, in which they will locate tanks with a capacity of 5,000 barrels of oil.

WABASH, Ind., Nov. 19.--Hog cholera of a fatal type has broken out in Liberty Township, this county, where large droves are being fatted for the market. Two hundred animals have died in two weeks and many more are sick.

Joseph Dion was sleeping quietly at Bellevue Hospital last evening at 9 o'clock, and had rested nearly all day. Prior to his confinement sleep had not visited him for a week.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 19.--In the hold of the British ship Cashier, lying at the ballast wharf at the foot of Chestnut-street, is a young man named James Kelley, who is heavily manacled and closely guarded. He is accused of murdering the first mate, John Ross.
WICHITA FALLS, Texas, Nov. 19.--Information has been received here of very disastrous prairie fires in Indian Territory, especially in the section lying north of Red River Station.

LONG BRANCH, Nov. 19.--The indictment of Phil Daly, the owner of the palatial Pennsylvania Club House at Long Branch, to-day, is one of the results of the crusade begun early last Summer against the gamblers and pool sellers in Monmouth County. Mr. Daly was fined $300 and costs for selling pools at the Monmouth race course.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--Jacob Schaefer won his first game in the balk tournament this evening, and 2,500 persons saw a brilliant and interesting contest lasting two hours and fifty minutes, and running through 26 innings. Schaefer had suffered among the betting men to-day, his opponent, Vignaux, having the call.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 20.--A shocking accident occured this morning in Olneyvillesquare. A runaway horse attached to a wagon came dashing down Manton-avenue just as Charles E. Dyer, a conductor on the Broadway route, stepped from his car.

BUTLER, Penn., Nov. 20.--An explosion occurred at the Pittsburg Producers' wildcat oil well, near Mars Station, to-day, caused by the gas igniting from a match struck by one of the employes who was lighting a cigar. The derrick and rigging were destroyed, and William Irvine, Oscar Marshal, and two other workmen seriously burned.

Joseph Groblewski spent a restless night in Raymond-Street, Jail, Brooklyn, after hearing the verdict of the jury convicting him of murder in the first degree for having poisoned his second wife. He looked haggard and troubled yesterday, as he claimed that his trial had not been managed well.
The canvass of the lower part of the city by the Grant Monument Association is progressing slowly. That it will result in largely increasing the fund is not doubted by the Executive Committee.

ITHICA, N.Y., Nov. 20.--The Hon. Henry W. Sage, founder of the Sage Female College, Cornell University, has given $60,000 to endow a Professorship of Ethics and Moral Philosophy in the university, in memory of his late wife. At a meeting of the Board of University Trustees to-day the gift was formally accepted.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 20.--The Seamen's Union to-night raised the standard of wages to $2 50 per day, and by the run or trip, with fares paid back, as follows: To Oswego, $25; Kingston, $25; Ogdensburg, $30; Charlotte, $20.

LONDON, Nov. 20.--Dispatches received here state that the Servians have become dispirited over their recent reverses. The Bulgarians, on the other hand, have been aroused to the highest pitch of enthusiasm by the example of Prince Alexander and the victories gained under his leadership.

INDIANAPOLIS, NOV. 20.--John T. Musselman died in the State Insane Hospital, near this city, yesterday. He was from Logansport, and father-in-law of Rufus Magee, Minister to Sweden. He was at one time worth $300,000, and widely known throughout Northern Indiana.

A sudden descent of the mercury like that of Thursday afternoon causes the feminine element of the family to think about Winter wraps and fur garments. Among the latter sealskin is the favorite material now, as ever, and nothing to take its place has made its appearance as yet.

TRENTON, Nov. 20.--Vice-Chancellor Bird to-day dismissed the application for an injunction to restrain Asbury Park from using the artesian well which was bored in close proximity to the Ocean Grove well, and from which Ocean Grove receives its water supply.

At the Chamber of Commerce yesterday afternoon representatives of various commercial organizations of the city met to discuss further the proposal to ask Congress to aid American shipping by subsidy legislation, framed on the basis of the French bounty scheme.

COHOES, Nov. 20.--On Tuesday the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company, operating the Rensselaer and Saratoga Railroad, made application to the Common Council for the right to lay a side track through Van Rensselaer-street.

A Cuban negro, Augustine Rebello, has been arrested on suspicion of being the murderer of Chang Ong, or Antonio Soloa, the proprietor of an eating house in a basement at Spring and Wooster streets, who was found dead in his place on the afternoon of Nov. 2.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Nov. 20.--A meeting of sympathizers with Mr. Parnell's movements for securing home rule for Ireland was held here last night. Resolutions in favor of the movement were adopted, and $300 was subscribed...

One-half of the capital stock of the Fifth-Avenue Transportation Company--the new Fifth-avenue stage line--having been subscribed, a meeting will be held at Delmonico's, on Fifth-avenue, next Wednesday at 4:30 P.M. to adopt by-laws and elect Directors.

Tammany Hall and Irving Hall were enveloped in a blaze of glory last night. The General Committees of the two organizations met for the first time since their overwhelming defeat of the County Democracy forces, and the gatherings were made occasions for inviting the general public to crow with the braves over their success.
Coroner Hesse began an inquest yesterday over the body of Florence Johnson, the child, 5 years old, who was smothered by her mother, Mrs. Mary Johnson, at the Brooklyn Nursery.

Herman P. Nelson, a sailor, returned to New-York on Oct. 5, after a year's voyage, to find that his married daughter had died and that his wife had gone to live with the young widower, Herman H. Pahdee, at No. 242 Fifth-street, Jersey City.
LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 20.--A peculiar disease has made its appearance among hogs at Bainbridge, but so far it is confined to six or eight pens. Farmers have taken alarm, and are killing their pork.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 20.--An improvement has been made on the Bessemer steel process at the Edgar Thomson Steel Works, which, it is said, will have the effect of making Bessemer steel equal in quality to crucible steel, ...

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 20.--Gen. Rogers, of Buffalo, has ordered a court of inquiry in the case of Capt. Eugene Root, of the Twentysixth Separate Company, which will sit in this city next Friday. It will be conducted by Col. Welch, of the Sixty-fifth Regiment, Buffalo.

HELENA, Ark., Nov. 20.--The citizens of Helena were aroused at an early hour yesterday morning by what many of them at first thought to be a very heavy rainstorm, but they were surprised to see a clear sky filled with what appeared to be snow flakes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.--Manager Scanlan, of the National Baseball Club, is delighted with the prospect opened to the club by its admission to the National League. He says that the National Club is not put in Buffalo's place.

Mrs. Sarah Mr. Henry sat upon the wittess stand the greater part of yesterday and underwent cross-examination by John Graham, counsel of her former husband, Zachariah E. Simmons, in his suit against her.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 20.--At NewBritain this morning Brand Brothers' factory, on Elm-street, caught fire on the top floor, and before the flames were extinguished a considerable portion of the building was destroyed. While several firemen were near the top of a long ladder a portion of the wall fell out and ...

When all the parties interested in the Wall-Street Daily News libel case had assembled in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday afternoon there was an ominous pause and a general looking about for the next move.

HARRISONBURG, Va., Nov. 20.--By a decision of the Supreme Court of Virginia in the case of Effingers, Executor, against Hall, from Rockingham County, affirming the decision of the lower court, nearly one-fourth of the property in Harrisonburg will be thrown upon the market to satisfy the claim of the Hall beirs. The property includes land and improvements, and is worth about $60,000.

CASA GRANDE, Arizona, Nov. 20.--The stage bound to this place from the Silver King mine was stopped to-day by a masked highwayman, armed with a shotgun, when two miles south of Pinal, Arizona. The robber, who it is believed had confederates, obtained two bars of silver bullion worth $5,000. Officers from Pinal are now in pursuit.
OPELIKA, Ala., Nov. 20.--Great lawlessness exists around Heflin, in this State, having among its incidents several highway robberies. F.M. Bishop while traveling from Carrollton, ...

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 20.--There is only one topic discussed in this city to-night, and that is to-morrow's football game between Yale and Princeton. The hotels are full of college graduates who have come to New-Haven to see the match, and the students themselves are devoting far more time to discussing the chances of victory than to their text books.
Affidavits in support of the motion for a new trial for Samuel B. Goode, who was convicted of murder in the second degree in the Court of General Sessions on Thursday, will be filed on Tuesday next.

The second anniversary of the establishment of the Gospel Chapel, at No. 305 West Thirtieth-street, will be celebrated by a meeting tomorrow afternoon in the Reformed Church, on Thirty-fourth-street, west of Eighth-avenue. QUEBEC, Nov. 20.--Capt. Dale, of the steamer Brooklyn, and Capt. McLean, of the steamer Titania, after a thorough examination before the Marine Commission which has been investigating the cause of the stranding of their vessels, have been exonerated from all blame, and received back their certificates as Captains.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 20.--Secretary Flannery, of the Miners' Association, issued a circular to-day to the railroad miners in reference to loading cars and filling contracts for the Hocking Valley coal operators.
Leon H. Blum, of No. 123 Duanestreet, have received the following subscribtions for the relief of sufferers from the Galveston fire:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20.--Capt. John Abbott, Robert Treanor, mate, and Patrick Tally, hand, were drowned yesterday afternoon near the mouth of the Patapsco River, by falling fron the deck of the schooner John Nichols. They are said to have all fallen together, and all sank at the same time. The vessel returned to port, and the police have begun an investigation.

Stephen G. Ober, 30 years old, a resident of St. Paul, Minn., a guest at the Hoffman House, was discovered last night insane from excessive drinking. He was sent to Bellevue Hospital. Ober is a well-to-do business man of St. Paul and visits New-York frequently on business. His friends will be informed of his plight. His condition is not serious.

"There are in this city more than 3,000 places where intoxicating liquors are sold," said Judge Noah Davis, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday, while directing a jury to acquit Rafela de Rosa, charged with a violation of the excise law.

Side by side with Emperor WILLIAM'S declaration, to the Reichstag that he "confidently hopes the Balkan conflict will not disturb the peace of Europe" has come the rumor that Russia is massing troops on her southern frontier.

"When I first went into the grocery business, just after the war," said the prosperous head of a large retail grocery house up town, "it was a part of a young clerk's trade that he should know how to make his own paper bags.

MONTREAL, Nov. 20.--The city is in a ferment to-day over the counter demonstration in the West End last night. The French Canadians are evidently determined not to take a hint, for it was learned this afternoon that printed notices have been posted in prominent places ...
The Senate investigating committee has touched, thus far very lightly, upon the subject of the expenses of the judiciary of this city, which amount to about a million and a quarter per annum.

In the suit of Mrs. Elizabeth Van Antwerp for a limited divorce from William Van Antwerp, her brother, Theodore Van Antwerp Trotter, testified yesterday that her husband told him he had lost $100,000 belonging to his wife, but would replace it within six months.
Liverpool, Nov. 20.--The steamship Historian, (Br.,) Capt. Hughes, from New-Orleans Oct. 28, has arr. here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20, 1885. The President has accepted the resignation of D.B. Searle, United States Attorney for the District of Minnesota, to take effect on the qualification of his successor, who, it is believed, will be appointed in a few days.

The attention of nearly everybody who passes along the east side of Broadway, between Twenty-first and Twenty-second streets, is attracted to a large show window filled with unique and beautiful glassware, decorated in bright colors, blue and gold especially.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 20.--The Milton and North Mountain Railroad Company, with a capital stock of $200,000, was chartered at the State Department to-day. The line will extend from Milton, in Northumberland County, to a point near Millville, in Columbia County.

A TIMES reporter called upon Capt. William M. Conner, proprietor of the St. James Hotel, yesterday, and found him in his private office with a party of gentlemen. Capt. Conner was asked his opinion in reference to the controversy among Philadelphia medical men regarding Mr. John McCullough.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.--The Bureau of Education is preparing a report on art and industry in schools, colleges, and institutions of public training. It is replete with practical knowledge, which will form a basis for these studies in public schools.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20.--Suit was brought to-day against the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company by William B. Chew, who lays his damages at $25,000. Chew was formerly a conductor on the road, and was arrested and tried for embezzling $15 and acquitted.
The Essex County Hunt ball was given last evening in the Music Hall, at Orange, and the flowers of all the Oranges, as well as many fair blossoms from New-York, were assembled there.

MONTREAL, Nov. 20.--The action of damages instituted by the firm of S. Carsley and Carsley Co. for $50,000 against the Bradstreet Mercantile Agency was decided by Judge Loranger this morning in favor of the plaintiffs, damages being assessed at $2,000 and costs in each case.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 20.--East St. Louis is in a state of great excitement to-night over the assassination of John B. Bowman, ex-Mayor of that town.
President Bates, of the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company, has received the following dispatch from Little Rock.

A large number of physicians and gentlemen who are connected with charitable medical institutions met last evening at the hall of the New-York Academy of Medicine in answer to invitations issued by the Charity Organization Society.
MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 20.--The export of cattle from this port since the opening of navigation was 61,500 head, an increase of 5,000 head over that for the corresponding period last year.

THOMASTON, Me., Nov. 20.--Wilkinson, who was executed to-day, remained calm and cool as the hour of his death approached. He slept quite well during Thursday night, breakfasted heartily, and smoked. His parents are living near London. His father is a tradesman. Wilkinson is not the prisoner's real name.

Bidding was fairly spirited at an auction sale of Richard Butler's private collection of pictures in Ortgies Co.'s art rooms last evening by the American Art Association. A few works by American artists brought good prices.
Excitement ruled again on the Petroleum Exchange yesterday. Prices were knocked down and one failure of some importance and two or three others of no great consequence were announced.

Gen. C.H.T. Collis has addressed an open letter to Edward S. Whelen, of Philadelphia, who presided at the last annual meeting of the Reading Railroad Company and who will probably preside at the next meeting. Gen. Collis raises the old question of whether or not bondholders of the company are entitled to vote.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20.--Joseph C. Mackin, the Chicago "fine worker," who was yesterday taken down to Joliet to serve five years for perjury, began work this morning as a stonecutter. Mackin is a good specimen of manhood, weighing 185 pounds, and is physically well suited to his work.

MONTREAL, Nov. 20.--A man named Woodland who lives in the suburbs of Rochesterville recently invented a disinfectant, the use of which he claimed insured such complete protection against smallpox that vaccination would be rendered unnecessary.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20.--There was an increased attendance at the Indian Rights Convention, in this city, to-day Mrs. A.S. Quinton, Secretary of the Woman's National Indian Association, and Miss Alice Fletcher made addresses. Mrs. Quinton urged that the Government give the Indians lands in severalty.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20.--W.F. McClure, while making a call at a house on Oak-street last night, heard the appealing cries of a woman from the lake. He ran to the shore, and, seeing her struggling in the water, summoned the police.
CAMDEN, N.Y., Nov. 20.--For several weeks farmers in this neighborhood have been losing hogs and sheep in a very mysterious manner. Until recently the depredations were attributed to thieves.

Miss Jeanne Franko, a violinist whose work is familiar to the musical public of this city, gave a concert in Steinway Hall last evening before an audience of large size and extreme catholicity of taste. Miss Franko is a performer of agreeable, if not unusual, ability.

Representatives of the cutlery trade of the United States met at the St. Denis Hotel yesterday for the purpose of effecting a formal organization with a views to protecting mutual interests more effectively than has been done heretofore.
