Speaker George Z. Erwin is expected in the city either to-day or to-morrow. He is coming down from the wilds of St. Lawrence for the purpose of ascertaining whether ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt has been able to fix up his fences.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.--Louis Sommerfield, a Pole, 52 years old, to-day shot and instantly killed his wife and Gottlieb Eisenbaum, at the latter's saloon in the northeastern part of the city.
LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 20.--The people of Middletown are rejoicing over the announcement that the Conewago furnace at that place will go into blast next month.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 20.--John L. Sullivan, the pugilist, has signed a contract here with John Cannon, of New-York City, under whose management he agrees to make a tour of Europe and Australia next year. He agrees to meet any man who may be brought before him, at any time, under any circumstances, with or without gloves, and under any rules.

SUGAR LOAF, N.Y., Nov. 20.--The Rev. H.B. Edwards, an itinerant preacher and a member of the Methodist Episcopal church at this place, is on trial before the Quarterly Conference, Mr. D'C. Crawford presiding, on the charge of "unchristian and unministerial conduct."

PARIS, Nov. 3.-Each Minister of War in France--and there have been two-andtwenty titularies of the French War Department since the fall of the tyrant--has marked his administration by some great act of reform.

William Heath, whose once rich and influential stock brokerage firm failed on the second day of last month, spent yesterday in a cell in Ludlow-Street Jail. Few persons called to see him, and to all except his intimate friends,

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.--Capt. Ramsay, Superintendent of the Naval Academy, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy recommends that permits for the admission as cadets be issued for one year prior to the time fixed for examination, and renews the recommendation that all candidates for admission be required to report for examination on May 15.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 20.--L.B. Jones, a young man of prominence, was convicted in the Hustings Court to-day of sending a challenge to fight a duel. His punishment was fixed at one hour in jail and the payment of one cent fine.

There was a large meeting of representative men, taxpayers, and property owners of Sing Sing in Olive Opera House on Thursday evening to discuss the proposed method of introducing water into that village for fire and domestic purposes.

Alfred Mendel, age 45, of No. 43 Attorney-street, is lying dangerously ill at his residence from the effects of injuries received at the hands of Mr. Berger, his landlord. Coroner Kennedy was called yesterday, and he took the ante-mortem statement of the injured man.
COPENHAGEN, Nov. 20.--The panic in the corn trade in Denmark continues.
DUBLIN, Nov. 20.--Arthur O'Connor has been selected to contest East Donegal for a seat in Parliament at the coming election.
About 90 persons attended the thirtyninth annual banquet of the Theta Delta Chi fraternity, given under the auspices of Psi charge of Hamilton College, at Delmonico's last evening.
The Board of Aldermen, acting as a Board of County Canvassers, completed the work of correcting and revising the returns of the votes cast at the recent election and formally declared the result.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 20.--Last evening some boys found County Judge Alden S. Sanborn's dead body in the woods east of the city, in the town of Blooming Grove.

John G. Brandt, aged 53, of No. 161 Ludlow-street, a silk weaver, employed at the corner of Canal and Baxter streets, was laid off on Nov. 17. Since that time he has grown disconsolate. Yesterday he left his house early in the morning, and told his wife that he was going to see a few friends.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Nov. 20.--In the trial of Chief of Police Hammond for the manslaughter of John Wolf the jury this morning, after being out but half an hour, returned a verdict of not guilty. The killing occurred while the officer was endeavoring to arrest ...

The Kings County Board of Supervisors, acting as a board of canvassers, concluded its examination of the election returns yesterday and made its official announcements; the results show no material changes. On the State ticket, the entire vote cast for Governor was 106,829.

The correspondent of an evening paper suggests that in order to save Fifth-avenue from street cars it is necessary that a smooth pavement be laid, and that it be not thereafter disturbed except for repairs, the pipes and conduits below the surface being made accessible by being inclosed in a subway.

The sale of Richard Grant White's library and art collection was concluded yesterday. No high prices were realized in the Shakespeareana, save that Mr. White's collection of engravings to illustrate Shakespeare's works sold for $175.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 20.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20; drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 25.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 20.--In the Corporation Court to-day a nolle prosequi was entered in case of the Commonwealth against A.W. Chapman, High Constable of Norfolk, indicted for obtaining $150 from Arthur Schroeder, traveling ...

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 20.--The Democratic City Committee voted this evening to make straight party nominations for the city election, and appointed a subcommittee to look after party interests in the matter of registration and rallying votes to the polls.

TRENTON, Nov. 20.--The annual meeting of the State Sanitary Association was concluded this afternoon. State Geologist George H. Cook read a paper on the "Value of Arte-an Wells for Domestic Use in Different Parts of NewJersey."

GALVESTON, Nov. 20.--The relief fund for the benefit of the fire sufferers reached $98,120 to-night, of which sum the committee has applied $38,500 among 735 recipients, representing between 2,500 and 3,000 individuals.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 20.--The Dominion Government have awarded contracts for the construction of the different sections of the Short Line Railway to the International Railway Company, of Sherbrooke, Quebec.

LIMA, Nov. 20. via Galveston.--An official dispatch from the Prefect of Juaja states that Caceres has been defeated by the First Division of the Government force, who out off his retreat by Huaripampa. Caceres lost heavily in killed and prisoners.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 20.--George Clark, a negro, who so brutally murdered his wife in Petersburg yesterday, was arrested here to-day and lodged in jail. The woman's head was split open with an axe, and the colored people of Petersburg are greatly excited.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Nov. 20.--The boiler in S.F. McLaughlin's grist mill at Richland, Ind., exploded this afternoon and killed Mrs. McLaughlin and Charles Fisker. Fisker was working in a blacksmith shop adjoining the mill.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20.--Creditors of Nelson B. Haynes, the milliner who made a voluntary assignment a few days ago, will to-morrow ask Judge Prendergast to set aside certain alleged fraudulent transfers of property made by Haynes just before his assignment.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Nov. 20.--Erie County Infirmary, two miles from this city, was destroyed by fire to-night. There were 95 inmates, five of whom were burned to death. Their names are: Miss Mary Latcha, Miss Mary Upp, Mrs. Schiefler, Miss Mary Miller, all of Sandusky, and Mrs. Newcomb, of Berlin Heights.

CARTERSVILLE, Ga., Nov. 20.--The 10year-old daughter of Thomas Higgins, while standing before the fire yesterday, found her clothes in a blaze. She was soon wrapped in flames and was terribly burned. She died last night in great agony.

The Fire Commissioners took no action yesterday with reference to the fatal accident at the ruins of the Empire Plaster Mills on Thursday. The building was out of their jurisdiction and had been surrendered to the owner,

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 20.--The general assignment of Edward Steinfield, clothier, to Henry Michaels was filed in the County Clerk's office this morning. It was not unexpected, as Mr. Steinfield's embarrassment has been a matter of street rumor for several days. The employes are the first preferred creditors. The assets and liabilities have not yet been made public.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20.--The persistency of Mr. L. Lehmann and his friends in demanding an investigation of the case of an advance of 100 per cent. in his invoices will result in an investigation. The Secretary of the Treasury will now go to the bottom of the matter, but exactly how or when the investigation will be conducted has not yet been decided.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 20.--A burglar, while attempting to rob the residence to Washington Rice at Troy to-day, was caught just as he was going through a window he had forced open and was shot. He cannot recover. The man gave his name as Joseph Porter and said he was from illinois.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20.--The stable of Andrew J. Hamilton, at Fourth and Marriott streets, was destroyed by fire to-night, causing a loss of $5,000. The adjoining livery stable of A. Starrett was damaged to the extent of $2,000. The losses are covered by insurance. Upward of 50 horses in the two stables were gotten out safely.

The steamship City of Montreal, of the Inman Line, which left Liverpool on Nov. 7, and was due last Wednesday, had not been reported at sundown yesterday, although the City of Berlin, of the same line, which sailed three days after the Montreal, arrived yesterday morning.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Nov. 20.--At about 12:30 o'clock last night a quantity of explosive material was exploded about 25 feet from the dwelling on Prospect-street owned by Bernard Boland and occupied by Morris Williams. The explosion was heard a long distance.

An exciting game of football was played at Hoboken yesterday morning between the University of Pennsylvania and the Stevens Institute, which resulted in a victory for the former by a score of 22 to 9.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--A meeting of the stockholders of the National Baseball Club was held here this evening with closed doors.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 21.--The entire adult population of Ste. Marthe village to-day voluntarily assembled in church and pledged themselves to abstain from alcoholic beverages for one year. The village has a population of 2,000 persons.
Lieut.-Gen. Sheridan and Inspector-General Baird will leave Washington in a few days, by direction of the President to visit Arizona in connection with the recent Indian troubles.
A full dress rehearsal of "Lohengrin" was held at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening and occupied the attention of all persons concerned until a late hour.

The exhibition of the American Institute continues to be daily visited by great crowds. The chrysanthemum show, which was one of the finest displays ever given, was closed last night, and this concludes the floricultural displays for the season.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 21.--The past week has been a busy one for the people of Galveston. Such moving about of families, hauling of furniture, and doubling up of tenements was never before witnessed in Texas.

Field are to come to Boston next Tuesday to attend the New-York and New-England Railroad meeting and to look into the matter of the refection of the highest bld, that of their New-York syndicate of 95 1/8 for the second mortgage bonds of the road which were held by the State.

SILVERTON, Col., Nov. 12.--A novel wedding took place near here to-day. Miss Mellie Connors, of Lake City, and Mr. Oscar Olsen, of Animas Forks, were married on the summit of the divide, at an altitude of ever 13,000 feet, the party being on snowshoes.

OTTAWA, Nov. 21.--Sir John Macdonald, Premier of Canada, left suddenly last night for Quebec, from whence he sails for England today. His departure was kept secret, as a hostile demonstration in Quebec was feared should it become known that he was in the city.

LONDON, Nov. 4.--The art season has opened unusually early this year; it is not often that the end of October sees three of the Bond-street galleries in full swing and the 1st of November following suit with those remaining; and as these exhibitions are of more than accustomed interest it must be a captious critic indeed who cannot find fit food in some of them to suit his varying moods.

MONTREAL, Nov. 21.--There is a most gratifying decrease in the death rate from smallpox. There were only 15 deaths in the city yesterday and 8 in the outlying municipalities, and for this week 132 deaths in the city and 32 in the suburbs, against 170 and 61, respectively, for the preceding week.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 21.--Henry Raesche, a prominent and well-to-do citizen, was found dead in bed this morning. MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 21.--Herbert R. Jones, an ex-banker of De Pere, was taken before Commissioner Bloodgood this forenoon and examined on a charge of embezzling moneys while acting as Postmaster at De Pere.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 21.--A very pretty girl, Margaret Dixon, 16 years of age was received at the penitentiary last niht from Stark County, having been convicted of burglary. She ran away from home and secured employment as a servant at Alliance.

Two representations of Italian opera were given at the Academy of Music yesterday. In the afternoon the impressive performance of "Lucia," witnessed twice already this season and described with sufficient minuteness in these columns to claim nothing more at present than a record of its occurrence, was repeated, with Mlle. Fohstrom as Lucia, Signor Giannini as Edgardo, and Signor de Anna as Aston.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Nov. 21.--The annual summary of the losses of vessels and lives in the Gloucester fisheries for the past year shows that 34 lives were lost, against 131 last year and an average of 124 for each of the previous 15 years.

At the special election Tuesday for Associate justice of the Supreme Court only a very small vote was polled. Judge Battle, Democratic candidate, was without an opponent. He will be commissioned as soon as the official vote can be received and declared.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 21.--Edith Allen Porter disappeared from her home in Auburn on Nov. 12, leaving a message to her friends, in which she said that she was going to a better world, and they might look for her body at the bottom of a large stream of water near by.

The magnificent armory of the Seventh Regiment was none too large to accommodate the thousands who witnessed the eighth handicap games of the regiment last evening. SOFIA, Nov. 22.--After a stiff battle this afternoon the Servians were driven out of Dragoman Pass by the Bulgarians, who then occupied the pass.

LONDON, Nov. 23.--A dispatch to the Times from Calcutta says that 5,000 people have been drowned and 150 villages submerged in Orissa by a cyclone, and that 1,241 square miles in the Moorshedabad and Huddea districts have been devastated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--The annual report of the Hon. Joseph S. Miller, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, shows that the total receipts from all sources of internal revenue taxation for the fiscal year ended June 30 were $112,421,121, as compared with $121,530,039 for 1884, $144,553,344 for 1883, and $146,523,273 for 1882.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22.--Commissioner Sparks has recently made a ruling which is probably destined to have an important influence in two or three ways upon the course of transactions in public lands.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22.--Engineer J.H. Delong and his wife were startled by a shot in the front room of their flat, on the third floor of the building at No. 310 Monroe-street, last evening. ALBANY, Nov. 22.--The Superintendent of State Prisons, Mr. Isaac V. Baker, has in preparation his annual report to the Legislature. The document will present interesting information upon the operation of the various systems under which convicts have been worked during the past year.

MONTREAL, Nov. 22.--The French-Canadian demonstration on the Champ de Mars this afternoon was by no means such a success as the National Party predicted. There were certainly not more than 10,000 people present, and the weather being bitterly cold, most of them left before the meeting was over.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 22.--Charges were preferred yesterday before Gov. Hill against the Commissioners of emigration of New-York by an association of soldiers known as the Veteran Rights Union.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 22.--Advices from Pineville, the county seat of McDonald County, Mo., in the extreme southwestern part of the State, say that Irwin Grubb was taken from the jail there on Friday night by a mob and hanged to a tree. Grubb murdered Dorson B. Anderson on the night of June 20 last for his money, and confessed the crime.

A row growing out of the Brighton Beach races occurred on Saturday afternoon at George Horn's saloon, corner of Cherry and Catharine streets. Horn, who owns several horses himself, has been in the habit of backing the mounts of young McCarthy, Commodore Kittton's famous light weight jockey.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22.--G.S. Darling, of Wallingford, felt an unusual interest in the services when he went to the Episcopal church in that town this morning.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 22.--Jack is the name of a fine old shaggy-coated, jet black dog, the property of a well known sportsman in this city. He is now some 10 years old, and he has, almost from his infancy, done duty as night watchman in a fashionable restaurant on Statestreet.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 22.--The Hocking Valley strike may now be regarded as at an end. At a meeting held at Buchtel on Friday night, at which both miners and operators were present, it was suggested that the then existing differences be settled by arbitration.

NEW-BOSTON, Texas, Nov. 22.--A double murder occurred four miles east of here about 10 o'clock last Friday night. BOSTON, Nov. 22.--Being still locked out from the Bowdoin-Square Church, Parson W.W. Downs and his supporters hired a hall to-day, and he preached to a large audience. His service was held in Music Hall, and attracted a throng of men and women, many doubtless drawn by curiosity.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 22.--Yesterday's ball game at the Exposition was the most exciting of the series, and was witnessed by 8,000 people. New-York was the favorite, and a great many bets were made. Ewing caught for the first time, and the confidence in New-York was partly due to that and the fact of Connor being in the nine.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22.--A.H. Lighthall, of San Francisco, the patentee of the cable traction tramway of that city, is at the Continental organizing a new street cable company to run in opposition to the Philadelphia Traction Company. The new company, besides operating in this city, will procure a charter granting them privileges throughout the State.
GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 23.--Subscriptions to the relief fund for the fire sufferers have reached $106,000.

The rain did not keep people away yesterday from the store of R.H. Macy Co., at Sixth-avenue and Fourteenth-street. The place was crowded with ladies and children, who had gone there to see the regular annual holiday opening of dolls and toys.

CHESTER, Penn., Nov. 23.--John Sharpless, one of the most prominent of the Orthodox Friends in Delaware County, was brutally murdered at his farm in Nether Providence Township, about two miles from this city, last night.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Fred Douglass, the colored orator and Marshal of the District of Columbia, arrived here to-day and was a guest at the Delavan House for a few hours. Mr. Douglass, while not wanting to be interviewed, did not object to express himself fully on any important question of the day.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23.--A well dressed young man, under the influence of liquor, entered a station house and said he had committed a murder in Chicago.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 23.--The steamer Rio Grande, from Galveston, has arrived here with the cotton in her forward compartment, lower hold, on fire. The compartment in which the burning cotton is stowed is being flooded by means of steam pumps and fire engines.
Recent visitors to this capital will hear without much regret that the plaster group at the top of the Arc de Triomphe is about to be taken down.

The high electric light tower at the intersection of Liberty and Habersham streets fell with a tremendous crash at 6 o'olock, last night. The fall was caused by a runaway mule striking the tower. No one was hurt.
A fire, which probably had its orgin in the spontaneous combustion of oily rags or cotton waste, broke out late last night on the top floor of the five-story building at No. 15 Vandewater-street.
ZANESVILLE, Ohio, Nov. 23.--A bold robbery was committed in Holmes County, near Millersburg, at about 6 o'clock Saturday evening, the victim being a peddler named Honfield.

One of Pinkerton's detectives passed through this city yesterday on the way to Buffalo having in charge P.M.L. Sheppard, whom he had arrested in Florida after a chase lasting nearly 18 months. Sheppard was for 85 years the Cashier in the freight department of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company in Buffalo.

There was not the close fight last night for officers of the Young Men's Democratic Club of Brooklyn that had been expected. The leaders of the two tickets in the field withdrew in the interest of harmony, and with one accord the vote for President of the club was given to Mr. Joseph G. Gay.
"Living for Show" is the title of a new comedy adapted from the German by Mr. Augustin Daly, which is to be produced at the Boston Museum next Monday night.

The remains of a fossil shark, consisting of a portion of a defensive fin spine, were found in the drift in a cultivated field in the town of Benton, in this county, by Mr. David Crozier a few days ago.
The Miss Livingstons keep a millmery establishment at No. 4 Newark-avenue, Jersey City. The store is just around the corner from Police Headquarters and on the main thoroughfare of the city.

The bears on the Petroleum Exchange had another field day yesterday, and prices were knocked down just as easily as if there had not already been a decline of 15 points or so in the two days preceding.

There is a monstrous eel now calmly reposing or swimming in the big fountain at Heublein's restaurant under the Opera House. It is 4 feet long, weighs 7 pounds, and is what is generally known as a silver eel.

The increase of the Sunday business on the elevatod roads, caused by the reduction in the rate of fare, has had the effect of showing very clearly the inadequacy of those roads to the work devolved upon upon them.

Servia's check at Slivnitza has sobered her and taught her Generals discretion. Political considerations, too, have begun to dominate the military situation. If Prince ALEXANDER has really agreed to restore the status quo ante in Eastern Roumelia, King MILAN has no logical around for continuing hostilities.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Clarence Seward sent a telegram here Saturday asking if Attorney-General O'Brien would be at his office to-day.

BUSHKILL, Penn., Nov. 23.--Three weeks ago Mrs. David Meckes, of Ross Township, Monroe County, died while giving birth to her fourth child. Since then the children have all died from scarlet fever, three of them in one day.
Christine Ouldi was taken to ChambersStreet Hospital Sunday evening suffering from yellow fever is an advanced stage. He died at 7:30 o'clock, within two hours after he reached the hospital.

The arrangement which the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company has effected for an independent line to this city is one which the people of New-York can regard with unalloyed satisfaction.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23.--The additional facts learned to-day concerning the atrocious murder of Emma Smith by her husband Saturday night could be numbered on the fingers of one hand.
There was a sad tragedy at Newmarket on Friday, Miss Jummy and Sunrise were almost equal favorites for the Glasgow Stakes, and it was one of the heaviest "gambling races" of the week.

The belief is gradually spreading among the members of the Grant Monument Association that the bulk of the fund must be contributed by popular subscription. A letter received yesterday by the Secretary shows that the belief is not confined to the association.

Since the Lighthouse Board has established a light on Latimer Reef and taken Eel Grass Shoal Lightship from that station, the Providence and Stonington Steamship Company petitioned the Government to place the lightship off Ram Island Reef.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23.--The American Iron and Steel Association has written a letter to the Hon. Daniel Manning, Secretary of the Treasury, in reply to his circular of last July ...

William Peck, the young man who is charged with having enticed from her home in Stamford, Conn., Sarah Gilfoyle, a young girl who was employed as a domestic in the family of his stepmother, and inducing her to come to this city, was arrested yesterday by Detective Price, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 23.--George Miller, a young man 29 years old, blew out his brains with a revolver at the residence of his father to-night. His mother died a year ago, and since that time he had been despondent. It is thought that his mind was affected.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 23.--Since last November there has been steady and growing opposition to Senator Beck, caused by what is said to be his secret friendship for Blaine in the last Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23.--Among the cases upon which the Supreme Court oF the United States delivered its opinion to-day was that of Thomas Drew and Edmund Webb against the Executors of Moses H. Grinnell, late Collector of the Port of New-York. It was brought up on a writ of error from the Circuit Court for the Southern District of New-York.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23, 1885. Mr. and Mrs. U.S. Grant, Jr., called at the White House to-day. They spent a few minutes going through the rooms, and then stopped in the Green Room.

LACKAWAXEN, Penn., Nov. 23.--Four hunters--John W. Hoffman and L.T. Quick, of this county, and W.B. Van Sickle and W.H. Lattimore, of Sussex County, N.J.--had a remarkable hunting experience on Friday on the ridges along the Shohola Creek.
The ceremony of the opening of the Lower Bolan Railway on Saturday last was interesting by reason of its significance with regard to the Central Asian question.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 23.--Lucius A. White, who was arrested here about two months ago charged with the forgery of Brazilian securities, was tried in the United States District Court this morning on three indictments.
PLYMOUTH, Wis., Nov. 23.--Otto Puhlman, a prominent miller and grain dealer here, has failed. His liabilties are $28,000 and his nominal assets $50,000.
The Court of Sessions in Brooklyn was crowded yesterday morning, when Joseph Groblewski was brought in to receive the death sentence for the murder of his wife, Clara, ...
About 9 A.M. yesterday a train made up of three cars left the Brooklyn end of the bridge for New-York, with a full complement of passengers.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 23.--Shortly before midnight on Saturday, C.A. Thorpe, of Perryville, and J. White, of Frenchtown, called at a public house on Gay-street and asked for lodging.
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 23.--Quite a sensation has been created here by the publication of a statement that John Pierson, a convict, has confessed that he was the man who killed ...
The eighteenth anniversary of the execution of Allen, Larkin, and O'Brien, the "Manchester martyrs," was commemorated last evening at Clarendon Hall, under the auspices of the Fenian Brotherhood.

AMERICUS, Ga., Nov. 23.--On the Wilkinson plantation, Lucy Gifferd, colored locked up her five children while she went to church yesterday. She returned at midnigh to find her cabin in flames, two of the children roasted to death, and the other three badly scorched.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Nov. 23.--Travel on the Shore Line Railroad is obstructed in this city. The schooner Louisa Smith, lumber laden, in passing though the draw at Shaw's Cove, stuck fast in the mud, which prevented the closing of the draw. Passengers are transferred in carriages by a circuitous route, necessitating considerable delay. It is expected that the obstruction will be removed by morning.
The annual Thanksgiving Day meet of the American Athletic Club harriers will take place at Pettit's Hotel. Jamaica, Long Island. Trains will leave the foot of East Thirty-fourthstreet at 8:45 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23.--From several Republican Senators who have been in Washington recently the impression has been gained in conversations that the President need not expect to see a fight made against his nominations on political grounds.
John J. McCarthy, a dissipated looking young man, was placed before the bar in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday, charged with murder in the first degree.
A flat contradiction in every particular of the charges made against him by Stenographer O'Connor was the testimony of Justice William H. Kelly before the Senate investigating committee yesterday.

QUITMAN, Ga., Nov. 23.--The excitement which exists throughout this section over the incendiary burning of the colored college here, which took place one week ago to-night, is intense. Suspicion as to the origin of the fire points in two directions, and is just uncertain enough to leave the matter in dispute probably for all time.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 23.--The second trial of Louis Willett, alias Charles Crosby, for murder, began in the Circuit Court and Court of Oyer and Terminer to-day.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 23.--The Rev. Harvey Johnston, of the Colored Union Baptist Church, and the Rev. P.H.A. Braxton, of the Colored Calvary Church, both of this city, have, through ...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 23.--On Saturday evening last Justice-George N. Kemedy, of the Supreme Court, on motion of Louis Marshall, granted an injunction restraining the New-York Central Railroad Company from guaranteeing $50,000,000 bonds of the West Shore Road and from perfecting the lease of the West Shore for 400 years.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 23.--The oil market took another tumble to-day, the closing price this afternoon being nearly 10 cents lower than the final sale of Saturday.
Joseph Larisch, a butcher, was arraigned at the Tombs Police Court yesterday on a charge of abduction.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 23.--The Superintendent of Public Works has given orders that the cauals will close Dec. 1 at midnight.
LEARY, Ga., Nov. 23.--The African Methodist Episcopal Church of this place is in a tangle. This church is presided over by the Rev. Haly Hardy, a coal-black negro.
Kate Belloni, of Brooklyn, cried and looked timidly at Justice Walsh from a pair of liquid blue eyes, yesterday, and said she was not a bigamist.

LONDON, Nov. 23.--Lord Salisbury to-day had a conference with the Queen. The greatest personal interest of the whole electoral field centres in the contest at Birmingham between Mr. Bright and Lord Randolph Churchill, which will be decided to-morrow.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 23.--There was a report in the town of Shellon to-day that a case of smallpox had broken out among the workmen brought in by the Derby Silver Company to take the place of a number of Strikers. The Health Officer of the town denies the report, and many of the citizens believe that the story was due to the strikers.

OTTAWA, Nov. 23.--Mr. Norquay, Premier of Manitoba, has received through the Secretary of State, by an order in Council, a confederation medal in recognition of the valuable services rendered by him to Canada.

Wall-street men, uniting in a protest against the nuisance of obnoxious fumes arising from work in the Assay Office, sent a representative of the law firm of Redfield Lydecker, of No. 20 Nassau-street, to Washington yesterday to ask relief from the Treasury Department.

People who were dissatisfied with the weather yesterday will be pleased to learn that the distinguishing feature of the storm was marked originality. At an early hour in the morning the storm centred at Norfolk, Va. Instead of following in the footsteps of its predecessors and advancing at a hurried gait, it suddenly performed a right-about-face movement, and swept down upon the unexpectant coast of North Carolina.

NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 23.--At 5 o'clock this morning an accident occurred at the north shore of Lake Pontchartrain by which a young man named Charles Lennahan lost his life.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Louis Lounsberry, of Randall, aged 65 years, an employe in the New-York Custom House for 20 years, while in a tree shaking nuts, Saturday, fell 30 feet to the ground and received probably fatal injuries.
CORK, Nov. 23.--A man named Tobin, who has been acting as caretaker on a farm from which the tenants had been evicted, at Araglin, County Cork, was shot dead to-day.
A man with gray hair and a silk cap on top of it sat in a large, dingy room in the Bowery yesterday and talked to women enough to have filled out a "Black Crook" company.

The full details of the agreement for the renewal of the Latin Monetary Union confirm the opinion formed from the discussions of the delegates, namely, that the agreement is directed rather to the closing up of the union than to its perpetuation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 23.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20. Drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 25.

Mr. Nat C. Goodwin, by all odds the best mimic on our stage and a comedian whose drollery is irresistible, was seen last night at the Standard Theatre in a formless sketch called "The Skating Rink," written by Mr. R.G. Morris.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23.--The funeral of John B. Bowman, the murdered ex-Mayor of East St. Louis, took place from his late residence this afternoon. There was an immense attendance.

GALVESTON, Tex., Nov. 23.--The steamer Regius, which sailed from this port to-day for liverpool, carried 9,162 bales of cotton. This is is the largest cargo of cotton ever shipped from Galveston.

William Steeger, a German, 28 years old, came to this country with his wife Louisa in February last. They had been married in June of last year. Mrs. Steeger is 22 years old. Upon reaching this country they went to live in apartments at No. 212 Grand-street, Hoboken.
A fair to raise funds for the maintenance of a home in the country for weary women was opened yesterday afternoon in the parlors of the Murray Hill Hotel.

The will of Dr. William Frothingham, who died so suddenly last week, was filed with Probate Clerk Beckett yesterday in the Surrogate's office by an agent of the Safe Deposit Company of New-York, where it has been placed for safe keeping.

The Williams Alumni Association of New-York held its first meeting of the year at the University Club Theatre last evening. David Dudley Field presided. Speeches were made by J.C. Goodrich, Dr. A.D.L. Jewett, William P. Prentice, Jacob F. Miller, and others.

The diestablishment, and, as a consequence, the disendowment, at least in part, of the Established Church in England, although not a burning question to the political firmament at the present moment, is nevertheless one that will become so in the not very far future.

"Fra Diavolo" was performed a second time at the Academy of Music last evening in the presence of an audience that was remarkably large considering that the elements were unfavorable to an outpouring of the populace.
The New-York County Medical Society held its annual meeting last night, at the rooms of the New-York Academy of Medicine, No. 12 West Thirty-first-street. Dr. Daniel Lewis presided.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23.--If "Tom" Foley and Charlie Parker, who represent Slosson and Schaefer on the Billiard Tournament Committee, have their way, the tie will not be played off, and the money will be divided among the three contestants.

The firm of Straiton Storm has not yet ordered work resumed in all the various departments in the factory, the members preferring to wait until they are assured that the boycott on their goods in Massachusetts has been entirely removed.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 23.--Charles Lund, a Dane, foreman in a spoke factory, was found this morning lying on his back, with his head in a little gully, dead.

BOSTON, Nov. 23.--Cyrus W. Field and Russell Sage arrived in Boston to-night and have been closeted with their counsel at the Hotel Brunswick all the evening preparing to participate in the meeting to-morrow of the Directors of the New-York and New-England Railroad Company.
RANGOON, Nov. 23.--The British expeditionary force has reached Silemyo without meeting with opposition from the Burmese troops. The expedition is in excellent health.

Sir Richard Cross is fully sustaining his reputation. "I want to know," he said the other day, "what Mr. Gladstone will say in Midlothian. I am ready to reply to his utterances." How Mr. Gladstone can have had the hardihood, in the teeth of this warning, to go to Midlothian at all is one of those things which I am afraid Secretary Sir Richard will never be able to understand.
OTTAWA, Nov. 23.--The statement has been party widely that there are in circulation here a number of counterfeit silver coins.

MONTREAL, Nov. 23.--Considerable excitement was occasioned in the city to-day by a report that Gabriel Dumont, the half breed, was in town yesterday. It was said that he arrived in town by the New-York train on Saturday night, and stopped at the Princess Louise Hotel.

For the past four years there has been no little wonderment among the people of Coytsville, a little village of Bergen County, N.J., two miles north of Fort Lee, over the presence there of a family of four persons about whom almost nothing was known.
DEPOSIT, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Forty-two years ago a farm hand named Murcus Hope was accoused of stealing $30 from a farmer named Groner, for whom he worked, a few miles from this place in Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23.--Major Lewis Merrill, Seventh Cavalry, has been found incapacitated by an army retiring board and granted four months' leave.

The Park Police Mutual Endowment Association held a meeting last evening at the Arsenal in Control Park. This association was organized in January last, and has for its object the relief of park officers who are sick.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Nov. 23.--Oliver Terry, a well known farmer of Wallkill Township, went on a spree for two or three days last week. When he got sober he was so much ashamed of himself that he went into his father's barn and shot himself through the heart.

The Governor of Virginia has gone a little further than usual in ordering all the public departments to be closed on, the day designated by the President of the United States as one for public thanksgiving.

ALBANY, Nov. 23.--In the Court of Appeals today, the Hon. William C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following business was transacted: No. 878--The People, respondents, vs. William ...
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 23.--The title to a large tract of land in this city known as the Silver Lake and Oakland additions, and comprising about 600 lots, threatens to be called into question.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23.--The second annual convention of the National Association of Cattlemen was called to order here this morning.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23.--The new east-bound freight rates (25 per cent. basis) went into effect this morning.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 23.--A well authenticated case of petrifaction is reported from the town of Topsfield.
LONDON, Nov. 23.--A telegram from Sofia says that the Servians have bombarded Widdin and that the city is on fire.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 23.--Two very remarkable cases in medical science have been developed in this city during the past two weeks, the knowledge of which has been very closely guarded by the medical profession.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Nov. 23.--James Pells is an old Kingston Point fisherman. On Saturday last when he drew his net into the boat, near Kingston Point, he saw something that drew forth from him the exclamation: "What's that?"
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 23.--The monument which has been erected in honor of Edward Kelly, the Irish leader who was sentenced to be hanged, drawn, and quartered in 1867, was unveiled ...

CHICAGO, Nov. 23.--The Hotel Richelieu, the new hotel in Michigan-avenue, this city, has been leased for a term of years by Mr. Henry Clair, recently of the Metropolitan Hotel, NewYork, and H.V. Bemis, of Chicago, who will conduct it under the firm name of Clair Bemis. Mr. Clair assumes the management of the Hotel Richelieu to-morrow.
The season of grand opera in German at the Metropolitan Opera House was entered upon most auspiciously yesterday evening.

In connection with the works in progress for the repaving and releveling the Piazza of St. Mark an undertaking has been commenced which may lead to results of considerable archaeological importance, and which will be of especial interest to students of the architecture of Venice.

A committee of the New-York Mercantile Exchange, consisting of W.S. Temple, W. H.B. Totten, F.B. Thurber, David Hunt, and J.H. Seymour, forwarded a check for $1,000 to Mayor Fulton, of Galveston, yesterday for the sufferers from the fire.

In his long practice Dr. Carpenter has seen generations come and go. Three generations of many a family have been under his professional care, frequently at the same time. For half a century, closely identified with the active life of the community, his memory is well stored with reminiscences of the city and observations of its people.

LIMA, Nov. 24, via Galveston.--Further official dispatches from Tarma say the forces of Cacers numbered 3,200 men at the time of his occupying Jauja, but that large numbers deserted him before the struggle at Huaripama.
The Rev. Dr. Richard S. Storrs presided at a meeting of the Long Island Historical Society last evening, at which resolutions were...
The fifteenth annual report of the Association for Befriending Children and Young Girls shows that in the year ended Oct. 1, 1885, more than 500 children have been cared for.
BELGRADE, Nov. 25.--King Milan has decided to abdicate the throne. If necessary Austria will occupy Servia in order to prevent the accession of Prince Karageorgevics.

CHESTER, Penn., Nov. 24.--The Sharpless murder is still the absorbing topic in this locality. The delay in arresting the murderer and the fact that such a wretch is at large causes considerable uneasiness.
Louisa M. Van Horn, a doctress and Spiritual medium, was found dead yesterday afternoon in her apartments at No. 241 West Sixteenth-street. Death is supposed to have resulted from natural causes.

WHITEHALL, N.Y., Nov. 24.--E.M. Gifford, of Ticonderoga, while hunting deer this afternoon, shot and instantly killed Edward Rand, 50 years of age, a resident of Hague, having mistaken him for a deer.

BRIDGEPORT, Ill., Nov. 24.--Mr. Crawford Jones, a devout member of the society worshiping in the little church at Walnut Grove, south of this town, scampered home to his wife the other night and told her that he had seen a young man with a shining countenance sitting in a window in the upper story of the church.

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Nov. 24.--Dr. R.Y. Rogers, who registered yesterday at the Edwards House, was robbed of $1,000 during the night. Ever since the State Fair in Macon, this State has been flooded with pickpockets, and many similar robberies are reported.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 24.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 20; drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 25.

Inspector Maloy, of the Bureau of Buildings, made an inspection of the St. George Flats, at Nos. 223 and 225 East Seventeenth-street, which were partially destroyed by fire in the Spring of 1884, and which have recently passed into the possession of the Germania Life Insurance Company.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 24.--William Gardner, the young man who was arrested on suspicion of setting fire to De Golyer Brothers' varnish factory, in this city, twice within a week, has made a confession admitting that he kindled the first fire.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 24.--The National Cattle and Horse Growers' Association was called to order to-day by ex-Gov. Routt, of Colorado.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24.--Walter Dahlborn, an actor, and formerly a member of " A Wife's Honor" company, stood before Justice Kersten a prisoner this morning and exclaimed: "I was not disorderly without reason.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 24.--That Harvard indifference exists more in theory than in actual fact was well shown this afternoon, when 300 students stood out on Jarvis field in a driving, pelting rainstorm for over two hours to witness the final game of football in the class series for the championship of the college.

Business at the Federal Building had scarcely begun yesterday morning when W.S. Warner and J. Henry Work, accompanied by their counsel, Charles F. MacLean, appeared at the United States Circuit Court and asked what amount of bail was required under the indictments found against them on Monday by the Grand Jury.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 24.--The steamer Rio Grande, from Galveston, which arrived here yesterday with the cotton in her forward compartment on fire, is discharging her cargo. Her lower hold is full of water that was pumped into her to extinguish the fire, which is now apparently under control. The extent of the loss cannot yet be ascertained.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24.--The Directors of the Keely Motor Association met to-night at the Lafayette Hotel. Charles B. Collier, of New-York, said: "In view of the many comments on the 'Keely Motor' it was recently planned to submit...
MARSHALVILLE, Ga., Nov. 24.--The members of one of the negro churches in this county gave a possum supper last night, which ended ingloriously.
MONTREAL, Nov. 24.--The last vessel of the season, the steamship Coban, of the Black Diamond Line, left port this afternoon.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 24.--At Delaware, Ohio, to-day Mrs. William Dunlap, who had formerly moved in good society, being a member of a leading church, was sent to jail for 60 days to subsist upon bread and water and fined $100 for cruelty to her stepchildren.
